text: Text: 'Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy. But it might not be. In many developed countries, rubbish collection is a common service. Rubbish bags or bins are collected by a special truck and taken away. Usually, this service is paid for by local taxes, so families that produce a lot of rubbish pay the same as those that produce little. However, more rubbish means more collectors and trucks are needed, and local authorities pay more in landfill fees. If rubbish disposal is free, people might produce too much rubbish. The solution could be to make families pay for each bag of rubbish. This might encourage them to throw away less and recycle more. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this idea has complicated results. They studied American towns that started charging for rubbish. The most common system is to sell stickers for rubbish bags. Only bags with stickers are collected. In Charlottesville, Virginia, people were charged 80 cents per bag. The number of bags fell by 37%, but people just packed more rubbish into each bag. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14%. In other towns without this system, it fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also dumped rubbish illegally to avoid paying. Recycling increased by 15%, but this might not be because of the fee, as many people were already recycling. In another study, the economists found that higher prices for rubbish stickers reduce rubbish weight, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices cuts rubbish by only 0.3%. People would need to buy less of everything to reduce rubbish a lot. Other factors like income and education might also affect rubbish production. Richer towns produce more rubbish and have less time for recycling. Charging for rubbish is not a bad idea, but the effects are complex. Simple policies can have complicated results, and sometimes they don't work as expected.'

Text: 'Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special, but now you should ask what your job does to you as a person. Does it help your mind, character, and relationships? This is important. If your job makes you boring or too busy to learn new things, then money and status are not enough. I want to find out how work can help us grow as people, not just be a way to make money. Work should help us discover new talents and meet different people. This does not mean getting rid of unemployment. People want jobs that are interesting and useful. Work should be like art, with happy people at the center. Many jobs, like doctors and accountants, are not as appealing as before. Doctors are stressed, and accountants worry about ethics. Architects and administrators feel limited. Middle managers are losing confidence. Companies are getting smaller, and new ideas like decentralization and performance rewards are not working well. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel their values match their company's values. I am studying different jobs to see how they affect people. I look at happiness, love, friendship, and respect. I want to find better ways to work. Many experts focus on making companies last longer and earn more money, but we also need to think about what kind of people we want to be. Are we really alive at work, or are we just working because we have no other choice? For example, hotel workers often have low pay and long hours, even though they are smart and lively. Hotels have not changed much since the old days. They could be places where people from different countries meet and learn from each other. Hotel staff could have more meaningful jobs, but accountants focus only on profits. Work should be about relationships. People want to be independent and choose their jobs and colleagues. They need to talk to people from different fields. Communication is important, but real conversation is more than just talking. It helps us understand and respect each other. Every good conversation can change the world a little bit.'

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**

The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand. This is an agricultural idea, but it also represents modern growth and success. Broadcasting involves spreading information widely, like seeds, from a central source. 

When television was invented, it was set up as a centralised 'mass' medium, similar to the telegraph and telephone. This means that information was sent from one place to many homes. This fit well with the way societies were organised at the time. 

There were some experiments with different ways of using television. For example, in the 1930s, some people in Britain tried to use two-way television, like a telephone. Magazines showed how to build TV transmitters and receivers. However, big companies set standards that made it hard for these small experiments to continue.

In the early 1930s, television was mostly watched in public places, like theatres, in the USA and other countries. In Britain and Germany, people often watched TV in public settings. The idea of two-way or amateur television did not become popular.

Manufacturers saw that they could sell many TVs for home use if the price was right. As people started to have better living standards, especially from the 1920s, having a TV at home became possible for many. This led to centralised broadcasting, where information was sent to many homes.

Broadcasting helped governments share important information with everyone. It also helped create a sense of community in countries. Broadcasting was seen as a way to give people equal access to information, which is important for democracy.

Today, television is changing, and the idea of broadcasting might also change. The term 'broadcasting' might only refer to a certain way of using technology during a specific time in history.

**Clutter**

Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you have, you never feel safe. It is normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes wanting more things can get out of control. Modern advertising is made to make us feel insecure. It often tells us that if we don't have certain things, we are not good enough. To see how much you are influenced, try not to read any advertising signs next time you walk down the street. These expensive messages try to make us buy things without us even noticing. We see them everywhere - on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, the internet - all telling us to buy, buy, buy.

**Caves**

Scientists and universities around the world study caves. They want to know about their origins, water, and life inside them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and we want to learn more about them. Because caves are natural, they have been studied for a long time, especially in places where they affect our lives. However, visiting many caves needs physical skill, so cave research is often done by people who visit caves for fun, not just by professors. There is a special connection between professional scientists and amateur cave explorers.

**Weather Watch**

Many people who watched the weather without any tools helped start the science of meteorology. Since the 17th century, it has become a very technical science. Satellites and electronic tools give us weather information quickly, and computers solve difficult math problems very fast. Meteorology uses long words that are hard to understand for most people. But simple weather knowledge is still important. Human experience is needed to turn computer data into weather forecasts. Human observations can still give special information that helps professionals understand the weather.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Not long ago, I thought opera was mostly about theatre. But after working at a national opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. This is how it should be. However, I come from the theatre world, where the words and the actors are the main focus. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once the play starts, and the performers and audience usually speak the same language.

At a music performance, like in a concert hall or opera house, many people, like me, might not understand music technically. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A great singer or a perfect orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows us the result of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching a sports match - we know athletes do something similar to us running for a bus, but they do it much better.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often do not understand an actor's skill and are not very impressed by something that seems close to what they could do. They are not usually amazed when an actor finishes a long speech, although they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This does not mean theatre audiences are more generous or less demanding than music audiences. Many people go to both. But in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how challenging the play is.

Does music need to learn from theatre about this relationship? I think yes. Music in live performance is full of passion, humor, and emotion. It can go wrong, and it connects with the listener's imagination. But the way music is presented, with strict dress codes and respect for conductors and soloists, often feels too formal. Also, when audiences clap between movements or after a great performance, it can interrupt the flow of the music.

Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done to bring new audiences to concerts and operas and to make serious music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a high-quality musical experience, and it changed many audience members' lives. They were not just watching and listening but also participating.

I wish music had more of the risk and excitement that theatre can have. Sometimes, using unusual or challenging locations can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, but theatre audiences have learned to follow artists into unexpected places. Most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. But I believe something should change in music performances. I am just an enthusiast who loves theatre and music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**

I think sand is amazing because it can become useful things like glass and concrete. But, I don't like sand on the beach. It is a problem between the car park and the sea. Sand blows in your face, gets in your food, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove. But when you step on a towel, get in a car, or walk on a clean carpet, sand falls off. For days, you find sand on the floor when you take off your shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a long time. I don't like sand.

**Lock and Key**

People have always wanted a safe home. Long ago, they used a beam behind the door. Now, we have electronic locks with many combinations. But people still like using a key. Some companies tried using smart cards for locks, but people prefer keys at home. One company made a new electronic lock with a real metal key.

**Modern Art**

I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because I don't understand modern art. I like some things, like furry art, neon lights, and big photos. Maybe if I knew more, I would have more opinions. Art is not about understanding but feeling it. This idea doesn't work for me. But the new gallery helps visitors understand art. The labels explain the art and what it means. This information helped me understand the pictures better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

When books are turned into movies, a lot of the story is cut or changed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also be interesting. When I worked on a movie script, I saw that I could remove a lot of the talking and details from the book and still tell the same story. This doesn't mean the book's words were not needed. It's about how each type of story, book or movie, needs different things. In a book, we often see repeated details about characters or who is speaking, which helps us understand better. In plays, which are mostly talking, the extra words can make it feel like real conversation. Some modern plays use a lot of extra words that don't add much meaning, just to show people are talking.

**Watching Movies**

When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the movie world. It's like escaping from real life for a while. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, we return to the real world. In the past, some people thought movies were just for fun and not real art. Our parents and teachers often thought this way. They liked movies but didn't see them as art.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were many small rooms that looked the same. There were three main entrances, but none had a place to ask for directions. It was confusing for new people, but not many strangers came there. The people who worked there knew their way around. Together, they made movies that brought romance and adventure to people, helping them escape from their daily problems for a few hours.

**Film-makers**

Many people want to make movies. There are many books and courses on how to write scripts and make films. Some competitions even give away cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make his movie El Mariachi, which cost $7,000. This movie made him famous. He wrote about his experience, saying he wanted to make a great movie before he turned 25, like famous directors Orson Welles and Steven Spielberg. In the past, film-makers took longer to become successful. They worked in different jobs in the studio before directing their own movies. But now, without big studios to help, new film-makers have to be more independent.

Text: 'In those days, the council houses were all over the west side of the city. They were rows of small, old houses in orange brick or white stucco. In summer, the chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, made the air smell bad. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose as he walked to deliver newspapers. I have forgotten most of my early life. But I remember sitting near an upstairs window, looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. Later, I remember faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that I don't think was ours, and snow falling over a big mansion at Earlham. My mother is in many of these early memories. I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or into the city, I knew she was different. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, alone even in a room full of people. She also had strict rules about how to behave, which was unusual in West Earlham. This sometimes led to big cleanings or telling me to 'behave properly'. I didn't understand these rules. It meant not going into neighbors' gardens or touching their rose bushes, sitting quietly in the dining room with hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and many other rules. Over time, other people appeared in these early memories. My mother had some friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who said very little, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively and not liked by the others. Later, I realized they were not very cheerful company. They talked about bad legs, cold weather, and ungrateful children, a group I often felt I was in. Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' was on my shoulders. I felt I had to grow up and get free from it. This was not easy. Growing up in West Earlham had a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug while my mother sat in a chair. After your fifth birthday, in September, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile away. Some lucky children had a mother with a bike and a child seat. I think my mother let other children take me to school. If I remember anything about these early years, it's the summer holidays. These were days when you saw a bit of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity event at a house far away, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and talked about the League of Pity, a junior charity. But my mother said they just wanted money. My mother often talked about people wanting money, and she didn't like politicians. She thought they were rich people who took money from the public. Maybe I exaggerate. Maybe I forget her good points and focus on her faults. But my mother didn't have much kindness. To be fair, she did care about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she took me on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would look at paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother didn't mind this and even started to have opinions about the paintings. I remember her once looking at a painting of a Roman soldier and saying, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' This was the only time I remember her trying to make a joke.'

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. It was getting dark, and the air was thick with a light rain. This side of the street was familiar to me since I was a child. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. Each house was special to me, just like the little paths in the cement that took rain from the roofs to the street. I used to pass them on my roller skates or scooter. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed a bit less fancy. The porches were lower, and the front yards were smaller. Over the years, things changed: wooden porch railings were replaced with iron ones. In Shillington, some houses became stores, and some stores, like Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in those spaces that used to be shops.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert is a furniture designer. He lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. The flat has big doors and brick walls. Gilbert didn't want an open space because it was hard to relax or work when everything was in one room. So, he used a big plastic sheet to create a hallway and hide his office. This also led to the kitchen, which he wanted to be a place for both cooking and meeting clients. To make the flat feel warm, he used light wood floors and added furniture from his parents and markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. His first book, "In Patagonia," was published in 1977. It was a travel book that felt like a thriller and a romantic story. Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make his stories more interesting. He believed that through travel, people could discover exciting histories.

**Swimming**

One summer, during a heavy rain, I swam in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles on the water, and it felt magical. In 1996, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and escape the routine of swimming back and forth in a pool. Many places today are marked and explained, but activities like walking, cycling, and swimming let us explore the wild and mysterious parts of the world. A swimming journey would help me see the world in a new way.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying had no clear purpose. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps mothers and children become close. Many people think children cry because they feel helpless. But why do adults cry? It seems that the look of crying is more important than the sound. Crying might have helped early humans build trust and connect with others. Tears can also have other reasons. We might cry to show we care about people who suffer. Sometimes, we cry without wanting to, like when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, especially when we are with others. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**

We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it change our lives? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but no one is sure about its effects. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on Earth, changes in climate will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. So, any changes to these resources are important.

The problem is knowing how the world will change and what causes these changes. In the last 100 years, human actions have increased certain gases in the air, which are linked to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the climate, but we do not fully understand how. We do know that greenhouse gases and global temperatures have changed together over the past 40,000 years, showing they are related. Evidence shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C in the last century. Most scientists think this is partly due to human pollution.

Scientists use computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict future climate conditions. These programs use physics and chemistry to study temperature, pressure, and other factors. However, they are not perfect and can be slow and costly. We do not fully understand all climate processes, but we know the climate system is complex. Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before.

GCMs suggest that by 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and rainfall patterns will change. Extreme weather like heatwaves, floods, and droughts may become more common. These changes will affect ecosystems, like forests and grasslands, and the resources we depend on, such as food and water. Some effects may be irreversible and harmful, but not all. Some climate changes might be helpful. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat production since 1952.

However, many future effects of climate warming are not good. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry areas. The Mediterranean Basin is already seeing less rain in some parts. Changes in glaciers will affect ice and wildlife habitats. The Arctic ice might melt completely, which could help marine transport but increase iceberg dangers.

The most visible effect of global warming might be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds to the ocean. About half of the world's people live near coasts, so rising sea levels could cause severe problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo might face flooding. Many people could lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island countries could disappear if sea levels rise too much, affecting their people and culture.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong in body and mind. This will be the profile of the first astronauts to go to Mars if millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to send a capsule on 5 January 2018 work out. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, because saving fuel is important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth are in the right position is in 2031. It is a big challenge, but the race is on to create new technologies. If these can be ready soon, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it never leaves Earth, trying to reach these goals will help future missions.'

**Aesthetics**

Sometimes, the way we think about art makes it hard to understand. Art is often seen as just a physical object, like a building, book, painting, or statue. But real art is about what these objects do to our experiences. This misunderstanding can make it difficult to truly appreciate art.

Some art pieces are so admired that they become "classics." When this happens, they can seem separate from the human experiences that created them and the effects they have on our lives. This separation makes it hard to see their true meaning.

Art is often put in a special place, away from other human activities. This makes it hard to connect art with everyday life. People who study art need to show how art is connected to daily experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of human life.

To understand art, we sometimes need to look away from the art itself and think about everyday experiences. We can enjoy flowers without knowing about plants, but to understand them, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. The same goes for art. We need to start with simple experiences that catch our attention and make us happy.

Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comics without thinking of them as art. But these are the arts that are most alive for many people today. When art is only seen in museums, people look for enjoyment in their daily lives. Some people who don't like the idea of art being only in museums still think of art as separate from everyday life.

The best times for art are when it is connected to everyday activities. This is when people appreciate art the most.

**Observing Lions**

People often think that lions hunt in a very organized way. At sunset, a group of lions quietly moves and surrounds their prey. Lions seem to work well together to catch food. But after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. We started our research in 1978 to find out why lions hunt together, take care of their cubs, and scare away other animals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its young survive, then working together might not always be good. If an animal is too kind, others might take advantage. So, why do lions work together? We thought we would find the answer in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. It took many research methods to learn about their behavior. Wild lions can live up to 18 years, so we are only now getting answers to our questions.

**Pop Music Review**

Bedrock's third album was very important for the band. "New Life" changed rock music in the country for the next ten years. The old style of music was serious and had loud guitars. The new style was lighter and mixed different sounds. The album had songs about everyday life and feelings. It also had fun and serious songs. The album showed that Bedrock was good at writing songs. They wrote about things like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. The album's best songs were about deeper feelings, like "So Low" and "To the Brink." "New Life" had 16 great songs with no bad ones, which is rare for long CDs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I loved stories about "The Sibyl," wise women from ancient times. My mother told me a story about one Sibyl. She offered nine books to a king for 300 gold pieces. He said no, so she burned three books and offered six for the same price. He refused again, and she burned three more. He finally bought the last three for 300 gold pieces. I learned a lesson from this story. I was often a lonely child. I wanted to play with other kids, but they said no. My mother told me to do something interesting so others would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot this lesson. When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something I cared about. I don't like traveling much, so I sent my editor a list of places I didn't want to go. I like to learn about ruins because I enjoy thinking about the past.

**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**

When you send your manuscript, it goes into a big pile called the "slush pile." A junior editor or an experienced person who works part-time will look at it. They want to find something new and interesting. If they like your novel, they will give it to a senior editor. Then, it will be discussed in a meeting. The editor must explain why your novel is good and if it can sell well. They also want to know if you can be a successful author. Publishers often want to meet you before they decide to publish your book.

**Advertising in the Early 1990s**

If you worked in advertising in the early 1990s, it was a tough time. The economy was bad, and the recession was worse than expected. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were high, people spent less money, many lost their jobs, and many homes were taken back by banks. Every business was affected, especially car and building companies, which lost 30% of their business.

People in advertising were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They had to help their companies make money with smaller budgets. They were told to do more with less money. At the same time, marketing became more important. Companies started to focus on making products that customers wanted, not just what was easy to make. This made marketing more respected but also more challenging.

In the 1980s, advertising was very successful, but the 1990s started with a big downturn. This was partly because of the bad economy, but also because companies started to question the value of advertising. They wanted to know exactly what they were getting for their money. Advertising was under more scrutiny than ever before.

Companies wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, and media placement from advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working hard for them. This meant that people in advertising had to find ways to do more with less, just like their clients.

Other challenges made advertising difficult, like changes in population, the power of retailers, changing consumer needs, more sponsorships, and stricter advertising laws. Some companies also had to learn how to advertise in other countries.

Because of these challenges, people in advertising had to figure out which parts of their work were effective. Help was hard to find because companies and agencies were busy dealing with these problems. Successful companies often kept their strategies secret. Books and seminars on advertising were not very helpful because they often made advertising seem easier and more successful than it really was.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Cooking was not a popular job. Chefs work long hours, have a lot of pressure, and do not earn much money. But I still wanted to be a chef. I was not happy at university. The work was hard, and the social life was not fun. Being a chef seemed like a good change. It felt serious and honest, unlike my college life. I also loved the idea of cooking. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The meal was amazing. I wanted to thank the chef who made it. After that, I wanted to learn how to cook like that. I started reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making big meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The school's swimming teacher was a small, strong man with tattoos. He used to be a drill sergeant. I asked him to teach me how to dive. He told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward. I practiced this for an hour. Next time, he had me stand and dive off the edge. He was very strict. He always told me to look up and keep my legs straight. The next week, I went to the high diving board. It looked very high. I was scared but tried to be brave. I jumped and felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, my dive was not good. The instructor was not happy, but I felt great. I thought, "This is what it means to be free as a bird."

**The Traveller**

For people who like comfort, travelers seem strange. Travelers choose to take risks. They climb dangerous mountains, sail alone in big seas, and eat strange food. They live with the unknown. Some people think travelers are odd. They are different from our everyday life. We like our safe world with microwaves and phones. We think travelers are not important. We are happy with our predictable lives.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, but he spends a lot of time on it. He is not the best sailor, but he is good. He sails because he likes to write about it. Sailing gives him stories to tell. His boat has a device that shows his exact location. He likes this device, but he thinks other sea tools are not good. He believes the compass changed how people see the sea. Before the compass, sailors watched the waves and felt the sea. Now, they just follow the compass. The sea is now just a space to cross. Raban thinks this is why he can look at the waves so closely.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books help us feel more at home in the world. We can see our own experiences in stories from long ago or far away. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought only we felt. They express our thoughts clearly. We feel thankful to these writers for helping us understand ourselves. Reading and travel help us escape our daily routine. Our eyes are open when we visit a new place or read a great book. We notice things we ignored before, like the sky, a friend's actions, or a hidden sadness.

**Author's Note**

These travel stories were first in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I made small changes to some parts, but not much. I fixed a few mistakes, but only small details. I did not change the stories to predict the future. For example, in a story about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell later. I wrote the story as it happened, not knowing the future. This is the story of travel: seeing the world with just a ticket. I believe other travelers notice things too. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

The word 'ecotourism' is often misused. It started in the 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Travelers wanted to know their trips did not harm nature. It became a popular term for holidays. Now, 'ecotourism' can mean many things, like living with tribes or a short boat trip. It includes cultural, natural, or adventure tours. The original idea was to help people make good choices, but without clear rules, travelers can be confused.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook from my trip to Transylvania for 50 years. I found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time, but I did not write much then. I stayed in friendly homes for weeks and stopped writing. I thought there was nothing to write about when I was not moving. When I started writing this book, I worried about the order of events. But then I decided it was okay, so I let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**

Fashion is not just a modern thing. Many people think it started with the business growth in the 1800s and 1900s. But, fashion has been around for a long time. Historians say it began in the 1500s and 1600s when trade and markets grew. As societies became more complex, and more types of clothes were made, the meanings of clothes also became more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people and in different situations.

**Writer**

People often think that all writers are rich and famous because of stories about big book deals. But for most writers, life is different. Many writers have other jobs during the day and write in the evenings. Some, like me, do different small jobs, like teaching or writing articles, to make money. I have heard about a job writing for a chocolate factory, but I never got such a chance. Still, by doing part-time jobs and with help from friends, I manage to write my books.

**Sudden Fame**

Our small shows around the country started to sell out, and we needed more security to handle the excited fans. We had to use secret ways to enter the places we played to avoid being surrounded by fans. On our days off, it was hard to go out without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched our every move, and our management took care of everything we needed. Even though I was always shy, I started to feel strangely confident, which is something only shy people who suddenly become famous might understand. In short, I felt overwhelmed.

**Music and the Future**

Technology is changing our lives at work, home, and in our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, we had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, there are fewer live music shows and jobs for musicians. More people can listen to music now, and this will probably continue because music is important to us. Music is part of big events and personal activities. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the future, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn instruments.

The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain. Musical skills will still be important for jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can also help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that music can improve thinking skills. In Europe, group music lessons help children with social skills and focus. Playing an instrument might also help with skills like studying and being organized.

In the future, people will listen to more types of music. New styles will mix different kinds of music. Technology will help people compose and play music, making it easier for everyone to create music. This might mean fewer live performances. More people of all ages will want to make music together in their communities.

To prepare for this future, music teaching needs to change. More people should be able to learn different instruments throughout their lives. Music lessons and tests will need to change to stay relevant. Musicians will need to learn how to teach and inspire people of all ages and work with different groups. They will also need skills in communication and management for community work. This is a big change from the past, but it is a chance to show the quality of music education.

Finally, we need to make music more important in our lives. Music is crucial, but often not appreciated enough. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**

Sometimes, people make fun of actors. This happens because actors often talk about their work in interviews. They should be like the dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." But instead, actors often use boring phrases or talk about gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once said that acting is interesting only when you do it. Talking about it makes it seem empty. Every time an actor starts a new play, they learn everything again. When the play ends, they feel empty until the next one. This emptiness is clear when people talk about acting.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester plays Hamlet as a young man between boyhood and manhood. His performance is simple and confident. He understands the text well and controls his body and mind. Lester plays Hamlet as a young man full of anger but also funny and lovable. His performance is very skillful. Watch how he moves his body, like he is waiting to come alive. Handy, who plays Horatio, also shows this feeling. Acting makes us ask: What is acting? What is behavior? Is acting copying real life or creating something new? Who controls the actors' bodies and minds? This is a big question in theatre.

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. Actors sit quietly and listen. When it's their turn, they read the line, think about its meaning, and wait for the right moment to speak. For example, if the line is "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, imagine the scene, and then speak. The director says not to plan too much. Go with an open mind and trust that something will happen.

**The Perfect Theatre**

The perfect theatre makes you feel like your presence matters. Going to the theatre is special, and the staff should feel this too. The theatre should connect the performer and the audience. Everyone should see and hear well. The size of the theatre is important. It should fit the human voice and body. Many old theatres did this well. They feel like they have a history, like old church steps. You can't please everyone with a play. People don't know what they want to see until they see it. When you go to the theatre, you want to see something surprising. Otherwise, you could just stay home.

Text: 'Paul Simon Rock and roll in the 1950s was mainly for young people, but it was also important for older people. It changed the middle class and middle-aged people a lot. It also helped create new rock stars. These new stars listened to rock and roll and knew it would be a big part of their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this exciting new music was on Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was very popular with young people who wanted to be rock stars. Like young John Lennon in Liverpool, who listened to Radio Luxembourg to hear rock and roll, Paul Simon loved the music on Freed's show. He was ready to go from listening to music to making his own music. Snow I could not see a path, but I thought I would be okay if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke. I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had made a roof over a gap between two rocks. I climbed out, feeling scared and thinking about what I would do if the hole was deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think. In one hour, I had walked about half a mile. I knew I had to change my plan. Qualitative Research There are many books that try to help researchers with qualitative research. These books talk a lot about collecting data, but not much about how to analyze it. Many people do not know how researchers look at their data. So, we asked different social scientists to talk about how they analyze data. The idea was to share how they do it, not to make a guidebook. This means making hidden steps more clear. This sounds easy, but it is not. We let our contributors show their work in different ways, like personal stories or more formal writing.'

**Screen Learning**

A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting like a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs. He didn't remember much. Many people like learning on the internet and computers, but is it a good way to learn? One writer tried an interactive program with his son. The father read the words, but the son played with the pictures. "If he had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something," said the father. TV, like my son and his noodles show, gives ideas but not much detail. Research says learning happens best when talking with teachers or parents. New technology can help teach children, but formal education is still important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world's film-making moved to Hollywood. Locals didn't like it, seeing their area of Los Angeles changed by new people. But in the end, success was more important. Success in Hollywood means making money from movies. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: it might make a star, but it must make money. In less than 100 years, Hollywood grew from a small village to a famous town like New York, Rome, or Paris. A century ago, you would walk through orange groves to the village store. Now, it is still like a village with one main topic: films. People talk about how much money films make, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to live somewhere else but work in Hollywood. It is still the place where many people in show-business want to be.

**Photography**

Photography was invented in the 1800s by artists. They wanted to keep a lasting record of what they saw. They found a way to make images that were more real and detailed than paintings. This worried other artists. At first, art critics liked the new images, but then they said photography was not art. They thought it was too mechanical. But photographers knew they had found a new art form. They used cameras like other artists use brushes and pencils. They wanted to show the world and its beauty, as well as people and things in it.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, every children's book had illustrations. This was also true for many novels for older readers. But as time went on, there were fewer illustrations because books were printed in smaller numbers. Children's publishing was busy, but it was often done with low budgets. This led to some average work, but the best artists always did their best. The black-and-white illustrations from this time are a mix of good and bad work. They are interesting for research or just looking. The best works will be shown again, either in new books or exhibitions. There are signs that people are starting to appreciate these illustrations again. Soon, a publisher might make a series of classic children's book illustrations from this time.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**

Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone online where you are. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are also telling everyone, even people you don't know, that you are not at home. This made people think about the problems of sharing too much online. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people. This can be exciting because it might bring us money or fame. So, we start sharing our secrets, photos, and stories online. But soon, we realize that the internet can be a dangerous place, and we can get lost in it.

This might sound sad, but don't worry. There is hope. A long time ago, some brave people started sharing their lives online. They learned about the dangers before social media existed. These people, the first bloggers, experienced many things that we are now facing. We can learn from their stories.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the web. Back then, the web was mostly used by students and scientists. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a website full of his personal stories, photos, and art. In 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people read about his life. Hall shared everything, and nothing was off-limits. But one day, his website disappeared, and there was only a sad video called "Dark Night." Hall had fallen in love, but his partner said, "Either the blog goes, or I do." Hall realized that sharing too much online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the problem of sharing too much online is still here.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a young woman in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a coworker sent her blog to the bosses, and she lost her job. This is called the "online distribution effect." It means we feel we can say things online that we wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected. If we forget this, we can make big mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. She stopped blogging for a while but later started again, writing about her family. Now, she is a famous "mommy blogger," and her blog helps support her family. Armstrong learned an important lesson: just because we can say anything online doesn't mean we should.

Text: 'Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and rich countries, more people have trouble sleeping and feel anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books talk about people who can't sleep or about sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep: how it works, why we need it, and what happens when we can't sleep. A sleep expert says, 'People need more sleep. They sleep less when they are busy and wake up early to avoid traffic.' 

A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to sleep about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep. In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and how dangerous it is to drive when tired. They find people to study by advertising in student newspapers. These people are paid and asked to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner says some people worry because they put electrodes on their heads, but they only study physical things.

In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. People come at 2 pm, after little or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road on the screen goes on and on, and the room is warm. Many say they won't fall asleep, but Dr. Reyner has a video of one person trying not to. At first, he is awake, but then he starts to blink and nod off. The car goes off the road. Coffee can help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for a short time. She suggests using tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum, especially for people who work at night.

We know some things about sleep. Humans sleep in cycles like other animals. There are four stages of sleep, from light to deep. We dream in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injury. Scientists think women sleep half an hour more than men, and older people need less sleep, but they don't know why. Some researchers say sleep helps us 'travel through time without injury.'

In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then slept again. This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poor liked this quiet time. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer hours, changing sleep patterns. In some places outside Europe and America, people still sleep in short periods. They wake up to watch for danger or take care of the fire. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.'

**Text for A2 Level:**

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots in the Arizona desert. I had a full cowboy outfit, but I was not a real cowboy. I looked at the Arizona mountains and knew I did not belong there. I flew from Denver early in the morning and thought I might look like a cowboy. But when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport, I knew I was not one. He wore an old T-shirt, needed a shave, and carried a dirty bag. He looked at my new boots and walked away.

I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. But I don't race anymore. I don't know what to do now. I thought I could talk about races on TV, but many other drivers want to do that too. I also tried to sell old cars, but nobody was buying them. Being an "ex" racing driver is hard. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a champion. Even if I was a champion, people would only listen for a short time.

I miss racing cars. I miss the speed and the excitement. I miss being famous. People used to want my autograph. Now, I have a lot of free time. I looked at the sky and saw some birds. They seemed to tell me to leave their home. I realized I have a lot to learn.

**Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people walk down the city streets, and if you join them, you will hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver for its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and the mountains, clean and safe environment, and good schools and jobs. Some people complain about the many new buildings, but the new people and tourists have helped the city grow. People used to call Vancouver 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Now, Vancouver is more of a gateway than ever.

**Writing Letters**

Journalists like me are usually not good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because we try hard to make our writing have a big impact, so writing a simple letter is difficult for us. Real artists, who don't think about the effect of their words, don't have this problem. I think a real artist knows how to use words well. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about why they were so good, but they showed he was a great writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap star, a disc jockey, or a minor royal would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that they don't need famous people. Last week, people waiting to enter a new Superbuy didn't care who opened it, as long as they were first in line. The first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel happy and those who came late feel jealous.

**Citizen Kane**

The film *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941. There was a lot of talk about it before its release because people were worried about William Randolph Hearst, who the film was said to be about. Even though the reviews were very good, the film did not make much money at first. It was television that made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is a film that has inspired many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said he succeeded because he didn't know what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a film about a newspaper owner who was like Hearst. Welles saw this as a great chance for himself as both director and actor.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He told her twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped at the golf club on his way home. He needed to talk to someone, and the golf club was the best place for it. Carmel nodded her head but seemed like she didn't really hear or understand. Dermot asked, "Will you be all right? What are you going to do today?" Carmel smiled and said, "Funny you should ask that. I was just thinking I had nothing to do all day, so I was going to walk downtown and look at the shops. I thought it was almost a sinful thing, just wasting the day." Dermot smiled back and said, "You're allowed to enjoy yourself. And if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't worry about it." Carmel replied, "No, that's fine."

**Title Race**

A recent study showed that job titles can cause jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a big recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey found that 70% of office workers would give up a pay raise for a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title. It seems that people care more about their job titles than money. Today, nobody wants to be called a subordinate. The titles focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to say the same thing.

Text: 'The Vienna Assignment I was in Vienna to take photos. That was usually why I was anywhere. Photos were more than my job. They were part of my life. The way light touched a surface always excited me. One picture, one snapshot, could show the essence of a time and place, a city, a person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo. As long as I had film in my camera, there was a chance. Finish one roll, load another, and keep looking. That was my way. It had been for a long time. I almost succeeded once, when a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became popular in newspapers and magazines worldwide. It was just luck. But they say you make your own luck - both good and bad. I went freelance after that, which seemed smart, but life outside photography took some wrong turns. The mid-nineties weren't as successful as I thought they would be when my photo was on the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photos and getting paid. That was fine with me. The assignment was a bit of luck. I did the London photos for a picture book: Four Cities in Four Seasons - London, Paris, Rome, Vienna. It was a European project that paid me well to take photos in my home city in spring, summer, autumn, and winter. I gave my own view of daffodils in Hyde Park and traffic in Piccadilly. I accepted that the best of my work might be ignored. It was just a picture book. It wasn't meant to change anyone's views. After a cold Christmas and New Year, I handed in my London-in-winter photos and learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job. They offered me the role instead. The Austrian publishers liked my work. Also, I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was happy to go. Things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna was a good escape. They put me up at the Europa, in the heart of the old city. I had last been to Vienna with my wife for a busy summer weekend. It was hot and not very memorable. I hadn't taken many photos. Alone, in a cold January, it would be different. I knew it when I got off the bus from the airport and saw the city. I was going to enjoy myself and take great photos. The first day, I didn't even try. I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to feel the city's mood. The weather was set, frozen like the old empire's buildings. I hadn't seen what Schussner did with other seasons. I didn't want to. This was going to be my Vienna. A photo is a moment. But you have to wait for the moment. So I waited and looked until I could see clearly. Then I was ready. The next morning, I was out at dawn. Snow overnight meant Stephansplatz would be white and empty. I hadn't figured out how to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its spire was tall, but at the bottom, it was huge. Probably there was no way to do it. I'd have to settle for part of it. In that weather, it could still be magical. Photography has always been magical. In the 19th century, people thought it was magic before they understood the chemistry. Pictures develop and become strong on their own. You can watch a blank paper become a photo. Even when you know why it happens, it still feels mysterious. That feeling stays with you forever. Maybe that's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't surprise me.'

**Kinetic Art Exhibition**

Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It has become a place full of wonder. This change is not because of a big, expensive show, but because of a special exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or shows movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art in the 20th century. It shows that making art that moves has been an important but often unnoticed part of art in the last 60 years. The exhibition has many paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. Guy Brett, who has studied this art for a long time, put it all together. There are not many explanations, so visitors can enjoy discovering things on their own.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art is liked by many people, even those who usually do not care about art. People might like his work because it is easy to understand or because it shows fun and relaxing subjects. Some people might be interested in Hockney because of his friendly personality and clever words in the media. Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. But others say he might seem less important because he is very popular, not because his work is not good. Hockney knows his limits and does not claim to be a great artist. He believes only time will tell how important his art is.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

I have seen many contemporary art exhibitions. Some are great, and some are not. I do not like shows that try to push a certain idea or trend. Sometimes it works, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was different. I worked with seven artists in an empty warehouse. The show, called 'Window-shopping,' was a collection of different artworks. The only thing they had in common was that they were all art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats moved around on a toy train track. Matthew Crawley opened a video camera and broke it, which showed on a screen. These works did not fit into a theme, but they worked well together. I did not try to make a big statement about art, but I think art is personal, and artists decide what they want to do.

**Art History**

People who like paintings sometimes do not want to analyze them. They think it might ruin their enjoyment. Some say art historians focus too much on theory and forget the pleasure of looking at art. This is like saying knowing how a dish is made ruins its taste. But knowing more about art can make it more enjoyable. Our enjoyment of art is not just about our personal taste. It is also influenced by the society we live in. While enjoying art is important, thinking about it does not take away from the experience. In the past, people thought art was separate from thinking, but this idea is outdated.

**Metals**

A long time ago, people in the Stone Age might have found metals because they wanted to look nice. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, and finding a shiny yellow stone. This stone was gold. It was not like other stones, and it was very pretty. Gold was easy to shape, so people liked it a lot. Copper might have been found by accident too. When people saw how useful copper tools were, they looked for more copper and learned how to get it from rocks. This is how metalworking started.

**St Ives**

We walked down a small, winding street with our bags. The wind was very strong, and the waves were cold and big. No one was outside, and the windows of the houses were closed tight. We saw the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. The sky was dark, and visiting Cornwall without a car did not seem like a good idea anymore. I told my friend we would have nice walks by the sea and warm evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is hard because it is gone. The people who lived in peace or had hard times are not here anymore. We do not know why they moved or stayed in one place. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas on past cultures. We cannot watch the past like a movie. But maybe we can. With computer modelling, we can make old landscapes and put virtual people in them. These digital people can act like real people. We can change things like rain or population and see how these virtual people react.

**Vervet Monkeys**

Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys. One day, the leader male monkey saw a new male monkey in nearby trees. The new monkey wanted to join the group. If he joined, the leader might lose his position. To stop this, the leader monkey had a clever idea. When the new monkey tried to come closer, the leader made a loud call that means a leopard is near. The new monkey quickly went back to his trees. This happened many times. But then, the leader made a mistake. He made the leopard call while he was walking calmly on the ground.

**What Cats Catch**

In a village in England, people counted what their cats caught. In one year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor saw this and thought all cats in Britain might catch 100 million birds and small animals each year. But this is not true. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals. The important question is: are these numbers too high? The answer seems to be no. In winter, people feed birds, and gardens have places for birds to live. So, the bird population stays high. The survey showed cats are hunters, but they are not destroying the bird population in Britain.

**Buffalo's Day**

Buffaloes are very important to marsh people. Every morning, buffaloes leave their sleeping place slowly. They make tired sounds as they move to the reed beds. They stand at the edge of the platform, making noises about the hard day ahead. Finally, the leader buffalo moves into the water. In the water, they seem to forget their plan and stay there for a while. Slowly, they start swimming, looking very tired. They spend the day in the reeds, eating green plants they find.

**Picasso's Painting**

In 1940, Picasso painted fish while staying in a fishing port. The painting shows a fish seller's table with a crab and some fish. The fish look alive. The painting is hard to understand because Picasso used flat shapes and soft colors. It looks like an underwater world. But there is tension in the painting. The fish and crab seem ready to fight. The sharp shapes and a chain around a fish add to this feeling. There is a hidden sense of danger in the picture.

Photography

For the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture all parts of human life. In this short time, photography has grown to show moments in time and space, letting us see both big and small things. It has shown us pictures from faraway places on Earth and in space, as well as the complex and difficult parts of modern life. Photography is a powerful way to show human experiences.

However, using pictures to record events is much older. The first pictures go back to about 35,000 years ago. We do not know exactly why early humans made cave paintings. They might have shown real events, helped with hunting, been religious symbols, or just made life more colorful. But pictures have always been important to human culture.

People have always wondered if pictures show the truth and what their role in society is. The idea that "seeing is believing" gave pictures a special place. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a true visual record. The camera, like the human eye, was seen as a tool that could capture a real image. This image was thought to be very close to what we see.

Photography was seen as a great cultural achievement, creating images that artists had worked hard to make by hand. Because photos seemed so real, people thought everyone could understand them. This led to the idea that photography might be a "universal language." In 1933, photographer August Sander said even isolated people could understand a photo of the sky.

But as global communication grew in the late 1900s, we had to ask if photos could be understood across different cultures. Is photography limited by cultural rules like language? Are we so used to photos that we forget how complex they are in showing "reality"?

Photography is often seen as clear evidence, making it seem like there is no difference between real life and photos. It is common for someone to show a photo and say, "this is my grandson."

Since its invention in 1839, photography and how people use it have changed a lot. Photography has moved from just keeping records to becoming historical documents. Photos now tell us about the people and society that made them, not just the subjects in the photos.

The camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography can inspire social and political change. For example, the Italian Renaissance in the 1400s used new ways of showing images. Similarly, photography has helped create our media culture and also shows the world's harsh realities.

**How to Write Poetry**

Writing poetry can be tricky. It's like walking through a field with hidden dangers. You need to be spontaneous, but one wrong move can cause problems. It's hard to give advice because everyone is different. The best way to learn is by reading a lot, writing often, and using your imagination. Some people need to feel safe to write, while others write when they are sad. Some write on a schedule, and others wait for inspiration. All ways are good if you are true to yourself. It's important to find your own voice and let it grow.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, you can't have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used if necessary. A character's memory can help move the story forward. Dialogue, or conversation between characters, is useful because it shows different sides of a story quickly. It keeps the reader interested. A short story should not be too long, but it should still have conflict and action. Every word should be important.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. At first, you might not know what will happen next. You learn by playing more. In chess, you need a long-term plan, not just short moves. Over time, you see the whole game and patterns. Screenplay writing is similar. The more you write, the more you understand its complexity.

**Looking at Writing**

Charles Darwin said that speaking is natural for humans, but writing is not. All societies have language, but writing systems were invented only a few times in history. Writing started in complex societies and improved slowly. In the past, most children didn't learn to read or write. Even today, many children find it hard. Children naturally learn to speak, but writing is something they must learn with effort. We need to understand how writing works and how children learn it.

I have never started a book with more doubt. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and I don't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only sometimes, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up things to fill the gaps and make my story clearer, but I don't want to do that. I only want to write what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the people in this story made-up names, and I have tried to make sure no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. Maybe he never will be. When his life ends, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water. Then my book, if read at all, will be read only for its own interest. But maybe his way of life and his strong and kind character will influence others, so that, long after his death, people will realize he was a remarkable person. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know about his early life may find something useful in my book. I think my book, with its limits, will be a good source of information for my friend's biographers. I do not claim that the conversations I have written are exact. I never took notes of what was said, but I have a good memory for what matters to me, and though I have put these conversations in my own words, they truly represent what was said. I said earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the freedom that historians take to put words in the mouths of people in my story that I did not hear myself. I have done this to make the scenes lively and realistic. I want to be read, and I think I am right to make my book interesting. The smart reader will see where I have used this trick, and he can choose to ignore it. Another reason I started this work with worry is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is very hard to know people, and I don't think you can really know anyone but your own countrymen. People are not only themselves; they are also the place they were born, the home they grew up in, the games they played as children, the food they ate, the schools they went to, the sports they played, and the poets they read. All these things make them who they are, and you can't know them just by hearing about them; you can only know them if you have lived them. You can only know if you are them. And because you cannot know people from another country except by watching them, it is hard to make them believable in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because you can describe your characters briefly. You give the reader a general idea and let him imagine the details. In this book, I do not pretend that my characters are as they see themselves; they are seen, like my main character, through my own eyes.

**Poetry Recitals**

Today, poetry can be confusing because there are many different styles and ideas about poetry. Some poets write poems to be read in books, while others like to perform their poems in front of people. This has been happening more and more over the last twenty years. 

In small towns, people gather in village halls or homes to listen to poetry. Schools and colleges invite poets to read to students. Arts festivals also have poetry readings by famous poets. 

For poets who like to perform, these events are good. Their poems are simple and easy to understand when heard. But, when you read them on paper, they might not seem as good. 

Poets who focus on writing carefully crafted poems might not be appreciated by people hearing them for the first time. They might choose to read their simpler poems to connect with the audience quickly. 

Listening to poetry is fun and helpful, but it is not the same as reading it. Hearing a poet read their work can show you how to understand it better. It is good if the audience can read along or know the poems beforehand. 

The main reason for poetry recitals is to make people enjoy poetry and not see it as something only for experts. Sometimes, these events include music, like jazz, to make them more enjoyable.

**Oral History**

Historians are using more oral evidence, but it has problems. It is not simple to think that someone's story is a clear picture of the past. In an interview, both the historian and the person telling the story affect each other. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence changes how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is influenced by the historian's position and how they understand history. Historians help create new evidence. The person telling the story is also not directly connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with other things they have heard, like from TV. They might remember the past as better than it was or feel upset about things that happened later. Feelings make the story seem real, but they might come from later events, not the past.

**Animal Science**

There are two main ways to study animal science: looking at how the body works and looking at the whole animal. Physiologists study how nerves, muscles, and senses work together for behavior. The 'whole animal' approach looks at the behavior of the entire animal and what affects it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are different. Psychologists study learning in animals like rats and pigeons in labs. Ethologists study natural behavior in wild animals. These two groups are now working more together. Physiologists think their methods are more basic. But even if we know how every nerve cell works, we still need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own structure that we must understand. Describing a bird's nest-building by nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

Students studying social science for the first time face a challenge. They need to learn the content of the subject and the methods used to study it. They must know the facts and how these facts are found and organized. Social sciences are not just common sense. Each social science looks at a different part of social life, uses different study methods, and has its own ideas. These ideas help social scientists go beyond common sense and make each discipline unique.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He used Greek words for some of these ideas, which came from an earlier Greek source. Utility and function are not part of his definition, but he does talk about the best forms for different buildings. The focus is on architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins. There was a long history of simple huts in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These simple forms were important and influenced later architecture. The classical temple, though fancy outside, is basically a simple, single-room hut.

**Simplified Text:**

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, near the railway line and gasworks. She once made a mistake by jumping a small bridge with all four wheels in the air, but Chen found it funny when he found out. He was happy and said, "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" Mui thought men were strange because Chen wasn't upset. Instead, he was excited and planned a trip with Lily. They chose a Monday at the start of next month, the quietest day of the week, to leave early and return by midday, so they wouldn't lose customers. Lily practiced driving around the allotments in the meantime. Mui, despite her worries, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. Lily felt a bit hurt by Mui's lack of trust in her driving skills.

On the day of the trip, they left home and soon saw the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was ready to give directions from the back seat, had to admit it. Lily even passed a few slow cars with great skill, and Chen clapped for her. They drove through the seaside town, past the lagoon with small motorboats, and along the empty promenade.
