Lily parked in a street with many empty parking spaces. She wasn't sure about the road markings, so she decided to pay a parking fee to avoid any trouble. Lily locked all the van doors carefully. Chen joked, "Don't worry, no one will want that old van." The sisters were annoyed. Lily said Chen was ungrateful, and Mui told him he was too easily fooled by looks. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He held Man Kee on the railing and thought about his future. Chen wanted Man Kee to have a good education and own many restaurants one day.

The sea made Chen feel thoughtful. He saw a ship in the distance and used a telescope to look at it. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it—a small, old, rusty ship. Chen showed it to Man Kee and said, "This is a special ship for us. It will take us back home one day." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them. Chen said, "Let your mother see the ship, Son." But Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope. When he finally did, the view was gone, and Lily only saw a white light. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared, and Lily saw seagulls instead.

**THE WELL**

I read that if you dig a deep hole, you can see stars during the day. I wanted to try this, so I asked you to help me. You watched as I pulled up the well bucket and climbed in. I told you to let me down. I didn't think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not be strong enough. You tried to hold the handle, but I fell into the well. I hit my head and saw strange lights. Later, I realized they looked like stars in cartoons when someone gets hit.

At first, I was confused, then scared, then angry at you for letting me fall. I was also worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I didn't answer. You ran to get help. I climbed out of the well and hid. I heard Mother, Father, and Arthur looking for me. I felt happy but then saw the wet spots I left on the ground. I was scared they would find me.

Mother was screaming, and I knew I had to do something. I came out of hiding, pretending to be hurt. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat. I said I swam through it to escape. Father asked me to repeat my story. I added that the tunnel collapsed after me, so no one could find it. Father didn't believe me. He looked at me with disappointment. Arthur also looked sad, knowing I was lying.

I realized my lie was obvious, and I felt ashamed. Father's words hurt me, and Arthur's look made me feel even worse. I understood that lying was wrong and that I needed to change.

**Moving Day**

Susan is a widow. Her children are grown up. She has to leave her family home. The moving van says "Removers of Distinction." Susan sees that everything special in the house is being packed. Fred, the removal man, is careful with the breakable things. His helpers are not as gentle. Susan is leaving a lovely house. It is a four-storey building near a small harbour. She remembers the years her children grew up there. 

When they bought the house, her son Robert, who was five, asked, "Mum, when you buy a house, how do you get it home?" Now, Robert is an adult and is helping with the move. He makes sure Susan does not talk about the piano. Francesca, her daughter, is also helping. She is very careful with the Steinway piano.

Fred, the removal man, says, "She doesn't look like she's going to cry." Susan asks if people cry. Fred says, "You'd be surprised. They cry when everything is in the van, but they are fine at the new place."

Susan remembers when they moved in. The piano was the first thing they brought in. It got stuck on the stairs. They had to cut the banister rails. Peter, Susan's late husband, solved the problem. They took out a window and used a crane to bring the piano in. It cost a lot, and they couldn't tune the piano for months. Peter said, "That's there forever." But forever is a long time. 

Now, Susan is not as mobile, and the children are busy. She thinks about the stairs and the banister rails. She should have warned the movers, but it is too late. Fred says, "It's just the piano to come now." Susan is nervous. Robert and Francesca watch. Fred and his team move the piano down the stairs and out the door. 

Robert laughs first, and then they all laugh. They are relieved it is over. They walk down the path for the last time, arm in arm, laughing. The only tears Susan sheds are tears of laughter.

Text: 'Online Book Reviews for Everyone

Writing your own book reviews: is it just fun? From the start, the Internet was meant to be open to everyone. In theory, anyone could share their ideas or start a music channel online. But in the early days, you needed some technical skills. However, one area really became open to everyone: book reviews. On Amazon.com, the first big online bookstore, anyone could write a book review. Amazon allowed anyone to say what they thought about a book and give it up to five stars. This seemed like a great idea. Each book had its own page, and new reviews appeared automatically. This way, Amazon got free reviews, and people could see what other readers thought, not just what the publisher or professional critics said. Other online bookstores did the same, but Amazon was the biggest, with over 80% of the market. Because of this, Amazon had the most reviews and also some problems. Many reviews were submitted every day, so it was hard to check them all. Amazon had a team to make sure reviews followed their rules. Reviews with just one word, personal attacks, bad language, or spoilers were not allowed. But reviewers were anonymous, and bad reviews were only removed if Amazon found them. This allowed for some tricks. For example, writers could give their own books great reviews. One writer, Lev Grossman, wrote fake positive reviews for his book after getting bad ones. He was caught when he wrote about his trick. Authors could also comment on their books by clicking a special link. Most authors used this to encourage people to buy their books. Some even shared their email addresses. But Amazon did not always check if the comments were really from the author, except for famous writers. A fake comment pretending to be from John Updike was removed. Problems mostly came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it got good reviews from the press. But people in the book felt upset and wrote angry reviews on Amazon. These reviews disappeared after a few days. Despite this, Amazon liked that many people wrote reviews because it was good for business. Reviews were meant to be a place to talk about a book, not a chat room. Amazon watched popular books closely to make sure reviews followed the rules. Funny reviews were often posted on less popular books. For example, a children's book called The Story about Ping inspired jokes because 'ping' is also a computer term. One review compared the book's story to the Internet. But most reviews on Amazon were serious. They gave a good idea of whether a book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books meant making up feelings about books you didn't care about. This is why letting everyone review books is a good thing.'

**Art in Modern Times**

In the last 200 years, people often think that artists must be different from others. We like art that is new, surprising, or shocking. We admire artists whose work was not liked 100 years ago. But with today's art, we sometimes feel unsure and say it is not art. The media often say this, and we agree because we expect art to be new and different. We forget that today's art also has old themes and methods. We think artists are special and different from us. In the past, people asked artists to make art for specific reasons. Today, artists work alone, and we get upset if they try to be like everyone else.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and ask an important question. An artist picks a piece of text from an art book. The text talks about different pictures and says, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist asks someone to make a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter writes the text on the canvas in simple black letters. My question is: Is this a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery, London until 26th June

Artists usually stick to one style if it sells well. People expect them to keep doing the same thing. Some artists, like Picasso and Hockney, change styles and succeed. Eric Rimmington is trying something new. He is known for still life paintings but now paints the London Underground. He likes railways and has made 40 paintings and drawings of the underground world.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. The villagers joke that only a sick person would come here to rebuild. I am alone except for an old woman who cleans the house. I am not happy or unhappy. I think about the past. Art helps me find meaning in life. It lets me see the important parts of reality. Art is a way to deal with what hurts us in life. It helps us use our imagination to find our true potential. Otherwise, why do we hurt each other?

Text: 'Family Business'

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father and my brother Maurice had just picked me up from my school. I had won the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my exams. My father talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I knew what he was thinking. My father usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you will get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I said. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also heard," he continued, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can understand things quickly, you like talking, and you enjoy performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."

"Anyway," he said, "I feel you won't want to join the family business now. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."

Like many children, I felt trapped by family expectations. I wanted to explore other jobs. But I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him strong.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was often right, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, unhappy. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant."

My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and I often took care of him. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived well - a big house in London, good schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was always lively.

"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then decide. It will give you some pocket money and help me."

"OK," I said, happy to avoid making a decision now. My father would get upset if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.

So it happened. In my last term at school, and during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on easy tasks. I became a smart student, with a little house, a small white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me. He took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor said I might get a First Class degree in Law. I felt ready and focused.

But my father told me he needed me for one last job, the most important for the family business. He promised it would be worth it.

"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams soon, and I need to focus on them. It's really important."

I could tell my father didn't understand my pressures, or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him. He would see a refusal as a betrayal.

As he explained the job, I saw his dedication and skill. He was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money. At first, it seemed like a good idea because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois got a raise at her advertising job, making thirty-five thousand. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. They could have found this in a cheaper area, but Lois wanted a better address. She felt their old place wasn't good enough for a young barrister and a successful businesswoman.

To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated well after a long day. But times had changed. Lois made it clear that her career was as important as Simon's. They needed both salaries for their lifestyle.

Now, their life was at risk because of Venetia. She came to their office angry, accusing Simon of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed a jury four years ago. She also said Cartwright gave shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. Simon denied it, but his denial sounded weak. He felt guilty and remembered being punished as a child. He wished he had said Cartwright was lying to make himself important. Venetia didn't believe him, and he worried she could ruin his career. If people heard about this, even as a rumor, he would be in trouble.

Text: I chose this place to live because I thought I could be anonymous. I hoped people here wouldn't care if the houses were old and the gardens were messy. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, but tonight, I am watching the birds fly. I have cleared some space in the garden for a chair, and my arms are scratched. It is a small London garden, where plants must grow tall. 

My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She writes books that are not published, and I sometimes have to talk about them because I am an English teacher. I have her latest book now. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask you about your work all the time,' she says. Then she offers to bring a drink. I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I see it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'So, you're on holiday now,' she says. She sits on the chair while I put a cushion on the grass. 'Cheers,' she says. 'I should've been a teacher - a writer doesn't have holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'So, what plans for the holidays?' she asks. 

I feel worried about the school holidays. Empty days. Hot streets. The walk to the shops and back. The little park with its fountain, and feeling lonely on the bench. 'Actually, I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask. My heart races. 'Of course,' Jaz says. 'If I'm around,' knowing she will be. 'Where will you stay?' she asks. 'With my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun,' I say. It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. 'Going back to your roots. So what do you think of my book?' Jaz asks. Her book, The Cruelty of Red Vans, is on my desk. I like the title and tell her. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing things to other houses and returning her manuscripts. I decide to be honest. 'Try writing about nice people for a change,' I say. 'Teachers!' Jaz says, upset. 'I keep a journal,' I say. 'I write something good about each day.' 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann,' Jaz says. 

Oh, I've got a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes. When we go inside, my kitchen feels calm. Then I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now, winking and saying, 'I've had my moments.' We almost died laughing.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it helps people feel connected to the past. We often know about our personal heritage, like who our grandparents were and stories about their lives. But we also need to learn about our past to understand our future. Heritage gives us a sense of continuity, helping us feel part of history. Just like we inherit our genes, we also inherit culture from past generations. There might be parts of our national heritage we don't like, but it is still ours, and it makes us feel part of something bigger. Heritage teaches us a lot and is important for our well-being. It affects our customs and the things we use every day. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. But now, because of changes in society, many of these stories are lost. Instead, we learn from places and buildings that remind us of the past. It is important to keep these links to remember our ancestors.

**The Fens**

I started writing a book called "Waterland," where the Fens, a part of England, became important. People ask why I, a person from London, wrote about a place I don't know well. I chose the Fens because they seemed simple and empty, a good place for my story. But I learned that the Fens are not empty. They are very English but also strange and mysterious. Many English people find the Fens foreign, even though other unique areas in Britain are part of the country's culture. The Fens are both empty and full, wild and cultivated, open yet mysterious. I didn't visit many places in the Fens while writing. I like to imagine places rather than just describe them. The Fens are not just a place but also a feeling.

**Museums**

Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, this meant putting items in cases with long labels. Now, displays should be interesting and use creative ways to catch visitors' attention. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can lend objects to schools or use them to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums show real items, not copies. They help people see and understand things from the past. This makes them different from theme parks or books. Museums that make their displays exciting and accessible will find that people want to see the real things they offer.

**Architecture and Environment**

People have always wanted to keep things from the past, but now changes in towns happen quickly and affect everyone. Some people want to preserve everything, while others think about how towns should look in the future. People who have lived through big events, like wars, may want to preserve things more. If people need to preserve things, planners should consider this. Change is not bad if we know how to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in society, like how many people live there and what they need.

**Einstein**

If you ask someone to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used to sell smart products like computers and encyclopedias. Most people don't know much about what Einstein did, except that he made some theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions. Einstein was part of a big change in science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to describe the universe better by studying matter and forces. Einstein helped by looking at time, space, matter, and energy in a new way. Before, people thought like Isaac Newton, who said stars and planets moved in a fixed space and time. Einstein said time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

When we were children, Lydia and I did not like prize-winning books because we thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this, but our father would give us money to read good books. He also gave us some books as gifts, saying they were not just literature. We thought most of these books were for boys, but we did read some short stories and a book of poems.

**Language**

In 1851, Jacob Grimm said that the origin of human language is a secret and amazing. Many strange ideas have come from this mystery. In 1928, Charles Caller said early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were in danger. These sounds were sad, and languages kept some of these sounds, like "malaria" meaning "fever". Because of these strange ideas, many people did not talk about language origins. But now, it is an important research area. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly talk and power struggles, not for sharing information, which is different from what philosopher John Locke thought.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Most reviews are written quickly and are not read for long. They have deadlines and are usually short. When published, they are only read for a short time, like a day or a week. People often think reviews are not important. Many believe writers do reviews because they need money or because they can't work on big projects all the time. But writing reviews is a skill. It is different to write a short review for a newspaper and a long one for a journal. Reviewers must think about who will read their review. Some readers just skim, while others are very interested in the topic. A reviewer needs to know a lot about many things and write clearly. Reviewers often write other things too. For example, the American writer John Updike writes reviews when he is not writing novels. He collects his reviews in books. Some people think only famous writers should keep their reviews, but others believe anyone can do it if they want. I feel the same about my work. I am a professor, and my main job is academic writing. But in English-speaking countries, it is normal for professors to write reviews too. In the past, some people thought professors should not write reviews, but now it is common. There are more reviews now, so many people can write them. I think this is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It is also good for professors because it helps them communicate better with people who are not professors. Writing reviews is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph opened the door to his apartment. As he walked into the dark, quiet hallway, he felt a small worry about owning the place. Even after three years, he sometimes felt this way when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the apartment, he used to come home excited and curious, often as early as he could, wondering what the apartment had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place to him, where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like burglars or broken pipes, but the apartment always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he started to see it as just another part of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated that it couldn't change. Sometimes, there were letters by the door or the answering machine had messages when he got home. He was glad the windows weren't broken and nothing was stolen, but he wondered what it would look like if that happened. From his boring office on the third floor on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his three or four quiet evenings at home each week. Once he left the busy office and started to feel like himself again on the bus ride home, he didn't need to be alone anymore, but he often forgot this when planning his social life. At his desk, he wanted to be alone with his things, but once he got home, he felt empty and waited for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a big emptiness, making him think that doing work he didn't like had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He often read or listened to music at night, but now he wondered why he did these things. His thoughts and feelings were unclear, and he felt lost. There was a time, he thought, when he didn't feel this way, when he could have changed his life if he had known his own value. But he was eager to find something, so he followed the first path that seemed right. After university, he tried to make a plan for a better life, but he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without thinking he could find happiness in his work. He went to one job interview and didn't think much about the job itself. It was an editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was happy to have a nice conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't think about the long meetings he would have later. Neil offered him the job right away, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many ice-cream vans, lots of people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving towards the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. A part of the area was marked for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the track. They tried to keep some goats in order. It was not easy because goats can eat almost anything.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I thought about the night and felt scared. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was no place to stop. We had not seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our torch to see the cliffs. The torch batteries were low, so we put in new ones, but they did not work. We could not find a camping place. A few miles later, Lesley saw a light, and we felt hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we could not see it. Time felt slow, and we kept moving.

**How to be Good at Presentations**

I am not good at making presentations. But as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and big shareholders. How can I get better at presentations and feel more confident? You are not alone. Presentations need different skills than running a company. Many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you say. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. Do your homework. Test your ideas before the presentation. Ask colleagues to find the 'hard questions' the audience might ask. Start with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your conclusion.

Some activities cannot be rushed. They need time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you add oil too quickly to mayonnaise, it will not work. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot gets tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things it does very fast, like solving puzzles or doing math. But other things take longer, like learning or thinking deeply. If you rush these, they might not work well, like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.

We learn and think in different ways, and these ways work at different speeds. "He who hesitates is lost," says one saying. "Look before you leap," says another. Both are true. The mind has three speeds. The first is faster than thought. Some situations need a quick reaction. For example, when my motorbike slipped on a wet road, my body reacted quickly to keep me safe. A concert pianist or an Olympic fencer also reacts quickly. This fast reaction is called our "wits."

The second speed is thought itself. This is when we think carefully, like a mechanic fixing an engine or a student doing homework. We call this "intellect." People who are good at this are called "bright" or "clever."

The third speed is slower. It is more relaxed and dreamy. We use this when we are thinking deeply or being creative. For example, when sitting by the sea and listening to the waves, we are in this slow thinking mode. This slow way of thinking is important. It helps us solve complex problems and be creative. Scientists are now studying this slow thinking. They find that it helps us understand difficult things better than fast thinking.

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**

I have been welcomed warmly. It is a friendly and well-supplied camp in a very isolated place. There are about forty people here - scientists, students, weather experts, and satellite trackers. We are a close group, and everyone helps each other. My basic French is just enough to talk, but not to have fun conversations. I miss the small details, and my phrasebook is not helpful at breakfast. This is not a big problem for me, but at first, I felt less confident. I was a bit scared of mealtimes. I would wait, worried about which table to sit at, afraid of the silence when I spoke, nervous like I was in my first weeks of school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think the reason I sometimes feel sad is not because I miss talking to people, but because I have lost the social confidence I used to have.

**Elliot**

When I first met Elliot, I was just a young writer, and he did not pay much attention to me. He never forgot a face, though, and when I saw him again, he shook hands with me nicely, but he did not want to become friends. If I saw him at the opera with important people, he would pretend not to see me. But then I had a big success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot liked me more. One day, he sent me a note to invite me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After that, because my success brought me many new friends, I started to see him more often.

**Alfred Hitchcock**

The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care about the story of his films or the acting. He cared about the photography, the music, and all the technical parts. For Hitchcock, it wasn't the message or a great performance that moved the audience. He believed that people are excited by pure film, no matter where they are from. So, if a film is made correctly, people from Japan and India should react the same way. Hitchcock was always clear and logical about his work. He was a man of reason and a talented craftsman who liked to hear an audience scream. He didn't guess or use abstract ideas, and he didn't explore his characters deeply. He focused on film, pure film, and the exact, calculated beauty of what a film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and catalogues. Telescopes were simple, and there were few books on how to do astronomy. Today, you can buy many different telescopes and equipment. Electronic calculators and computers have changed how we make charts and study the stars. This might be the best time for amateur astronomy. But, some things are not as good. Now, you might have to travel 80 km to see a sky like the one in cities 50 years ago. Airplanes leave trails in the sky that can last for hours and make it hard to see the sun and stars.

**Too Much Choice**

Today, there are too many things to do and too many choices. People always want the newest product or service. Technology makes things change quickly. There are always new products coming out. This can make people feel tired and stressed. More choices mean more stress and less time. People are now looking for simple things that make life meaningful. But, it is hard to make life simple when there are so many products. There are more types of soap and cereal than we need, and too many software updates and phone plans to remember.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother. We do not let anything change this tradition. The people who stay at McAndrews are like us: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like rude shop assistants or waiters who act too friendly. I know most of the guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children. We greet each other politely but do not have long conversations. It is hard to find this kind of respect for privacy in hotels today.

**Othello**

A special show of Shakespeare's play "Othello" moved from Stratford to London. I want to change my earlier review of this play. Before, I said Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello and criticized his acting. I still think Othello should be older than Desdemona, but I now believe Mr. Fearon's acting is excellent. The whole cast is great. Some memorable parts are when Cassio plays games with other officers, and things get out of control, and when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very emotional. The play is exciting and full of tension. Don't miss this show.

**Lake Vostok**

In the middle of Antarctica, there is a place where nothing moves. Around the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But in the center, there is no life. Except for a large hidden lake called Lake Vostok, under almost 4 kilometers of ice. This lake has been without air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Scientists are eager to explore it and find out what strange creatures live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also interested. For two years, researchers from around the world have been planning to study the lake. In the next few years, we might learn a lot about Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was an interesting talk on the radio last week. Some scientists are discussing why they want to be scientists. We know they want to learn about everything, from atoms to black holes. But they are asking why we want to know these things and why science can't explain this. It is important to know if what scientists do is right, rather than worry about why we do it. The main point is that science is a tool, and we should decide how to use it.

**Food**

Food is important and makes us happy. Many people think cooking is hard and only for special days. But that's not true. You can make a tasty soup by putting some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs in water. This is better than buying soup from a packet or a can. Instead of buying a chocolate mousse with many chemicals, you can make a delicious one in five minutes that everyone will love. Cooking is a way to show care and love. Sharing food is important for people, and we celebrate special days like birthdays and weddings with meals. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party!

**In the Elevator**

This morning, Alistair tried to clean his office, but papers were everywhere. Tax forms and other papers filled his desk and boxes. He also had many books and journals. As he went up in the elevator, he knew Mallory would be on time for their meeting. She was always on time and liked things neat. He wondered what she would think of the mess. Mrs. Wilson, who cleaned for him, came while he was trying to tidy up. He hoped she would help, but she only cleaned his apartment, not his office. She thought he was from somewhere far away, not from her world in Brooklyn.

**Karen**

Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She made her own story of strength. When she was twelve, her brother accidentally hit her eye with a golf club. She thought she was blind, but the doctor said she was okay. She only needed a few stitches. When she saw her mother in the doctor's office, she felt she was saved for a reason.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty was walking across the village green. She felt both happy and sad. She was happy to know something important first, but sad about Dr. Bailey's health. He was her doctor for many years and helped her with her throat problems. He always listened to his patients and made them feel important. The village loved him for this.

Joanna's Lessons

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. But she also writes books for young children learning the piano. Joanna is famous for her amazing piano performances. She plays many styles of music like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for kids, a boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna found it funny and played it, making the boy happy.

Joanna is different from many top pianists because she cares about how children learn the piano. She wrote a book called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World" for beginners. She did this even though she has a very busy schedule. She performs at many festivals, runs her own recording label, and likes to work with other artists.

Joanna believes the first piano lessons are very important. She thinks music should be for everyone, not just for those who want to be stars. She grew up with many children learning different kinds of music at her home, where her mother taught piano. Joanna wants everyone to try learning the piano, just like learning to swim or speak a little French.

Some children learn piano quickly, but others take more time. Joanna is interested in helping those who find it hard. She worries that some parents push their children too much, making them feel they have to be perfect. Joanna wants music to be fun and enjoyable.

Her books are colorful and have stories to make learning fun. They come with CDs that have music for parents or teachers to play with the child. Joanna thinks practice is very important. She didn't practice a lot until she went to the Royal Academy of Music. Now, she practices eight hours a day and loves it. She says it's important to know what you want to achieve when you practice. Her advice is to mix hard and easy pieces and enjoy playing.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**

Dr. Johnson said, "What is written without effort is read without pleasure." This means good writing is hard work. When I look at my old school essays, I see few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think this is because writing by hand is slow and makes you think carefully. It is hard to change or erase, so you write with care. But with computers, it is easy to be careless. Many writers find they spend the same time fixing computer drafts as they did writing by hand. Also, emails are not as personal as handwritten letters. People say emails have brought back the love letter, but they often lack the feeling of handwritten words. Words on a screen can seem harsh and lose their meaning. 

**The CD**

I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not special, but the shiny disc was interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said. I agreed and gave the disc to him. "Amazing they hold seventy minutes of music," he said, turning on the hi-fi. He pressed a button, and a drawer opened. He put the disc in and closed it. "Some say they sound sterile, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "No," he said. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He thought for a moment. "I don't know. You could have two lasers or turn it over by hand." He smiled. "Good point." He pointed to my chair. "Let's get you in the best place for the stereo effect."

**Books versus Electronic Text**

Malcolm Bradbury said if matches came after lighters, we would think they were better. People say electronic text is like the invention of printing, but changes take time. In 1979, a book said books would disappear in the 1980s. That was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is hard, so people don't do it. Computers make people read bits of text. Some say this leads to new ways of storytelling, but non-linear reading is not new. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from start to finish. Computers don't encourage reading everything in one go.

**The Office**

Charles walked into the office. It was neat and tidy. The carpet was clear, and the desk was dark wood. Files were in drawers, and journals were on shelves. Kathleen said, "You need to use computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, looking at the room. He did not think about computers. They had talked about this many times. She did not understand why he resisted technology when he was good with computers and had written a paper on it. She inspired that paper. She could use any software and make it do amazing things.

Text: "You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She wasn't really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She sometimes forgot because he wasn't supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He found that staying away caused too many problems. Lancelot thought about how he went from being an important advisor, meeting authors and playwrights over lunch, to being very busy with no time to park his car in the morning. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder before putting it in front of him. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see another synopsis. He wanted to see a "First Draft." Ian Cuthbert had been given a lot of money for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, but he was not easy to work with. Lancelot skipped the introduction and looked at the synopsis. It was almost the same as before. He closed the folder and put it aside. Ian's manuscript seemed like it would never come. The synopsis was not very good and lacked excitement. Lancelot remembered a story about a famous author whose last book was published incomplete after his death. Ian's advance was large, which was not a good business decision. Lancelot, who studied languages at Oxford, remembered when Ian was a promising talent at Cambridge. Ian's friends took over British theatre quickly, but Ian was even more talented. He wore his coat like a cape and talked about famous writers as if he knew them. But Ian's talent stayed hidden. While others succeeded, Ian became more difficult. He was chosen to edit an arts magazine but never published it. His contract with a fashion magazine was renewed three times, but he produced little. At meetings, Ian was witty but critical. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot was starting to think that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the beginning.

Text: 'Breakfast in England

Health experts say breakfast is very important. But in history, breakfast is quite new in England. In medieval times, breakfast is not often mentioned in books. Sometimes, travelers ate early before long trips, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles. 

In the sixteenth century, breakfast became normal for everyone. Some people think this is because there was more food. But there were also big social changes. For example, people started working set hours and often began work very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary, not just for rich people.'

**Photography**

When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal ideas, and cultural rules. In this book, we will see how these things change the style and meaning of a photo. We will also see how people look at and feel about these photos. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they might think they understand the photos. But we can ask if the photo shows the scene as it really was. Or does it show what the photographer thinks? Is the exact moment important, or is the photo a symbol of something in the world?

**More than a Game**

For me, sport is more than just playing. The best people in sport believe in themselves completely. You need to focus if you want to be the best. You have to give up other things. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. You have to try hard or you will fail. Sport has taught me to be disciplined and determined. It also shows how to work in a team. My sport lets you be great alone, but it is also a team game. It is like life - you can do well alone, but you must remember others. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has shown me new things and places. But you also have to give up a lot for these benefits.

**Tuning In**

Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, this happened one night in California many years ago. I was awake, listening to a bird singing in a tree. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's song was so beautiful that I stayed awake. The bird's music reminded me of jazz and Indian music. It felt like the bird was making up the music as it sang. I was amazed by the bird's song until I finally fell asleep.

Text: People have always had strong feelings about birds. But what do these feelings say about us? Paul Evans writes about this. There is a noise from the greenhouse. A small brown bird is hitting the glass. It is a wren. Some people think wrens bring messages or signs. Is it trying to tell me something? Or is it just a bird stuck in the greenhouse? Maybe both are true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people watched wrens to see if they would have good or bad luck. Today, we still see wrens in pictures and decorations in British homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, people still like wrens. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because there is a lot of folklore about birds. In the past, people needed to understand nature to survive. They created stories about animals. These stories can change over time. For example, the red kite was once common in London. People liked them because they cleaned the streets. But later, people thought they were pests, and they disappeared from most places except Wales. Now, red kites are protected and are a symbol of conservation. Our connection with birds is very old. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also seemed magical to them. When we think about why birds are important, we also think about what it means to be human. Birds can fly and sing, and we admire these things. Some people think our feelings about birds are old and not needed now. But like some parts of our body, these feelings are still with us. Birds show us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because it means losing part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing are in poems and stories. Losing them is losing a part of our history. But birds not in stories are often ignored. Folklore is important. Stories and legends about birds help us feel connected to them. These stories are more powerful than scientific words. They help us feel and understand birds in a special way. Watching birds, whether on TV or in our gardens, is exciting. Science cannot fully explain why we love birds. The wren in the greenhouse makes me think about the past and the future. It is a mystery that keeps me wondering.

Text: 'Maps The purpose of a map is to show how places and features on the earth relate to each other. This is done using distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like 'a day's walk' or 'a day's journey by river'. This told more about how easy it was to travel the land than the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were 'Where do I go from here?' and 'How far is it?'. Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like train maps, do not show true directions. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks, and these signs could be different sizes to show their importance. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and where they were made. To understand old maps, it is important to know the method used to make them. The history of map-making is about making maps more accurate and detailed. Map-making has used other sciences to help. For example, instead of using the sun or stars to find direction, people used the magnetic compass. New tools were made to measure angles accurately. As people learned more about the world, they tried to map it. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, but is slightly flat at the poles, which changed how large areas were mapped. Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Soldiers needed accurate maps for planning battles. Archaeologists, historians, and geographers also needed special maps. Today, map-makers create maps showing many things, like weather patterns and land use. The value of maps in many sciences has led to a new interest in map-making. The progress in map-making has not always been steady. Sometimes, old ideas stayed around even when new ones were better. Map-makers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since it is easy to copy old maps, some map publishers did not want to change. So, maps should not always be trusted as proof of what people knew at the time. The many maps we have today show a lot of human work and thought. They are a valuable record of human history. This makes studying old maps interesting and educational.'

**Simplified Text:**

I was invited into a young man's nice living room. It was a calm and tidy place in a messy house. The kitchen was like economy class, but his room was like business class. He had the biggest collection of records I had ever seen and the first stereo record player I had come across. He also had expensive wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had a scholarship to study history at Oxford University, but he had nine months free before starting. He wanted to become a famous composer like Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for women, money, and fame. The difference was that my dreams were not as serious to me. When Andrew suggested I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I agreed. Andrew played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very good. He played more music from shows he had written at school. I was impressed. He needed a new lyricist, and I had a song that was recorded by a pop group. We decided to meet again and write something together. I was more interested in pop music than theater, but I knew Andrew was talented. I thought it would be smart to work with him. Even if we didn't succeed in theater, we could try to compete with famous bands like the Beatles later. The next day, at my office job where I was training to be a lawyer, I wasn't as sure about a career in show business. I still looked for bands needing a singer and wrote simple songs. I thought I might end up as a lawyer by age 25. My father said I would stop liking pop music by age 21, which worried me. But I decided to see Andrew again. It would be fun to write musical lyrics with him. Andrew was interesting and liked good food and old buildings. He also supported a football team. I wasn't sure about his idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, who helped orphans. The story didn't excite me, and it seemed too much like another show, Oliver. But Andrew believed in his music, and it was catchy. I didn't know much about musicals, but I thought we could be successful. I started writing lyrics, especially for the funny songs. Andrew told me the story, played the tunes, and gave me some titles. I skipped a day at the office to write my first theater lyrics. I didn't know it then, but I had changed my career.

**Language**

Humans have a special ability: we can communicate with each other using language. Language is a big part of our lives, and it is hard to think about life without it. If you see two or more people together, they will probably start talking. Even when alone, people talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to say that language is like an 'instinct'. This means people know how to talk naturally, like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not learn web-making from school or from a smart spider; they just know how to do it.

**Climate and Weather**

Climate and weather are made by the air around us and have a big effect on where animals and plants live. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet places can have tropical jungles with many different species. Cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather patterns, which make up the climate over time, happen because big masses of air move and mix. The air moves because the earth spins, and the air does not move as fast as the earth. The sun is also important for making the air move.

**Coffee**

As a bar-person, I had to serve drinks and make coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I had to learn a lot about making coffee, especially using the espresso machine. I learned how to make a good cappuccino, which is a coffee with rich, frothy milk. By the end of the first week, I realized making good coffee was not easy, and I thought I might have to do simple tasks like cleaning ashtrays again. But my boss was patient. He said, 'Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it.'

**Art on TV**

Why does TV often fail with shows about art? Painting and sculpture should be easy for TV because the camera can show a whole artwork and then zoom in on details. But few TV series show the joy and complexity of art. A good example is Robert Hughes's series "American Visions." Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to show British viewers American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on great artworks. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are shown in art and buildings.

**Dealing in Metals**

For 20 years, I worked as a metals dealer and became known for taking risks. Metals are less controlled than other markets. With luck, risk-taking, and market knowledge, you can make a lot of money. Risk is a big part of the industry. This fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, free-trade economists see that the market is not keeping metal prices high. More minerals are being taken out, and raw material costs are going down. Adjusted for inflation, most metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a big company that benefits from cheap raw materials.

**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**

Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, stretching from Florida to Cuba. Each island is unique and has something special. To get around Abaco and its islands, you need a boat. If your room doesn't include one, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. You can also rent a boat if you want to go on your own. Sailing is very popular here. Abaco is called 'The Sailing Capital of the World' because of its calm, protected waters. These waters are great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

Text: 'Build Your Own Bamboo Bike in the UK

The Bamboo Bike Club in Hackney Wick, east London, offers a special course. Run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, the course lets you build your own bamboo bike. It's a fun weekend activity where you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer.

Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire use bamboo, a method first tried in 1894. But buying a bamboo bike can be expensive, costing around $2,995 or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes affordable for everyone. They spent years working in a shed in Wales to create a business that lets people build their own bikes.

The Bamboo Bike Club is more like a community than a company. James and Ian have other jobs; James works with wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. They offer monthly courses where you can build your own bike for a good price.

On the first day of the course, you learn how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You start by putting together the front triangle of the bike with bamboo tubes. Metal tubes are used for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. James and Ian help you with every step, making sure everything is done right.

Most people enjoy building their own bike. Even if you make a mistake, you can try again with a new piece of bamboo. On the second day, you wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, the bike is ready for wheels, brakes, and other parts.

Bamboo bikes are strong and can last a long time. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested one off-road for three months. The bikes may look a bit rough compared to professional ones, but they are unique. James and Ian say that's the point.

Bamboo bikes are great for a smooth and easy ride. They are light and fun to ride. The cost of building your own bamboo bike is less than £500.'

**Self-help Books**

Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York. She found a book by Dr. John Gray, a pop psychologist. She thought it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand communication between men and women. It is very popular in the self-help industry. This industry is growing and helps people who want to improve their lives. It also helps the publishing world in New York. In Britain, many self-help books are published, but many are not good. For every book published, many are rejected. Editors look for books that can sell well. They ask questions like, "Is the author easy to promote? Is the idea interesting to many people?" Dione Reverend says a good title is very important.

**Autobiographies**

When someone writes an autobiography, they make a promise to tell the truth. But often, they do not tell everything. There are many reasons for this. Some things are too embarrassing to share. Some things seem unimportant. Sometimes, writers think they can show the truth better by making up stories. Some writers never plan to tell the truth. They call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true. Readers might think they read a true story, but it is fiction. This is not always done to trick people.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Detective stories became popular in the late 1800s and early 1900s. They show the problems of society at that time. In these stories, a crime shows human desires like greed. Solving the crime helps society work well again. In Hammett's stories, society is still not perfect after the crime is solved. The detective and the criminal are similar. They understand each other. The detective is both a good person and a bit of a crook. He is not fully on the side of the law. Sometimes, he feels guilty about this. Other times, he is very eager to catch the criminal.

**Science Writing**

Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. He says that to write well about science, you must understand the culture of science. Only scientists can explain science well. If you do not know the rules of the science community, it is hard to write about it. Gould believes you should never talk down to readers. You can make the language simple, but not the ideas. If readers feel you are treating them like they are not smart, they will not like your writing.

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym in the City of London, the air feels very cold. The gym is a popular place for workers to go during lunch. This summer, the gym used a lot of air-conditioning because it was very hot outside. Sometimes, the gym feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how people often use too much air-conditioning. Air-conditioning is important in many places, but there are other ways to keep buildings cool. Buildings can use natural light and fresh air. They can also have thicker walls to keep out the heat during the day and release it at night. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. People are interested in sundials again as we start a new millennium. A hundred years ago, sundials were important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches got better, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are taking sundials seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks they are special because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. Sundials are calm and romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

I used to think china-painting was only for very skilled people. I once saw older women painting teacups with perfect flowers. They were very good, and their hands never shook. I wondered who would want to learn china-painting. Would beginners be as good? When I visited a china-painting class, I found it was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint quickly like the women I saw before.

**The Wrong Country**

Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency, the clerk said the other people on the trip were a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.

When they arrived, a woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on." Keith thought it was an overnight stop. It was late, and they were tired, so they didn't ask questions. But the next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist said they could enjoy the lake and take a boat to Interlaken.

Keith told the receptionist there was a mistake. They were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist said their group was booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. Dawne described the man who made the booking. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, came over. She explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels.

Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks said she would check and left. Keith thought about everything that happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane. An old man named Nottage talked to them, saying he and his wife slept well because of the lakeside air.

Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't say it, but they knew it was ironic. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they ended up with a group of elderly people, even though they wanted to get away from the needs of the elderly. Uncle had said so himself when they asked him to come with them.

Text: 'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are learning from the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton. Eluned Price reports. Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, he is becoming popular now. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton 'an Antarctic explorer whose achievements were mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century.' But now, Americans are very interested in him. Books about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being written, and they are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is having a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about Shackleton's life. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with admiration and learn lessons in leadership and communication from him. They even say they are 'speaking Shackleton.' Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, is now a model for modern management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has used Shackleton as a role model for years. His company helps with communication during business problems. For example, if a company's factory explodes or if many workers lose their jobs. Shackleton also worked in public relations for a Glasgow steel company. It might be hard to see how surviving in freezing temperatures relates to managing a business crisis. 'Even if a company handles its problems well, it can still cause harm by not communicating well,' says MacGregor. 'Shackleton is a model for management because he was a good leader and communicator. He had strong values. He was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of Shackleton's most important decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his credibility for the next expedition: the lives of his men were most important.' This refers to Shackleton's 1908 expedition to the South Pole. He turned back 97 miles from the goal because of delays and low supplies. In a crisis, says MacGregor, people want to know someone is in charge. Today, managers often avoid responsibility, but Shackleton was ready to take it. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was stuck in ice for nine months and then crushed. When it sank, Shackleton told his men, 'we will all be safe if you do your best and trust me.' From diaries and accounts, it is clear that Shackleton was always in charge. 'Shackleton planned for everything, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions,' says MacGregor. 'He was flexible and ready to start over if needed. We have created a set of principles that Shackleton shows. Clients can relate to his story without feeling criticized.' Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. 'One of the hardest things to do in difficult times is to do nothing, especially in America, where people want quick solutions,' says MacGregor. 'If you buy bonds and the interest rates are wrong, you wait, and eventually, you'll get your money back. To sell quickly would mean a big loss. Also, don't be afraid to change plans if they aren't working. If a new product is bad, stop selling it.' Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if Hurley didn't wear them. Someone else remembered him doing the same with a biscuit when they were starving in 1905: 'He said he'd leave it in the snow. Millions of pounds couldn't have bought that biscuit.' Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, says: 'People want to hear about heroic actions more and more. Shackleton shows that there is nothing heroic happening now. Everything else fades away, and he stands as the true example of the ideals we miss today.'

Text: 'Finding Food in Madagascar In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. It lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insect larvae inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its teeth to make holes and its long, thin third finger to reach the insects. Scientists have known about the aye-aye's way of eating for over a hundred years. But they have only recently learned how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the aye-aye's hunting skills. He worked with two male aye-ayes, Nosferatu and Poe, a female, Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle. Dr. Erickson wanted to know if the aye-ayes found insects by seeing signs on the wood. He gave them logs with holes. Some holes had mealworms, and some were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food, without needing to see signs. Dr. Erickson also tested if they used smell or sound to find the insects. The aye-ayes could find mealworms even when they couldn't smell or hear them. So, how did they find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their big ears. They might be using echo-location, like bats, to find empty spaces in the wood. They can also hear insects move when they tap. The idea that the aye-aye is like a woodpecker in Madagascar is interesting. But there are birds in Madagascar that also look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is not only like a woodpecker and a bat, but also like a squirrel. Its teeth grow all the time, like a squirrel's. It can also open nuts and eat the inside with its long finger.'

Text: 'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we know what their lives were like when they were young? Old diaries and family stories often don't tell us much. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos, but they are still just images. Hannah Renier has an idea: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if wanted, about ordinary people. The idea came when she talked to her family and saw how much of the past was disappearing. "When I started, I didn't take it so seriously," she says. "But now I see people enjoy talking about their lives. They do it for their children or the future, but they also enjoy it themselves." People feel safe to be honest with her. A 62-year-old man who lost and made a fortune said, "I was surprised at what I shared. Some things were painful, like my divorce." He did it for his family but hasn't let his children read it yet. "If they insist, I'll let them. But I'd rather they read it after I'm gone." He saw patterns from his childhood in his life. Ms. Renier noticed this in others too. "Many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "Things from childhood affect them all their lives. They marry people their parents liked or do the opposite to rebel." "Many people still feel disappointed about things with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed." Ms. Renier listens but doesn't judge. "It's not for the public, and I'm not nosy. People sometimes tell me things and then say, 'I'm not sure if that should go in.' I include it, but they can remove it later. People want to be honest." "It's not about showing off. Life is moving fast, and we forget the past. This gives us roots. We need a link to our ancestors because families don't stay together as much now. People want a little immortality." Each book takes up to 30 hours of interviews. Ms. Renier uses these to write the life story, organizing and interpreting it. Modern technology helps her make everything except the book cover. The book is for a private audience and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be cheaper," she says. "But the people I've worked with are often wealthy, like readers of Harpers & Queen, where I advertise. They are the kind of people who used to have portraits painted for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**

The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, nothing here is real. All sculptures are copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with good natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together here. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**

Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography with community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We have courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a Beginner's Course, a short Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. Our members can use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books, magazines, and materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**

The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection, from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare items in their original cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, added a lot to the collections, making the museum outstanding. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery has beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**

There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos across Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought and usually take about a month to make.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**

The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running centre of its kind in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction. You can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred brass plates from tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre has made resin copies, called facsimiles, to preserve the originals and make brass rubbing available to everyone. Brass plates were used as memorials and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Most original brasses were destroyed, but many are still in Britain, and the Cambridge Centre has a wide range of examples.

**From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had small children for 35 years because of my unusual personal life. I love being a father. I fed the baby this morning, and that is what being a father means to me. I am lucky because my children and I love the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This makes us close, especially now that they are older. I try to be available for them, but I don't call them often. I wait for them to call me. My parents used to make me feel guilty for not calling, and I don't want to do that to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was about 25 when my children were born. It was hard for me to handle the responsibilities, but it also kept me young. As they grew up, they showed me new music and fashion, which helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young because I was busy with work, but now I can take them on nice holidays. They like coming to parties and events with us. They think my job is exciting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born when I was starting my political career. My wife and I wanted to spend time with our children, but my job makes it hard. I try to take them with me to weekend meetings so they know what I do. This way, they don't feel like I am gone all the time. More politicians are bringing their kids to work now, which is good.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when my children, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I tried hard to stay close to them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while, but it was confusing for the kids. Kate says I was always there for her, but I think I treated them like adults too soon. I wish I had been more organized. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. Your kids are always your kids.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready to have children when I turned 30. My wife and I had a nice house, so we decided to have a child instead of buying more things. Having my daughter Betty made me think about who I am. Being a parent is special, but it also makes you like other parents. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but Betty's smile makes everything better. A baby's smile can make anyone happy.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This is a play by Marlowe about a powerful warrior. It is very exciting in Terry Hands' version. He made the play shorter and faster. Antony Sher is amazing as Tamburlaine, doing stunts and speaking with passion.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall is now in London. It starts with two couples talking in a garden, but then it becomes a deep story about illness. Michael Wall was a talented writer who died young.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish writer, tells a story about the fishing industry in Wexford. The play has strong characters and emotions, with some funny moments. It ends with a big, exciting scene.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who want to kill each other. The story has clever surprises.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

E. **The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes makes Jonson's comedy about tricksters very funny. It was first shown in Stratford and is now in London. The actors are great as the con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James brings this comedy about fashion and women in Edwardian times to London. The play is well-acted and stylish. It is a classic that people should see more.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a sweet version of Beauty and the Beast set in London. It has beautiful music and celebrates love. It is a great show.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's version of this Shakespeare comedy is not very good, but Ron Cook and Anton Lesser give great comic performances.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This play by Granville Barker is about a lawyer who leaves a bad financial situation to his son. It is a wonderful play and is now touring.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard
