Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game. They are watching a strange bookshop. Emma sees her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into doing bad things and tries to make her leave her friends. When Emma is in danger, the story becomes very exciting. She is trapped in a dark house. This book shows family life and friendship. It also warns that adults are not always good.

**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to learn about a train accident from 1915. Eight people died in the accident. They use maps and stories to find out what happened. This book is clever and needs careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer is a girl who loves her father's racing pigeons. Her father leaves to find work, and Mary takes care of the pigeons. She wins prizes even though her mother is upset. The story is set in 1930 and shows that there are different ways to be smart.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
Rose rents a cottage with her two children to escape her old life. A scary cat and strange things in the house show why the last owner left. The local people do not like Rose and her family. By the end, the danger is gone, but Rose is worried about her son. The story is very exciting.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam is from a noisy family. He admires his cousin Lisa, who seems rich. When Lisa's life changes, Sam helps her. They both learn about family and reality. The story is a bit slow but has gentle humor. It is good for both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Robbie works in Stanley's garden. At first, she likes him, but then she finds him strange. She discovers what he keeps in his aquarium, and the story becomes a thriller. The book is set in New Zealand and is very interesting.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
Mick has problems at home and school. The story is told through flashbacks, letters, and notes. Mick learns to feel better about himself by acting in a school play. A kind teacher helps him. The story is sad but very good.

**Science and Weightlessness**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. The aircraft looked normal from the outside. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135, built in 1964. But inside, it was different. It was a long white tunnel with lights on the walls. Most seats were removed, except a few at the back. The 13 students from Europe and America sat there, looking nervous.

For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight. The European Space Agency asked for creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight. The flight was like a roller-coaster. For two hours, the plane flew up and down. At the top of each curve, the pilot cut the engines. The plane went higher by itself before falling back to Earth. In those few seconds, everything inside became weightless. The students felt like they were closer to the moon than Earth.

The plane took off smoothly. But soon, the pilot made the plane climb at a 45-degree angle for 20 seconds. The engines were loud, and blood drained from our heads. Then the engines stopped, and we felt weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated. The floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us to the ceiling. We floated without direction. After ten seconds, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned, and some students landed hard. There were 30 curves in total, giving ten minutes for experiments.

The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats land on their feet. They used a device to turn it belly-down. A German team studied how metal joins in space. A team from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films. They believe these sails could use the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours, we felt a bit sick, but mostly excited. One student said, "It was unforgettable. I wanted to be an astronaut, and now I want it even more."

Text: 'With the trees, I planted my stake in New Zealand JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER Jonathon Porritt is the author of Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology'. I had a strange time in my life when I didn't have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer here, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I like winter, so it was great. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, 'If you plant trees on it, you can have it.' This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice because my father grew up there. They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was okay for planting trees. I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and other farm jobs, so planting trees sounded nice, and I was excited. The rest of the family got excited too. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted all 70 acres. In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot, almost every day we were planting. I was never wetter or colder for so long, but it was a happy time. Every morning, I got ready for planting. I came out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but it was raining, and my clothes were still wet from the day before. My boots were wet, and my hands were cold. In the first year, I had a man to help me who knew how to plant trees, which was helpful because I had never done it seriously before. You have a bag around your neck full of trees, and when it's full, it's hard, but it gets easier as it gets lighter. The hardest part was making the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then line up three poles to guide you. Once in line, you plant all the way down, turn around, and come back. I like hard work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm, using the fewest spade strokes to dig the hole. The rhythm is important, and many farm jobs are like this. You train your body to do the same moves, and it becomes easy: take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in, stamp it down, and move on. Mentally, it's interesting. Your mind starts to think about different things. Many of my thoughts about nature and our place in it started then. I've been back to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is satisfying. I worry when I read about bad weather in New Zealand because I care about the trees. But it worked out well, and the trees are now 20 years old and healthy. I took time off from teaching and went back in 1984 for three months alone. I wrote my first book, Seeing Green, there. There's a small cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. I still feel a strong connection to that place. It's where I feel most connected to the earth.'

**Bringing Up Badgers**

"What now?" I thought when a helper handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset, where we care for orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange, so I looked inside. I saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft, and their eyes were milky-colored. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die of hunger. These cubs were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. The mother was dead, and the cubs were still with her. They were healthy but cold and crying. I cleaned them and put them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. I fed them with a syringe and wiped them with a warm cloth to help them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they ate every four hours. Soon, they drank from a bottle and moved around a bit. They seemed happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute 'mum'.

Three weeks later, Willow seemed tired but still ate normally. I didn't realize it was a warning sign. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, or liquid can go into the lungs. This happened to Willow, and he got an infection. I was sad but continued caring for the others. Six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, also named Willow. He was found cold and hungry. Willow II was hard to feed. I had to move the bottle around in his mouth to get him to drink. By the end of April, the females ate creamed rice and other foods. Willow II was different. He struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, he ate a sausage, and after a week, he was ready for other foods.

At nearly five months old, they ate cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were lucky because the summer was hot, and finding earthworms was hard. By August, the cubs became more active at night. We often walked through the orchard, and they played and chased each other. Derek joined us sometimes but didn't learn to avoid their playful bites.

During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were looking for food because of the dry weather. Badgers are territorial and can be aggressive. We were warned they might harm our cubs, so we made the pen secure. The local press took pictures of me with the badgers, and we started a project to build a home for them. With help, we designed a new home with tunnels and a gate. It had three rooms, one with a glass side for viewing. As we built it, the badgers explored it. They soon forgot about walks and enjoyed their new home. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company and other businesses helped. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they moved in. Later, I checked on them and saw them sleeping peacefully.

Now, I don't walk with them as often because they are active late at night. We see Primrose sometimes, as she joined another group, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before going off into the night. This is their home now, a place they know well and have accepted.

Text: 'Looking for true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass changes. Anjana Ahuja reports. Astronomer Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But one of his important achievements was to study compass 'variations' during his sea trips on the ship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors could not correct their compasses and find their way across the oceans. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the Atlantic Ocean. The trip stopped early because of problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these trips, Halley published a map in 1701 showing compass variations in the oceans. This map was very useful to sailors for over a hundred years until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate. Dr. Clark, who also loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. 'Halley had an amazing life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer but also did research in geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.' Dr. Clark believes that recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve making the same measurements Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the current model of Earth's magnetic field. 'It is common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. That's because you need to know true north to measure the direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements around the world. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in the satellite's data over the Atlantic Ocean. Halley's Atlantic journey was very important. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian made a naval captain to study declination. Does Dr. Clark have the skills to make his journey a success? He spent two years in Antarctica and works in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with four different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I am ready to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some people might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his amazing life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

Text: 'PEACOCKS AND THEIR TAILS Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show their beautiful tails to the female peacocks, called hens. This display puzzled Charles Darwin, who wondered why peacocks have such big tails in a world where animals need to be strong and fast to survive. Darwin thought animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the strongest and smartest survive. But the peacock's tail seemed to be a problem, not a help. So, Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection'. He thought females liked beauty, so they chose males with beautiful tails. Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He believed that if hens chose males with big tails, those males must have other good qualities. Wallace thought the tail was a sign of something important for survival. Today, scientists like Marion Petrie study peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if hens really choose males with the best tails and if those males have other good qualities. Observations show that hens prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails. But it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways. Some scientists think showy males might be healthier and have fewer parasites. Marion Petrie is studying if the children of attractive males grow faster and are healthier. This could mean hens choose mates for practical reasons, as Wallace thought. Another idea, called 'Fisher's Runaway', suggests that if females start choosing males with slightly better tails, over time, tails will get longer because both sons and daughters inherit these traits. This could support Darwin's idea that females choose beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London has many new yachts with the latest technology. Most of these boats are from a design change that happened 25 years ago. My boat, however, is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. People might think I am a romantic dreamer, but I am not sure about that. My boat uses old boat design ideas, but modern technology helped make it better. 

Modern technology is important in boat design and building, but it can make sailing too easy. Some people go to sea to experience the challenges of sailing. I think it's important for boats to have some comforts, like a stove for warmth and good places to sleep. But if everything on the boat is automatic, it takes away from the experience. For example, setting and taking down sails should be part of sailing. 

Some boats have steering positions in the middle, which makes more room inside, but I think a boat should feel like a boat, not a house. My old boat, Hirta, had comforts but no luxury. It had heavy sails, no electric water pump, no fridge, and no electronics, but it was the best boat I ever sailed. 

Old boats need a lot of care. After I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one. The Westerman was designed by Nigel Irens and Ed Burnett. They started with a drawing on a napkin, then used a computer to finish the design. The boat was made like old boats, with a model first. The final design was perfect. 

The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won races. It looks timeless and is comfortable at sea. The inside is made from old wood and feels peaceful. The boat was designed for sailing, not for furniture. It shows that you don't need to follow new trends to be happy. The boat is made from wood treated with glue, so it doesn't let water in. It has the benefits of a modern boat but looks and feels like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff are friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles or walk in the garden. I left feeling happy and full of energy. I want to visit again. This is a great break for a busy working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

This calm and relaxing place felt peaceful as soon as I arrived. The Hall has a beautiful library and conservatory. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up. They check your weight and blood pressure. I was called a patient, which was strange because I am healthy. But they found a shoulder problem and helped me with it. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and got a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit with yogurt. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are not too expensive. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm. It is a nice old manor with warm fires and a big lounge. If you want to lose weight, you might skip the rich food. The French chef makes delicious dishes. The hotel has a gym and pool to help burn calories. There is also a spa bath, steam room, and sauna. They have a sports injury clinic. I got advice for my shoulder injury. Careys is comfortable and relaxing. You can also explore the countryside. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a pool, tennis, and horse riding. There are beautiful walks and gardens. Waldo's restaurant has amazing food. The menu is long, and the food is delicious. I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options if you want them. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is delicious but has 360 calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I chose relaxing oils and had a very good sleep. The place is modern and well-run, with many treatments available. Guests include football teams, families, and friends. I would like to visit once a month. - Eve Cameron

**Natural Talents**

Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means that the things that make us different from animals are new in our history. Our ability to make art and do other human things comes from a small part of our genes. 

Animals and humans share many skills. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These examples show that the differences between us and animals are not big.

The first human art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we can't find these because they don't last. The first clear human art we know of is from the Cro-Magnons, about 35,000 years ago. They made cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

People say human art is different because it is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive. Let's look at these ideas:

1. **Not Useful**: Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." Human art doesn't help us survive or have children. Birdsong, for example, helps birds find mates and protect their area, which helps them pass on their genes. By this idea, human art is different.

2. **Made for Beauty**: Humans make art for pleasure. We can't ask birds if they sing for beauty, but they mostly sing during mating season, so it might not be for pleasure. This makes human art seem unique.

3. **Learned, Not Instinctive**: Human art styles are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, are born knowing their songs. If a French baby grew up in Japan, it wouldn't sing French songs naturally. Human art changes quickly, unlike animal sounds that stay the same for thousands of years.

In the 1950s, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy made paintings. Their art was shown in a London gallery, and many paintings were sold. These paintings were not made for a specific purpose, just like human art. Some people might say human art is different because it communicates, but even some famous human art was made for personal satisfaction.

**A Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story.

There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories often had brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance on their journeys. Today, you don't find such people in stories or real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's big adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. The name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home.

The team had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for the team.

This group started to cross 1,200 kilometers of the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a book about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He started the expedition for fun and to learn more about himself. 'I always thought I would stay in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I wanted to see who I really was outside the Army. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was worried because nobody had done that route before. We went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was kind to us.'

Anyone reading his story might wonder why he said the desert was 'kind'. The team faced many problems: illness, very hot and cold temperatures, thirst, and losing some of their water. 'But', Blackmore says, 'when we were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some. We didn't have the desert's famous sandstorms. And we didn't face the very cold weather that could have stopped us. But we had many challenges. The sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels, which sometimes fell on us.'

'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. We didn't have the money or time for one. No planes flew over us. Once we were in the sandhills, we were alone. I knew I was mentally strong, but I was scared about my physical strength. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" I was very scared.'

If it was like that at the start, how did they feel at the end? 'When you've walked 1,000 kilometers, you don't give up. You've gone through so much. We were very thin but strong. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything.'

In the middle of the book, Blackmore talks about lying in the desert, looking at the moon, and thinking of his family. How did he feel about what his family went through? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace. When I doubt myself now, I think of the desert and how we did it. I am prouder of that expedition than anything else. But when I think of my life, I think of my family and our happiness. Compared to that, the desert is not as important.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I miss the challenge and the open spaces. We had a strong sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Text: Susan Harr was feeling stressed, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier. But Susan started to think that maybe we rely too much on technology. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her wonder if gadgets are worth the trouble and cost.

Susan began to let her household gadgets stop working as they got old. She questioned what "extra time" technology really gives us. Is it just time to buy more gadgets? She thinks maybe we are being tricked by marketing experts. When her sewing machine started making strange noises, she decided to stop using it. Now, she sews by hand and enjoys it. She can take her sewing anywhere and doesn't have to worry about noisy machines.

There are some gadgets Susan still likes, like the washing machine. But she found joy in getting rid of others, like the color TV. Now, her family spends more time walking the dog, reading, and talking. Susan also enjoys sewing by hand. She listens to the radio or talks with family while sewing. It makes her feel relaxed and happy.

Susan realized that doing things by hand is not as hard as she thought. It is calming and satisfying to see her work improve. She doesn't feel rushed anymore and enjoys simple tasks like washing dishes. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if they really need things like the freezer or microwave. She thinks they could save money by using fewer gadgets.

Text: 'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from making beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems like a man in a hurry. I arrive at his workshop, which is under a railway arch in East London. He greets me with a quick handshake and says, 'Well, fire away then!' It is not clear if he is really in a hurry or just shy. But his workshop shows he is busy. There are many half-made pieces of furniture and planks of wood in different natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and has a good reputation. His order book is always full for months, even though he does not advertise. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the person to go to. Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes beautiful furniture with simple lines is not easy. 'There are few real cabinet-makers now. People call themselves furniture-makers,' Hurst says. He is disappointed by some modern furniture. 'I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people will accept.' He does not like bad, mass-produced furniture. Hurst wants perfection, and this is a key to his success. He is also talented. He is confident about his ability. 'I have a huge natural ability,' he says. 'I have always been good at making things.' Hurst is self-taught. How did he learn? 'I asked the right questions and picked it all up,' he says. Most of his work comes from private people. Some clients come back many times. 'You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying.' But he admits that working with clients is not always easy. 'The most annoying clients are those who don't know what they want, and then decide they do when it's too late ... my favorite clients are the exacting ones.' Hurst is happy with his work but also praises others. 'There are people far better than me. I can admire other people. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham' (a top furniture design school). He is critical of craftsmen who 'are trying to be artists and take a year to make one piece.' He also does not like degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. 'A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something that people really can use.' Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he says, 'After all, I am only making furniture.''

Text: 'Three ideas about why we sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This means sleep is very important. But, we are not sure why sleep is so important. Scientists have three main ideas. The first idea is that sleep helps our body stay healthy. When we sleep, our body fixes any problems from the day and makes us ready for the next day. The second idea is that sleep helps us learn. It says that sleep helps us remember what we learn during the day. Without sleep, we might not learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to get more energy for the next day.'

**Eccentrics**

An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of their society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own little habits. Some people love entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. Inside us, there is a fight between wanting to be different and wanting to fit in. It is like having two trains pushing against each other. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. Most people want to fit in, be liked, and feel part of a group. This is stronger than wanting to be different.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find others like them. They form clubs and have meetings to talk about their interests. They want to share what others might think is strange. Being in a group, even a small one, feels good. We all feel a pull between being ourselves and fitting in. We might say we are different, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new person says, "You must take me as you find me."

Anyone can choose to be more individual. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel in your gut what you are doing and then dynamically pursue it - don't back down and don't give up - then you're going to mystify a lot of folk." But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. If a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a hostess says shocking things to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. If they keep doing these things until they cannot act 'normal' anymore, then they might be eccentric.

The key to being eccentric is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care about what others think. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from people who are very aware of the world, like enthusiasts, practical jokers, or exhibitionists. These people react to the world around them. Some want to impress society, and some want to escape it, but they all think about society. Eccentrics just live their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**

We asked four nature experts to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most.

**A Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. None are more important than Barbara Ward, a small, frail woman who was at the center of environmental issues in post-war Europe. She turned her experiences into a strong philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man" is, to me, her most important book. It talks about the fast growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a strong call for what we now call 'sustainable human development'. I have read many books since, but none are as good.

**B Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of the colony. This book explains animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to an organized social structure. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to explain his findings to everyone. He worked with Eric Ennion, a talented wildlife artist, to create this book. Ennion's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful. This is the work of a true field naturalist.

**C Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced my life the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book defined my love for the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was discouraged by setbacks, but reading this book made the world brighter. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty together. Many say humans are the worst because of the harm we do, but I think of Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family. This is a concept we all need to understand.

**D Bruce Pearson**

I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library after it was published in 1966. I was drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and learned to identify birds during holidays. They encouraged me to sketch birds to help identify them. "The Shell Bird Book" had more to offer. It had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as valid as a scientific one. As art was my strong subject, I saw a new path opening for me.

Title: Do Reviews Help Sell Books?

We asked five big British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. Many people buy books because of reviews more than ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both feel bad if there are no reviews. But publishers think any review, good or bad, can help sell books. They like reviews that agree with their own thoughts about the book.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks still don't get enough attention. Reviews help make books and authors known. A good review by a trusted person can increase sales.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for us. We publish books by authors who are not famous, so we need reviews to help sell them. Good reviews are better than ads because they are honest. Reviews can help a book become popular, but they need help from other things like word of mouth and good marketing.

**Publisher D**  
In the US, a review in the New York Times can make a book popular. In Britain, it is not so clear. Sometimes, books with bad reviews sell well, and good books take a long time to become popular. Non-fiction reviews often talk more about the subject than the book.

**Publisher E**  
Publishers and writers want long, good reviews. But do they sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they knew the book from the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more. Now, a surprising reviewer or a fun review can make people want to buy the book.

Text: 'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in early Egyptian times. Today, Graham Smith keeps this craft alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham's designs are special and made to fit what his customers want. 'This way, I can make a unique item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's work or hobbies.' This is different from the usual cockerel design, which is the most common weathervane. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I saw that I could make many different designs,' he says. Graham decided to start a weathervane business. He had worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is fun and creative,' he says. 'I really like designing.' Graham has made over 100 original designs. He works with great detail and always asks the customer to approve the design before cutting it by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They like to have something a little different.' Graham does not want to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost real,' he says. 'For many years, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction changes,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want a special touch for their homes. This helps crafts like mine.' Graham is very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. American and Danish buyers are especially interested. 'The price,' he says, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can make a special gift.'

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was published, *The Horse Whisperer* was already a very popular book. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about his inspiration and success.

At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He was a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. A film project he was working on, called *Life and Limb*, suddenly failed. He was worried because he had not earned money for two years, and the film was his only hope to pay the bank.

Instead of finding a job, Evans made a surprising decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel. The idea for the story came from a farrier he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a horse that became wild, but a gypsy calmed it by talking to it. These men were called 'horse whisperers'. Evans was interested and started to learn more about them.

He decided to write a book instead of a screenplay. So, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses. He felt alone and worried about his future. By August, he had written half of the book and showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was "fine" and said Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts and support his family.

In October, the first part of the book and a summary were sent to seven UK publishers. Soon, his agent called to say they had turned down an offer of $75,000. The book was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Hollywood studios also wanted to make a movie from it.

Evans decided not to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. He wanted to stay involved but not be too close to the project. The success of his novel also brought new interest in his film *Life and Limb*, but he was not sure if he wanted to make it anymore. He thought it would be smart to write another novel.

Text: 'Young Chess Players Bobby Fischer is trying to prove himself again in the world of chess. Chess is now a game for young people. After 20 years away, Bobby Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, but he is not the same as in 1972. He is 49 years old and not in practice. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in 20 years. Fischer made chess popular, and now it is more professional. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, players need strong nerves and stamina, as well as intelligence. The game is very intense: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose. Games are longer now, and many are played without breaks. This makes it better for younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the top ten players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Players must prepare well before matches, especially because computers have changed chess a lot. A small computer can hold one million chess games and help players study their opponents. In one match, players used teams to find weaknesses in each other's games. The start of a chess game is now studied very carefully. Being well-prepared can decide the game. Today, there are more top players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prize money around the world. Success needs both physical and mental effort. A game can last up to eight hours. Players must stay focused, as a mistake can be very bad. The chess clock adds pressure. The end of a game can be a fast 'time scramble', where players have only seconds to make moves. This is not for thinkers; it is a battle of nerves and will to win. Losing is very painful at the top level. Winning brings happiness and a chance to rest. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess competitions last 9-11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even harder. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow stopped because both players were too tired. Karpov lost about 10kg in weight. Can Fischer succeed? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This made his leaving chess in 1972 surprising. But it made him a legend. If he returned for money, he will earn a lot. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Fischer wants to prove he is still the best, losing could be very sad for him.'

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.

**A. Nick Grosso**

Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's a low-budget film, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know it's difficult. I knew nothing back then." Nick left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational place. It was very exciting."

**B. Simon Pegg**

Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. Even at university, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor. I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has worked with the comedy group Funny Business, but his work with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "Steve saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.

**C. Ciaran McMenamin**

Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was very successful, and his career has grown quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to be successful. Encouraged by his mother, he went from school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for more success, but he knows fame is not the most important thing. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize it's not about that. It's about getting respect for doing good work."

**D. Neil Taylor**

Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I don't know. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to succeed in music ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I was very depressed, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E. Stephen Richards**

Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been touring and giving readings for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't do as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but later became unhappy with education. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with a job at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry being so successful, moving to novels is brave. "There's a structure with my poetry, so there's less chance to make mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad words. My main goal is not to just produce work without caring about the quality."

Text: A. Isabel is an art student who is 31 years old. She likes historical romance stories and is looking for Mr. Right. Isabel thinks she looks good in jeans but doesn't wear them often because she doesn't want to meet the wrong people. She worries about her knees but stays hopeful. The story is fun and exciting, like an old silent movie. B. This story is about a local radio station in America. A smart child named Francis With works for WLT Radio, which was started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays music, talks, and shows. The story is funny and takes us back to the 1940s and 1950s, with old cars and radios. C. In this story, a professor named Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poet. He talks to his wife's first husband about it. The poet writes bad poems and wants Richard to help her brother, who is in jail. The story is funny and smart, and the author makes the complicated story easy to follow. D. Two women and two men become best friends in London during the 1960s. One of them, James Hudson, starts a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. They both loved a woman who died years ago. The story is about murder, ambition, love, and jealousy. It's a long book where you can really get to know the characters. E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three children. Ian is 40 years old and lives alone. The story shows his special relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It's a warm and funny book.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four writers talk about international volunteer work.

**A.** Volunteer tourists often help build homes or schools. They pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money directly to the local community, it could pay for more work than one volunteer can do. This is especially true for gap year students who do not need special skills. Many studies question if gap year volunteering is really about helping others or if it is more about helping the volunteers' careers. However, these projects can help volunteers learn to act kindly towards others in their future lives.

**B.** Volunteering can help people from different countries understand each other better. It can help solve conflicts and encourage people to take part in global issues. It can also create international friendships. This can be good for both volunteers and the communities they visit. But if only rich people from wealthy countries volunteer, it might help them more than the communities they visit. These volunteers might use the experience to improve their own careers.

**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as a way for rich people to feel good about themselves. It can also be a way to help with international development. At its best, volunteering helps both the volunteers and the communities. It allows people to share skills and learn from each other. Volunteering can also make people aware of problems like poverty and injustice, and encourage them to help solve these issues.

**D.** Volunteer tourism is popular because people want to help others. It seems positive because it avoids big government and business. But it also avoids the need for government to help and makes development about individual acts of charity. Some people think volunteer tourism is just simple charity. But when it is called sustainable development, it can be misleading. It can ignore the real reasons for poverty and inequality in the world.

**Sound the Alarm**

**Stuart Harris reports**

Many people listen to the radio in the morning and need an alarm to wake up. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios.

The first model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for weekdays and one for weekends. It also has a cassette player, which is nice because you can listen to your own tapes. The radio quality is good, but it's big, like a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't work.

The second model was the best-looking and the overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. The digital display is nice, and the snooze bar is easy to use. It has a self-power back-up, so you don't have to reset it if the power goes out. However, it was hard to set up.

The third model has an extra lamp, but Tom Granger thought it was poorly made. The light is hard to use, and the radio is difficult to tune. The buzzer is loud, like a submarine alarm. Despite this, it's the third most popular model.

The fourth model is colorful and aimed at young people. Tom Granger liked it because it stands out. It was easy to set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can be 10 minutes early or late, which Paul Bridges found annoying.

The last model is the simplest and cheapest. Tom Granger liked it because it is small and easy to set up. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found more reliable. The radio quality is fine, and the buzzer works well, waking me up in just two beeps!

Text: 'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but not in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are in danger. This helps protect them because their spines point outwards. The number of spines a hedgehog has can make this protection better. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they need to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and roll into a ball only if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, usually under bushes or in a hole in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.'

**Great Sports Women on a Winning Streak**

Being good at sports is hard, especially for women. They have to work very hard and give up a lot of their normal life. But many women are doing great things in sports. Here are some stories of British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

Jill loves skiing. She says it feels great to fly through the air, but it can be scary. Sometimes the weather is bad, but she keeps going. Skiing takes a lot of time, so she doesn't have much time for friends. There are six men and three women in her team, and they all compete together.

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

Caroline started cycling two years ago and won her first race. She is now a professional cyclist and trains a lot every day. She worries people might think she is successful because of her looks, not her skills. Her boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands her busy schedule.

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

Annabel says rowing is hard for girls because not many schools offer it. Most girls start rowing when they are older, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches change often, so the team is not very organized. But she enjoys being fit and the social life.

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

Ffyona dreamed of walking around the world when she was 13. She walked across Australia, which was very painful. She walked 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. She needed to finish in 95 days because of her sponsorship. People think sponsoring women is risky.

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

Lisa says some men have big egos when driving. They don't like it when she does well. Racing is hard, and she doesn't earn much money. Women have been racing for a long time, but they were seen as unusual. More women are racing now, and Lisa loves trying to be perfect.

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

Alison wakes up early to swim and trains in the evening. She sometimes falls asleep at work. She likes staying fit and enjoys the social side of racing. Men and women often compete together, but the media focuses more on men. The prize money is also less for women, but they are working to change this.

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers meeting the famous artist Picasso when he was 18 years old. Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He had run out of money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while eating at a restaurant, he saw Picasso sitting with his wife and friends. Richard was surprised because Picasso was known to be a private person.

Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard approached Picasso and offered his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed his name and drew a little picture on the page. Richard was very happy and started a conversation with Picasso, even though they needed help from an American woman to translate.

After showing his friend the autograph, Richard's friend suggested he draw Picasso's portrait. Richard returned to Picasso's table and started drawing him. Picasso made funny faces to make it difficult for Richard, but eventually, he sat still. Richard noticed how young and strong Picasso looked, even though he was almost 84 years old.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the drawing. Richard was shy but showed it to him. Picasso then took the crayon and quickly drew a funny picture of Richard. Richard asked Picasso to sign it, but Picasso said he had already given his signature.

Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It was a special moment that meant a lot to him.

**Shopping Tricks**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use many tricks to make you spend more money.

**A. Fresh Look**

Supermarkets know people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance. They might also have a bakery that smells like fresh bread. The store might use green colors because it reminds people of fresh food. Most of what they sell, like frozen foods, is not fresh.

**B. Smart Display**

Where products are placed in a store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to know which areas people shop in the most. They put expensive or fast-selling items there. Shelves at eye level are popular because people see them first. Special offers in big bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also put items that go together, like salad dressings near salads.

**C. Staples Spread Out**

Supermarkets put basic items like bread and tea far from the entrance. This way, you pass by other tempting products. Stores put popular items far from the entrance too, so you see other things while looking for them.

**D. Less is More**

Some stores, like Next, show fewer items to make them look special. They want you to think their clothes are unique, even if they are not. This is because of good store design.

**E. Total Temptation**

People care more about the total bill than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They might sell some items at a loss to attract you. They buy in large amounts to get discounts.

**F. Price Tricks**

In chain stores, people notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 makes a difference. It also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting Magic**

Stores use special lighting. Chain stores want natural light so clothes look the same outside. Supermarkets use lighting to make fruits and vegetables look better.

**H. Walking Paths**

Stores use different carpets to guide you. One type is for walking paths, and another is for sales areas. Some stores use wood or marble for paths to make you walk on the carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Ads**

When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use video screens on shopping carts. These screens show ads for products as you shop. They are for people who buy on impulse and can increase sales by 30%.

Text: 'Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also made new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and written books like Quest for Adventure and Everest the Hard Way. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also broke the transatlantic record, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about it in their book: Sea, Ice and Rock. In 1979, Chris was working on Quest for Adventure, a book about adventure after the war. He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to sail. Chris could teach Robin climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat, and Chris and Robin went to the shore to climb. The climb was hard, but Robin was calm and steady. Chris showed Robin how to climb, and Robin used his own way to go down safely. During this trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they use their skills together on a trip to Greenland. Robin was a good leader. He asked everyone for their opinion before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring and difficult. He liked being on land more. Robin enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris felt a bit useless sometimes. The yacht was small, with six people on it, but it was made for four. In Greenland, Chris led the climbing. He was worried about Robin's safety. Climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, was hard. Robin was not a natural climber, but he did well. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours but had to turn back. Robin trusted Chris and followed him. Robin was also worried about the boat, but he wanted to try climbing again. On the way home, there was a small problem. Chris was supposed to be on watch at 4 am, but Robin did not wake him. Chris thought Robin did not trust him, but Robin explained it was not true. By the end of the Greenland trip, Chris learned that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.'

**A Simple History of the Apple**

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples for a very long time. In ancient times, people in Britain and around Swiss and Italian lakes ate wild apples. These apples were small and not like the ones we eat today. In Switzerland, people even saved apple halves for winter.

**Apples in Britain (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. The Normans, who came to Britain later, had better apple varieties for the British weather. British monks worked on creating new types of apples, and many of today's apples come from these.

**Popular Apples (1200)**  
In the 1200s, some apples became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a dessert apple, and the Costard was used for cooking. But then, problems like droughts and wars reduced apple production. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn more about apples. Harris brought back new apple types, including the famous Pippins.

**Apples Around the World (1750)**  
By the 1600s, apples were so loved in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. In America, Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees.

**New Apple Varieties (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree. The apple was called 'Delicious' and became very popular. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith found a new green apple tree. This apple became known as the Granny Smith apple.

**Modern Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from just a few types, chosen for their looks and ability to travel well, not for taste. Many old apple types have been lost, especially in the US. People now want more variety in apples. It's important to protect different kinds of apples for the future.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide offers exciting travel for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unusual places with interesting plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures like tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups are small, with about 16 people. This helps you learn more about the places we visit and meet local people. It’s a great experience for all travelers.

**Different Ways to Travel**

We use many types of transport, often on the same trip. We travel by bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, and sometimes on foot. Each trip matches the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people who like new experiences. They come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for people who are healthy, fit, and adaptable. Most are aged 25-55. About half are couples, and the rest travel alone.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique. We have 8 categories of adventures, each with special activities. Many things make our trips successful, like unique places, meeting new people, and learning about different cultures.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural focus. Some trips focus on local cultures and famous sites. We have trips in places like Egypt, India, China, and Peru. Short walks to unusual sites are often part of our trips.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our safaris visit famous game parks and let you see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can walk in the wild, track gorillas, or ride a canoe. We camp or stay in hotels and lodges.

**Ethnic Encounters**

Our trips offer chances to meet ethnic or tribal people, like the Maya in Mexico or the Huli in Papua New Guinea. We travel in small groups to help spread understanding between different cultures.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walks through the countryside. You stay in hotels or village huts. Your main luggage is transported, and you carry a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer some major treks for strong walkers. These involve walking in high mountains like the Himalayas and Andes. We stay with local people or camp.

**Wilderness Experience**

Explore remote wilderness areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These places offer a unique adventure.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays use local boats. We sail in places like Egypt, Turkey, and the Galapagos Islands.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River trips can last a few hours to several days. You can paddle yourself or enjoy whitewater rafting. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught. Our river trips offer a special view of the jungle and river life.

Text: 'Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best 10,000-metre runners in Britain. Richard visits a training camp in Kenya. The camp is in a place called Nanyuki, which is ten miles south of the equator. It is a quiet and beautiful place near Mount Kenya. Richard has been coming here for three years to train in the winter. But he never trained with Kenyan runners before. On his fourth trip, he decided to change this. He ran his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This is where the best Kenyan runners train for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. Richard was invited by the Kenyan coach because he finished fifth in a big race. Training at high altitude helps runners because it makes more red blood cells. This helps them carry more oxygen. Kenyan runners have been very successful because of this. Richard's first race in Africa was in Nairobi. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa. Many Kenyan runners finished before him, but he still felt he did well. Richard thinks Kenyan success is not just because of altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple way of running and living. They enjoy competing. Richard learned how they train when he stayed at the camp. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. It is a simple place with few comforts. The athletes live with the college students. They sleep six to a room. They train three times a day: an easy run in the morning, interval training in the mid-morning, and a steady run in the afternoon. They run about 40 kilometres each day, except on Sunday when they run 20 kilometres. Life at the camp is simple. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are ugali, stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they wash in streams from Mount Kenya. Richard learned that Kenyan success is not just about genetics or altitude. It is also about their simple lifestyle, hard training, and love for running. These might be the real reasons for their success in distance running.'

Text: 'Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing

Advertising is having problems. It's not just because of the recession. Advertising started to drop in 1989, before the recession got worse. The problem is bigger and affects the whole world. Advertising has not kept up with economic changes. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now markets are smaller. Even big brands should focus on smaller groups, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Think about your shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For things like cars, you might buy one every three years. You don't buy many clothes either, and most are not advertised brands. Even with other things like candy, medicine, and services, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

There are 32,500 branded goods and services advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising. Mr. and Mrs. Average buy 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all because of advertising. That's about 4 percent. So, you could say 96 percent of advertising is wasted, but nobody knows which 96 percent.

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about one in 16 (6 percent). The other 15 commercials (94 percent) seem wasted. You might think you don't pay attention to advertising, but most people think the same. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised.

Waste is part of advertising. Not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest. But advertising can still be cost-effective. It reaches many people to find the few who will buy. Media advertising works because it is a cheap way to reach many people.

With smart targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond. But they can never know exactly who will respond. Even the best direct mail never gets a 100 percent response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesman might succeed with every client. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media.

Any advertiser who gets one million new customers (2 percent of adults) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million extra customers. Any advertising campaign that wins over 2 percent of the population is very successful. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message more carefully.'

Text: 'Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has two surprises. The first is Southwell Minster, an old cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. The second is Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', built by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into garden compost, and heat their house with waste heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with their three children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and is 300 yards from the Minster. It matches the town's old buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area. The house is very quiet because it is super-insulated with special windows. Inside, you must take off your shoes. It is a sunny day, and the conservatory warms the air for the house. Robert opens windows to create airflow because the house is very draught-proof. Even the cats have their own special door. The Vales, who teach architecture, cared about the environment before it was popular. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house with no carbon dioxide emissions and no mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to protect drinking water. Water from washing goes into the garden. They don't use a dishwasher to avoid strong detergents. 'We wanted to show that you can have an eco-friendly house without living in the dark,' says Robert. The house's only old-fashioned part is the hall, which is tall. The Vales pay no water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. Soon, they will add solar panels to use even less electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking but will make extra electricity. The only heating is a small wood stove, used only in the coldest winter. Is it warm in winter? One February night, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The room was 18C, which is comfortable because there are no draughts. In the past, people were comfortable at lower temperatures because of their clothing. The house is simple and low-tech, with few things to break. It was built cheaply, costing the same as low-cost housing. Commercial builders do not like this idea.'

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies in a garden, he believed they were real. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural things. In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them among flowers. The photos are very pretty. But this simple trick shows that the camera can lie. Today, we use computer programs to change our digital photos, and it is not true that photography was ever completely honest. From the start, photos could be changed.'

**Blacksmiths**

Iron has always been important to people, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have been seen as more than just workers. Before machines were common, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The fancy metal designs in French and Belgian buildings were also made by talented blacksmiths.

By the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain. Big factories did not need them, and new buildings did not use pretty iron designs. But in the last 10 years, blacksmithing has become popular again because people are more interested in decorative buildings and creative interior design. Still, many iron products look old-fashioned, like gates and balconies called 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. In many design stores, you see rusty candlesticks with decorations.

Luckily, there are new ideas, and some events are promoting blacksmithing. One event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says we might be starting a new Iron Age. Power tools help blacksmiths work more easily, allowing them to bend and shape metal creatively. Dawson says, 'These artists now have a material which allows them to express themselves.'

About 250 items are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most money goes to the makers, but some helps promote good ironwork. Dawson's own work includes an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says his style is like 'drawing with metal in space.'

Many artists love working with iron. Unlike other metals, iron is hard to shape when cold. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's soft when hot, but hard when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles inspired by castles in horror films. One looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. She says, 'I love that steel feels like it will last forever.'

Iron has given people visual pleasure and a feeling of safety. It will likely be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

Title: The Day I Stopped Smoking

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. "What do you mean?" she shouted. "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't really explain how I went from smoking a pack a day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It was strange to me too. 

The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy. It happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I didn't like the pressure from people who wanted me to stop smoking. Also, I was healthy and didn't feel sick. I didn't cough and got over colds quickly, unlike some of my healthier friends.

On a normal Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking in Birmingham. I was there to write an article about other people trying to quit. I said, "I won't try to stop myself, it wouldn't be fair. I'm here to write, not to stop smoking." I enjoyed smoking and it made me happy. The counselor seemed to understand something I didn't.

We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when we were told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. The messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. Stopping smoking started to feel like a good idea. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I do anything?

In many ways, it was easy. The craving for nicotine, like hunger, went away after a minute or two. I only felt it for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem. I believed I needed cigarettes to meet deadlines, but I didn't.
