Surprisingly, being at home on weekend mornings was the hardest part, and it still is. I think smoking was something I did when I was bored. Having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each new experience as a non-smoker is different - eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were all times when I used to smoke.

Dorothy who? Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but not many people in Britain know her name. Georgina Ferry has been asking her friends if they know who Dorothy Hodgkin is. If they do, they pass her test. Dorothy Hodgkin won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964. She was a great scientist and studied crystals. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the progress of women's education and the spread of science around the world.

When Georgina started her research, she read other scientific biographies. A friend suggested a book about Linus Pauling, a famous chemist and friend of Hodgkin. But she couldn't find any books about him in her local bookshop. This shows that people often don't find scientists' lives interesting enough to read about. Even some scientists think their lives are boring to read about. This idea makes it hard for publishers to sell books about scientists.

Some scientists avoid being in the media because they don't want to seem like they are promoting themselves. But this can make science seem less interesting to young people. Luckily, some scientists are now appearing on TV and in other media, which helps people see them as real people.

Books about scientists are also changing. They used to be very serious and not talk much about the scientist's personal life. But now, books show scientists as real people with families and personal challenges. For example, Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?" is funny and shows his life outside of science.

Dorothy Hodgkin was very dedicated to her work. She solved the structures of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin. She also had three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life may not seem important to her work, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

Understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language. It's sad that many educated people don't know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

Margaret and her special skill

Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

This skill is called dowsing. Dowsing is finding water, minerals, or lost things underground. Some people think it is a special sense. There are many ideas about how it works. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more. Dowsers, like Margaret, might feel these vibrations. Some say they can even smell water.

Margaret and her husband are very busy, especially when there is little rain. They have many customers, mostly farmers with dry wells. Some customers have holiday homes far from water pipes. Others are building golf courses. Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near waste. The water is in rock cracks, and it is important to bring it up clean. They also need electricity for the pump, so the well should be near power supplies.

Margaret starts by looking at a map with a pendulum. The pendulum swings over places with water. Then, she walks with her hazel stick over the land. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. The stick helps her find the exact spot to drill. Her husband checks the same area. They must agree on where to drill. If they don't agree, they keep looking.

Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition. Many people are interested in how she does it. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This means she understands the land in a special way. Her skill helps their business succeed year after year.

Text: 'We changed lives for a day! Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to do something different? We made it happen for four people - read how it went. Amanda (23), a young mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy (30), who works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant. A. Amanda's story I had never been in a place like it before. It was dark and noisy, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my home town, and I wasn't sure I would manage! Being a mother is busy, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting used to it, the drinks fell off the tray and crashed on the floor. I was so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first! By opening time at 11.30 am, a line had already formed outside, and I felt really nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but that wasn't a problem because everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn't get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was very tired and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn't believe it when one of the waitresses told me it had been a 'quiet' day! I never knew how tiring waitressing would be. I've always thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be friendly and able to handle lots of customers! I'm quite shy, and I don't think I could cope on a busy Saturday night. I wasn't impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me! I was very glad to get back to my children. It seems easy after waitressing! B. Cindy's story I was nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it too. I was told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. I was wrong! As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing. At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming as loudly as they could! I decided to let them play, thinking they'd get tired. Wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they beat me! After much persuasion, I got them into bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun and games started! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew it was just a trick so they could come downstairs and watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never knew how tiring it could be looking after two small children. You don't get a second to think about yourself, and the responsibility is huge. Even so, I really enjoyed the day. Rosemary (42) runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary (30), a teacher at a primary school. C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I have to get up at 5.30 am, so sleeping in until 7 was a luxury! But I took a long time deciding what to wear. I couldn't turn up in overalls and boots, could I? Looking at about 400 pupils at assembly, I hoped I blended in and that my fresh complexion didn't make me stand out as being from the farm. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, using workcards graded by difficulty - very different from when I was at school and we had to recite tables together! Then I helped with a nature project - identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was exhausted and looking forward to a break, but the teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (bliss!) and then a French lesson in the video room. This was fun because all the children wanted to practice on me, which showed my rusty French. Finally, we moved to the school hall for Physical Education. I was tired by now, but the children seemed to have endless energy. The hardest part of the job was standing up in front of the class and speaking - even for just two minutes, it's scary. Teachers may get more holidays a year, but I think I'll stick to farming! D. Hilary's story I arrived at White House Farm at 8.30 am, bright and early, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's 280-acre farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves and heifers, and about 800 ewes! As well as milk, she makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream, which is sold in shops, restaurants, and at tourist attractions. I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk into plastic containers, squeezing ice-cream from a machine into cartons, and sticking on labels. It was hard to stop myself from tasting the goodies! At lunchtime, it was time to check the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and picked up a ewe that had fallen over. If the sheep are left for more than 12 hours once they have fallen over, they could die, so they have to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started the milking. The process took an exhausting two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite a lonely day. I was surprised how much I missed the children - animals don't talk back! The worst part of the job is not being able to get away from work. The cows always have to be milked twice a day, so it's really hard to plan any time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is irregular, and I'd hate to be at the mercy of the weather.'

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is interesting how many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who did not play music, is from a small town in southern Sweden. At 30 years old, he is now one of the best trumpet players in the world. His records include new music and old music from the baroque and classical periods. When you meet him, he looks young and friendly, like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London, and there was a TV show about his work and life, filmed in both England and Sweden. 

Hakan was born near Malmo. His career started because of a Christmas present when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a trumpet. He bought a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra. The teacher, Bo Nilsson, saw that Hakan had talent. Hakan is grateful to have had such a good teacher who loved the trumpet and knew many trumpet players around the world. 

Hakan says the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is hard to make a perfect one. Every trumpet has problems, and no two mouthpieces are the same. He learned to work with these problems. Even as a child, people could recognize his special sound. Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who started in a brass band, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired Maurice Andre, a French trumpeter who also played solo. Hakan bought all his records and looked up to him. His parents supported his dream to be a trumpet player. 

At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was like working in a garden. Hakan knew he played better than others his age, but he realized he could also connect with people through music. Thibaud suggested he enter a competition for experience. Hakan learned the music for the first round and made it to the second round. He knew most of the music for that round too, but the final round had a difficult piece. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and saw that people listened to him. 

Hakan is realistic about his work and does not try to explain his gift of communication, as he believes it might ruin it. He thinks the power of music is that it can always move people.'

**New Books in Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special story about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is known for its humor and the author's unique ideas. It is a difficult but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. She would not usually meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, both boys do not talk about the event. Leo, who was a good student, does not explain why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is worried about her son, and Sheila feels guilty. They meet and become friends. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives.

C. This book was nominated for the Booker prize. It tells the story of a small Scottish island and its people over many years. The story includes important moments in Scottish history, seen through the dreams of a young boy, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears but returns after World War II, appreciating his ancestors' simple lives.

D. After a successful book, the author wrote a sequel with the same gentle humor and observations about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is almost seventy. She lives with her friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is charming and kind, and Rosie helps her manage her relationships. By the end, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is taking over. The author shows the sadness in everyday life and how events can be random.

E. Six different people are invited by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe their personal journeys. Each person learns more about themselves during the trip. The author uses strong images to show themes of memory and awareness. These images are both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs: the good parts, the hard parts, and what they do every day.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34

**ANNE'S DAY**

"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and start work at 8 am. I begin operating at 8:30 am. I do surgeries all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some take all day. I've worked ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed during surgery, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it works, it's amazing. From 10 am to 1 pm, I talk to patients about their operations. I like this part and find it easy to talk to them. If they are upset, I try to comfort them, but I don't always have enough time. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I'm on call and carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first three days about my patients, and I dream about surgery at night. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31

**MARITA'S DAY**

"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9:15 am. On Monday at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work and any problems. We work in teams. My team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. I spend 10-15% of my time designing; the rest is production. I get a brief from the client and spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After the client agrees, we plan budgets and hire photographers and illustrators. I talk to the printers and make sure everything is on time. I manage people and need to communicate well. When their work is done, I send it to the printers. Managing many jobs can be stressful. Deadlines are always close, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour. We try to go out, but sometimes I eat sandwiches and work. It's great when a client likes your work, but disappointing if they don't. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. I find it hard to relax when I'm busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42

**LINDA'S DAY**

"I wake up at 7 am most days, but two or three times a week, I meet early flights and wake up between 4:30 am and 5 am. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Driving is a sitting job, so I watch my diet and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People ask me to recommend places, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are booked in advance, so I can check routes. Not everyone is polite. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice, and I have good relationships with regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. The press has tried to make me talk about clients, but I don't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to sleep by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27

**TRACY'S DAY**

"I wake up at 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial jobs, but mostly private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At 11 am, we get hungry and go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. The office is at home, so I check messages and calls when I return. If someone wants their garden designed, I meet them in the evening. We use old materials to make gardens look old. Sometimes people have specific ideas that aren't great. It's satisfying to see a garden finished and blooming. It's hard to relax in the evenings because I hear the business phone. I sleep well because the work is physical, and I'm tired. It's a tough job, but it lets me be creative."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27

**ZENA'S DAY**

"I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I'm the assistant resident engineer, looking after building bridges and a wall to keep cars from falling into a quarry. I check that contractors follow the schedule and safety rules. I help solve problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so I first check with the clerk of works about what happened since I left. The rest of the day depends on what he tells me. I look at paperwork or answer design questions. Lunch is usually for half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I eat as I go. When contractors eat, it's easier to check the site. We check their work, which can cause conflict, so we need a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day. If something important happens, I act before telling them. I usually leave the site at 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Work Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7.30 am. I work with customer programs for our credit card users. I help start and manage the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and answering emails. I handle advertising for the membership program in Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan and develop strategies. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6.30 pm and 7.00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10.00 am and check the mail. I receive 10 to 20 demo tapes a day, letters, and concert information. The phone starts ringing at 10.30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be helpful. I know if the sound fits our record label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7.00 pm and often go to concerts, sometimes seeing five new groups a night. I might visit an artist in the studio after a concert. I usually get home at 1.00 am and listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**
I wake up at 8.00 am and drive to work, arriving at 9.30 am. I check the mail and diary to see if we have clients visiting. I enjoy showing people around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques from £1,000 to £6,000. We buy from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration. I work with restorers, gilders, and framers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette with coffee to stay updated. I visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts monthly and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5.30 pm and take an hour to relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work shifts and leave home at 6.00 am for early shifts. At 7.00 am, I take over one of four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for 1.5 hours, then taking a 30-minute break. We control aircraft movements as a team. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I read about new air traffic rules between 12 and 4.00 am. It's important to be alert, so I take sick leave if needed. The job is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and maybe a general manager.

**E. Shop Manager**
If I work an early shift, I leave home by 8.00 am. I start by setting up the electronic sales system. I ensure someone watches the till and coordinate breaks. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be annoying when they bring reviews and expect quick service. Between 2.00 pm and 4.00 pm, publishers' reps visit, and I discuss new titles. I decide how many copies to order. I ensure new titles arrive on time. The early shift ends at 5.45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the system and locking up before going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7.00 am, then take a taxi to work, arriving at 8.45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies. I provide three services: an online newsflash, a security forecast, and a travel security guide. From 9.15 am to 9.30 am, I meet editors to discuss stories. My first newsflash is due by 10.00 am, and the second by 11.00 am. I write, send, and edit stories before they go online. I travel to Africa three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6.00 pm. It's hard to relax, and I'm often awake at 1.00 am.

**Career Power: How to Be a Good Leader at Work**

A. **What is a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps them change. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says leadership is about making things happen with people who are as excited as you are. A good leader should speak clearly and confidently. Dixon says, "Say 'I believe' instead of 'I think'."

B. **Can Anyone Be a Leader?**  
John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says many people can be leaders. We all have some leadership skills, but we need the right situation to show them. We often see leaders like Mahatma Gandhi or Richard Branson, but leadership is also important in our own jobs.

C. **Think About Your Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you had. Both might have been good at meeting goals, but how did they do it? The best boss motivated and supported you. The worst boss made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first was a good leader; the second was not.

D. **Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within rules. Leaders create new ideas. Michael Shea, who wrote about leadership, says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a company for the better.

E. **Improve Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can learn to be a better leader. Here are some tips:  
- Find what you are passionate about and lead with that energy.  
- Think of yourself as a leader.  
- Sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different styles and see what works.  
- Set goals and try to beat them. Look at your job and see where leadership can help you do better.

F. **Keep Learning**  
- Leadership takes practice. Take risks and learn from mistakes.  
- Learn to delegate tasks and motivate others.  
- Your way of leading might not work for everyone. Keep improving your communication skills.  
- Be visible and available to important people.  
- You don't have to lead all the time. Know when your leadership is needed and help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video**

Film critic Nick James reviews some recent films.

**A. Abyss**

Before Titanic, director James Cameron made this exciting Cold War movie. It is about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a submarine deep underwater. The leader, Bud, and his team are brave and funny. The special effects are very good, but the story is simple.

**B. The Thin Red Line**

This film is based on a book about the battle for Guadalcanal. Directed by Andrew Marton, it is a traditional war movie. It focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. The film has some good parts, like a dream sequence about the soldier's wife.

**C. On Guard**

This film is based on a novel from 1875. It is a fun adventure with sword fights. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain, and Vincent Perez is a lively hero. The film is full of action and humor.

**D. Character**

Set in old Rotterdam, this film looks like a museum piece. It tells the story of a strict bailiff, Dreverhaven, and his difficult relationship with his son. The film focuses a lot on the historical details.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**

This is a re-release of a classic film. The sound is very clear, and the music is exciting. The story is about three men, the good, the bad, and the ugly, who are all looking for treasure in the West.

**F. The Longest Day**

This is a long war film with many stars and extras. It shows the planning of a big invasion. The film is impressive but is better on a big screen. On video, it loses some of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
Steve Martin's "Compelling Evidence" is a very interesting story. The narrator is a lawyer who starts a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife when she is accused of killing her husband. The trial is exciting, and the ending is surprising. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" starts with excitement. Sigismondo, who helps the rich people of the Italian Renaissance, gets involved in politics and murder. We know he will find the guilty people. The story is a bit complicated and long, but it is still very good.

**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector who starts investigating when a man dies near her. She faces many challenges, but she is brave and smart. Leah is a great character.

**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker is about Spenser, a smart private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk to stop drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The conversations are quick and clever, and there is more thinking than usual. It is very entertaining.

**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann has detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They look into a robbery and attack at a famous actress's daughter's house. The author's easy style and interesting characters make this a fun mystery.

**BOOK F**  
Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock wrote "Blood Red, Snow White" together. It is about a lawyer and his female client, but the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story goes on. It has romance, money, and violence, making it a thrilling book.

**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher. He is in danger while filming a Robin Hood story. The funny characters make the story entertaining, but it is not as good as Shaw's other works.

**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are after a smart bank robber who targets female bank workers. The story builds tension slowly and is better than the average detective story.

Text: "I might be too old for this, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age decide to do this. This summer, I quit my job, rented out my flat, and decided to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old, and I'm nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America. When I came back, I wanted to do it again someday. But then I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning money. But I realized I was giving up my happiness for my salary. When I quit my job, it felt like I was in control of my life again. I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't change places with me, they envy my freedom. I'm not in a relationship, and I have no big career goals. I feel like I should enjoy this freedom, even for my friends' sake! Why am I nervous? First, it's about making plans. How could I let someone else live in my home? How do I rent it out? And I had to decide where to go. I'm bad at making decisions and am already late. 'Might as well enjoy the summer in England,' I told myself. Then, 'Why not stay for the start of the football season?' Leaving emotional ties makes it harder. I'm delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I adjust to a simple life? Will I fit in with young backpackers? Maybe not. Many Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to leave their lives and travel. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet, says people realize they can have adventures if they are brave and organized. Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, want one last adventure before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm ready to give up job security for the trip,' says Danny. 'I worry I won't move up in my career, but it's a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a sign of defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, a year of travel was a big change. 'In the military, there's a set way to do things. I needed to change this to live as a civilian.' There are many reasons to travel at my age, but some are common. 'We have a more flexible workforce today,' says Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development. 'More people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.' Big companies even have career-break policies. 'If you train someone, it's nice to know they'll come back rather than work for a competitor.' Dan Hiscocks, from Travellerseye, says more people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. 'If you're not happy, it's not about just staying in the job. Now people know there are opportunities, and a job isn't "for life" anymore. Travel lets you think about your life.' Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation can't grow up? Jennifer Cox thinks not. 'It's a sign of a better society when we care about living a balanced life. We ask, "Is this what I want?"' Ben, a 32-year-old going to Central America for a year, doesn't think he's running away. 'It's more about going towards something I want.' But he is a bit scared. 'It's about leaving behind a comfortable routine, like going to the office, saying "hi" to everyone, and having coffee.' I also worry about leaving a simple life, and I'm not sure I'd travel if my boss wasn't so bad. As Jennifer Cox says, 'There's often a reason, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to do it.' It took a push to get me moving, but now I'm excited about the next 12 months. Whatever happens, I'll be happy I took this chance. I think all of us older backpackers feel the same."

Text: 'Plugging in the home Georgina McGuiness had taken a long break from journalism and felt out of touch with technology. She shares how she changed her family home into a good workplace. The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to restart my career in journalism. My skills were old, from the 1980s, when typewriters were used. I didn't know how to use a computer, and many jobs wanted experience in desktop publishing, which I didn't have. I was afraid of technology; even pocket calculators confused me. I thought it would be hard to work again until I entered a competition in a local newspaper. My family and I won a computer package. We got a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We learned new words like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing. We started chatting with people around the world on the Internet. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem. I could work from home and still take the children to school. The children were good with computers because they learned at school. I was slow and worried I would lose my work by pressing the wrong button. But I learned the basic skills I needed. It was logical and easy. I started writing for a magazine, about two articles a month, and I felt happy to have the best of both worlds. The computer helped me become organized. I used to lose important papers, but now I use spreadsheets to keep track of money and pre-made invoices and letterheads to save time. As a journalist, the Internet helps me research stories and talk to people about working from home. But working from home can be lonely. There are distractions, like house chores, and the children and I sometimes argue over who uses the computer. Many people now buy computers for education and fun. In my street, people work from home to avoid traveling to the city. A report says the average computer user is 38 years old, well-educated, and owns a personal computer. Many have a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. I am ahead of this trend. Maybe one day, I will send a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or start my own magazine from home. The sky, or cyberspace, is the limit.'

Text: 'The Tartan Museum The new buildings of Scotland's national museum look very different from the old buildings in Edinburgh. But are the things inside the museum as interesting? Sally Varlow visited the museum before it opened. You cannot miss it. The outside of the new Museum of Scotland is very noticeable. It is on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh, with a big, yellow tower and buildings that look like a piece of cheese. Last winter, people had different opinions about the building. Some people loved it and called it a 'masterpiece', while others were not sure or did not like it. This winter, the inside of the museum is almost ready, and people might have different opinions about the exhibitions too. The museum tells many stories with important historic objects. There is a timeline to help visitors understand, but it does not make the displays boring. The museum does not let its beautiful national treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels, get lost in national pride. The real question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to visit again. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, says a visit should be fun and easy to understand, even for people who do not know much about history. Clarke believes in showing the truth. He does not like fake scenes from the past. He says, 'The public deserves the truth.' So, in this museum, you see what experts know. But can the stories be interesting with just explanation panels and a few computers? It is hard to say before the opening. Some things are clear, though. The views of Edinburgh Castle are amazing. Inside, the museum has many different spaces. The galleries are different sizes and shapes, with pale walls that look like stone and deep display cases. Light comes through small windows and from the roof. There is space to enjoy every item. Thanks to a group of children from all over Scotland, the museum has a Discovery Centre. The children wanted to ride through the displays, but they got a special hands-on centre instead. The Twentieth Century gallery, on the top floor, is the only temporary exhibition. It will change after three years. It has objects chosen by Scottish people and other famous people as important to life in Scotland in the twentieth century. The Prime Minister chose an electric guitar. Others chose televisions, Thermos flasks, and favorite toys. The idea is fun, but it might not seem very serious. It might feel more important when the computer with personal stories starts working next week. Dr. Clarke is right when he says, 'Objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else.' The modern buildings look great from the inside and the top, but some people might think they do not fit in with the old buildings around them.'

Text: 'The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition. It's a nice word and a calming idea. Change can scare some people and challenge others. But transition means moving slowly and nicely from now to the future. Unless, it is newspapers' 'transition' to the online world, which is not easy - because it might not happen at all. But surely (you say) it will happen one day. Everyone knows that print newspaper sales are going down while visits to their websites are going up. Just look at the latest print circulation numbers. The Daily Telegraph, The Guardian, and others are down between 8% and 10% each year, but their websites are getting more visitors. This might be true, depending on time, age, place, and more. After all, everyone - from web experts to print experts - says so. But wait a moment and think about some things that don't quite fit. If sales in that area have fallen so little, maybe the problem mostly affects newspapers? Yet again, the messages are mixed. The latest survey by the World Association of Newspapers shows that global circulation rose 1.1% last year (to 512 million copies a day). Sales in the West dropped, but Asia made up the difference. As for news and current affairs magazines - which you'd expect to be in trouble - they had a 5.4% increase. In short, on both sides of the Atlantic, although some magazine areas went down, many grew quickly. You can see a similar thing with books. Kindle and similar e-readers are selling a lot more this year. The first step of transition seems clear. Yet, when booksellers looked at the value of the physical books they sold over the last six months, they found it just 0.4% down. Screen or paper, then? It wasn't one or the other: it was both. Stories like these of young people stopping reading newspapers are not true. Look at the latest National Readership Survey numbers and you'll find nearly 5,000,000 people aged between 15 and 35 reading the main national dailies. And even in Europe, different countries have different stories. There's Britain, with a 10.8% drop in recent years (and a 19.6% fall for quality papers), but in Germany, the decline has only been 7% all round - with a mere 0.8% lost to quality titles. And France shows only a 3.1% fall (0.8% at the quality end of the market). These different national trends may show a situation more complicated than the digital revolution experts think. America's media experts used to say that online advertising money would pay for change and, with lower production costs, make online newspapers a success. But now, with digital ads on newspaper sites going down, such ideas seem old. Already 360 US papers - including most of the biggest and best - have built paywalls around their products. However, the best way to get people to pay seems to be a deal that offers the print copy and digital access together. In other words, print is also important in selling internet subscriptions. And its advertising rates make nine to ten times more money than online. Of course, this big difference isn't good news for newspaper companies, as keeping both a website and a print edition is hard, complex, and expensive. But newspaper brands still have much of their high profile in print; on the web, the job of just being noticed becomes much harder.'

**Taking Photos of People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A photo with a person is usually more interesting than one without. But, taking good photos of people can be hard. The photographer must think about actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, the camera can make people act differently.

**A. Group Photos**

In group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces. Or, you can take the photo from a higher place.

**B. Posing for Photos**

People often act stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. They can fold their hands or put them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Way**

Do not pretend you are not taking a photo. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their photo taken. They might feel shy at first, but they usually like it. You may need to guide them. A photo can be ruined if the person is looking away.

**D. Eye Contact**

A photo is more powerful if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They do not have to smile. Remind them to look just before you take the photo. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.

**E. Candid Focus**

Instead of looking at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the photo. This can make them feel more comfortable. The viewer can see what the person is looking at. Candid photos are interesting, and the expression is important.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child makes us smile, while a sad face makes us feel sad too. Look for familiar expressions like winks, anger, or thumbs-up. They are a visual language.

**G. Background Interest**

A background can add interest to a photo. Make sure the background does not take attention away from the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look larger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**

When people are talking, joking, or working together, there are chances for good photos. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Show how one person reacts to another.

**I. People and Places**

Many photos of people are taken on holiday. To show people with a background, use a wide-angle lens. Move back to get the whole scene in the photo. Ask people to stand close to the camera. A good photo shows a balance between people and the place.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you want to take the photo. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose with a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are all posed. Candid photos of events are more lively. A spontaneous photo can bring back memories better than a posed one.

Text: 'Under Sarah's Spell Sarah Janson is an artist who makes trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings trick the eye and look very real. Joanna Watt interviews her. Sarah Janson does not usually sign her paintings unless someone asks her to. She believes the work is more important than the artist. Janson is very modest and acts like her paintings make themselves. She says, 'I don't like to talk about myself,' and feels shy about being photographed. But later, in her living room full of art, she becomes more relaxed and the interview is fun and interesting. Janson has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she was not happy with illustration, so she joined a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to make a trompe-l'oeil painting, and she loved it. She decided to work on her own, feeling she was on the right path. Janson's skills in observing and detail, learned from illustrating, are important for trompe-l'oeil. She says, 'No one can teach you trompe-l'oeil. It's about observing life.' She believes she is still learning and says, 'If you think you know everything, you should stop.' Janson is honest about her weaknesses, like not being able to paint bread well. When she had to paint a big ceiling, she felt unsure and thought, 'I'm not Michelangelo.' Janson sometimes talks about herself as if she is someone else. She says, 'When I finished that ceiling, I thought, "Well I didn't do it, she did".' Her work is very good and different from others who try trompe-l'oeil. She has done many big projects for companies and private clients. Her work is often inspired by buildings. For example, she painted a dining room to look like a Venetian palace and a corridor to look like it leads to more rooms. Trompe-l'oeil must trick you and keep your interest. Janson says it should also be personal for the client. She enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. Some clients know what they want, and others do not. She listens to them and tries to understand their imagination. Many clients become her friends because she spends a lot of time with them. Janson thanks her clients for letting her paint on their walls. They are happy with her work, so she is always busy, even though she does not like to talk about her talent. She says, 'I don't like to talk about myself. Like my work, I am quiet. I don't want it to be loud.' But you could never get bored with Janson or her work. It should be more famous, and I am happy to talk about how great she is.'

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman talks about 'people skills' that are important for success at work.

**A** The way we are judged at work is changing. It's not just about being smart or having good training. It's also about how well we handle ourselves and others. These skills help decide who gets hired or promoted. They show who might do very well and who might not. These skills are important for future jobs too. They are not about doing well in school exams. Instead, they focus on social skills and personal qualities like being able to take action, understand others, adapt, and persuade. These are called emotional intelligence.

**B** Today, job security is not guaranteed, so personal qualities are important at work. Emotional intelligence is a new name for skills like understanding and managing our own and others' feelings. It includes self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. It's not just about being nice. Sometimes it means telling someone the hard truth. It also means managing feelings so people can work well together.

**C** Many businesses now see emotional intelligence as important for management. The more complex the job, the more these skills matter. People with good emotional intelligence help companies work better together. In today's workplace, teamwork and customer focus are important, so emotional skills are needed everywhere.

**D** Unlike IQ, which doesn't change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. Studies show people get better at handling emotions and social skills over time. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence and use it to help us in life. It's important now when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for all problems, but without it, other things may not work as well.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and phones have made it easy to take pictures of important events. Social media has changed how people share these pictures. Now, news often starts on social networks, and some journalists use these pictures for their stories. Sometimes, reporters use these pictures without asking. There is a rule that says pictures on social media can be used without asking if there is a very good reason. But people still talk about whether this is right or wrong. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event. This means that these pictures are important for the media's future. But, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure people are paid for their pictures and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

**Acupuncture** is a treatment that is 2,000 years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal medicine, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to help with many health problems, but it is most known in the West for helping with pain. Some doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists use it to help people with pain.

**What is Acupuncture?** Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy is called Qi (pronounced "chee"). Qi moves through the body along lines called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, the body can become unbalanced, leading to illness. An acupuncturist will try to find where the Qi is not balanced. They do this by feeling your pulse, looking at your tongue, and asking about your health, mood, and habits. They use thin needles in the skin and may also use heat or pressure to help Qi flow.

**Acupuncture Points** There are over 300 points on the main meridians where needles can be placed. These points may not be near where you feel pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This feeling shows the needle has reached the Qi.

**How Does It Work?** Western doctors have found that acupuncture can help with pain. They think it works because it might block pain signals from reaching the brain or because it releases natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.

**Types of Pain Treated** Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture. It is used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in very sick people.

**Modern Use** Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia in surgery started in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China see that acupuncture could be more than just a mental effect. In China, acupuncture is used in many surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia, like nausea.

**Effectiveness** Clinical trials for acupuncture are hard to do, but some show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with chronic pain. Acupuncturists say it usually takes six or seven visits to feel real relief, but some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.

**Different Views on Pain** Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They spend time finding out what might be causing the pain, like if it is worse in cold or damp weather. This helps them decide how to treat the pain.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist** Some medical professionals are trained in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using Chinese medicine can lead to a longer-lasting cure. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist who will refer you to a doctor if needed.

Text: P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very calm and confident, like a school headmistress. But she is actually shy. Her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is a bit like her. He likes to solve crimes alone, and she likes to write alone too. She needs privacy to write. P.D. James is very humble and does not think she is the most famous crime writer in Britain, even though many people around the world read her 12 detective novels. She likes the books of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, and some male writers like Graham Greene.

P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband, Connor Bantry White, in Cambridge. He was a student there. Her life was difficult at times. Her husband came back from World War II very sick. She had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped a lot by taking care of the children.

She worked for the National Health Service and later for the Home Office. She worked in the Police Department and the Criminal Law section. She saw many dead bodies while working in forensic science, but she was more interested in writing crime stories. She liked the challenge of writing a detective story. She wanted to be a serious writer and thought detective stories were a good start. Writing these stories helped her bring order to chaos. She believes solving a crime shows the importance of life, even if the person was not well-liked. She says nobody really likes violence.

Text: 'Handwriting Can Show Your Character

In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might need to give a sample of your handwriting. This is because handwriting analysis, or graphology, is used to see if you are right for the job. Many people believe that graphology is a real science. They say it can help find illnesses like heart disease and cancer, and show how a person feels or if they have emotional problems. Big companies use graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. But many doctors and psychiatrists do not believe in graphology.

Patricia Marne, a graphologist for over 20 years, thinks doctors should take it seriously. She says handwriting can show if someone is smart, what they might be good at, and if they are honest or tricky. She also says it can help see if someone might be a criminal. Criminals often have messy handwriting. They might write like children or go over letters many times. Ms. Marne can tell if people are honest, tricky, or good workers. She says young male criminals often have tall letters, showing they dream a lot. Graphologists can see if someone might become violent, is under a lot of stress, or has mental problems. Handwriting can also show if someone might think about suicide.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can show health problems too. If handwriting changes a lot, it might mean something serious is happening. A big emotional problem can change a signature for a short time. She also says people with 'thread' letters are clever but tricky. People who write in all capitals are hiding their true selves. Light writing means someone is sensitive. Original handwriting shows confidence and artistic talent. Disconnected writing means the person likes to be alone. Small signatures show someone might feel shy or not good enough. Circles over the 'i' mean the person wants attention, and crossing the 't' hard means they might be bossy.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years to learn how to read handwriting well. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She believes it is better than psychoanalysis because you can learn about a person without asking them questions. But there is not much proof for these ideas. Some psychiatrists say handwriting only shows how a person was taught to write and their artistic skills.'

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy, healthy team, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were. Our expert team included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, and windows open to the street. The team of seven people seems happy and adapts to the seasons by opening doors and using electric heaters. They have created a homely work environment without much outside control.
Ergonomist: The furniture is mixed and often creates bad postures. Chairs are old, not adjustable, and many are broken. However, the team has a varied work schedule, which helps reduce tiredness and boredom.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. The office is the right size for knowing what others are doing but also having personal space. It feels efficient and creative.

Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable and the air quality is good, helped by a No Smoking policy.
Ergonomist: Chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good. The space is well-used, but the layout could be better. The office feels impersonal with grey walls.
Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for planners and a poster. Staff relationships are okay. The office could improve by making it easier to share information and displaying success stories.

Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: The office feels like a glass case. Even with smokers, the air is not stale.
Ergonomist: The office is standard and uninspiring. Desks are just adequate, and not all chairs meet requirements. Computer setups are outdated.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and use technology well. The office is busy, but the wood panels and brown carpet make it look dull.

Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: The air-conditioning is poor, causing temperature changes. The space is cluttered and dusty.
Ergonomist: The furniture is not suitable for a modern office. Chairs are old and not adjustable, making it hard for shorter people to work comfortably.
Occupational Psychologist: The office is dirty and needs cleaning. There is little conversation, and everyone seems stressed. The company should focus on teamwork.'

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular and people in America chew 12 million pieces every day. It started as an old custom and is now a big business. Each piece of gum has less than ten calories, but it is still considered food. This means it must follow the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration. 

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and make it feel nice to chew. But this was not always true. Long ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like resin from the bark of the mastic tree, found in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. 

In America, colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States could buy lumps of spruce for chewing, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, growing sapodilla trees commercially has not worked well. As the gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were needed. 

Today, a few chicle gatherers, called chicleros, still work in difficult conditions. They travel long distances in hot, humid forests to collect sapodilla sap. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicle fly is especially troublesome because it lays eggs in the tappers' ears and nose. Chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap, which they carry to a camp to boil and make into bricks. Life at the camp is hard, with simple food and local alcohol.

Even though their work is tough, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. The United States used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use more synthetic materials to save money and meet demand.

Gum producers are finding new ways to sell their products. They say gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces tension. Soldiers in both world wars were given gum. Gum is also said to reduce tooth decay by increasing saliva, which helps protect teeth. Research continues to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and vegetable oils are used in gum, and most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural ingredients. In America, 137 square kilometers are used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**Remote Hotels**

**A. India - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests to their home. The hotel is simple, with hot water brought in buckets. This simplicity makes it special.

**B. New Zealand - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After a long climb down a glacier, I was surprised to see this hotel. It is in a beautiful, wild area. The luxury of the hotel, with someone playing piano, was amazing after the climb.

**C. Mauritius - Beachcomber Paradis Hotel**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in southwest Mauritius. The road to the hotel passes empty beaches. The hotel is big, with free watersports. But you can find peace on its nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, the beach feels far away from everything.

**D. St Lucia - Ladera Hotel**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia is in a dramatic location. It is quiet and high up, with rooms open to views of the Pitons and the Caribbean Sea. The style is colonial, with wooden furniture and four-poster beds.

**E. Turkey - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, near Istanbul. The islands are an hour by boat and have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is a wooden building, painted white with red domes. It is a bit old now but still charming.

**F. France - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
In the village of Etoges, in Champagne, is a 17th-century chateau. It has a moat with swans and 20 unique rooms. Some rooms have four-poster beds, and one has a billiard table. There are special weekend rates with breakfast, dinner, and champagne.

**G. Kenya - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel in Nairobi is comfortable and not too fancy. It is a popular stop for travelers on safari. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens and rooms. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to watch the sunset and enjoy dinner.

**H. Italy - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Hotel Splendido in Portofino was first visited by the Duke of Windsor. Many famous people have stayed here, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy guests. The hotel was once a monastery and is still very beautiful. The restaurant serves simple, delicious food.

**The Hotel Inspector**

Sue Brown works as a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton watched her do her job. During the annual check, the Globe Hotel is already having problems. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue Brown, the real guest. Sue whispers, "Very poor." This is a common mistake she has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide. But Sue is not impressed. 

When they arrived, they had to enter through an empty door with a buzzer and walk down a long, empty hallway. Sue says, "Not what I expected." Things get worse when the receptionist says they have no record of Sue's booking. Most of the hotel's rooms are empty that night. Sue's room is on the top floor, but she does not like it. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

Sue used to be known as "The Woman in Black" because she was tough, but she says she was never too tough. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He looks worried. He apologizes for a bad smell in the main lounge. Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that room. Greaves agrees and takes notes. He has been at the hotel for only five months. Sue says her feedback will help the hotel in the long run.

Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good work. Dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks how to get three rosettes. Sue says, "Don't serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves looks disappointed.

Sue's job is to say what other guests are afraid to say. Sometimes people complain about her, but she tells the truth. Sue writes a full report for the hotel. They pay to be in the guide, so they want her advice. The good news for Greaves is that Sue will not recommend taking away the hotel's red stars. But another inspector will come in the next two months to check if things are better. Greaves says, "Good," but he does not look happy.

Text: 'Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott tells about his experience of climbing the highest mountain on each continent: the Seven Summits. My journey to climb the Seven Summits started later in my life. I will talk about them in the order I climbed them. A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m) We were in a snow cave 91m below the top when my climbing partner, Dougal Haston, started talking to Dave Clark, our Equipment Officer, about sleeping bags. This was strange because only Dougal and I were there. I thought it was because of low oxygen. I then found myself talking to my feet. The cold was getting to my feet, and I remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. We were more worried about how we would survive than if we would survive. Over the next two days, I thought about our time on the summit ridge. I realized I couldn't have been there with a better person than Dougal Haston. He gave me confidence, and I felt calm, thinking it would all work out. I knew I needed a better rhythm to reach the top, and I did. B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m) This mountain is known as one of the most dangerous in the world. In April 1976, Dougal and I arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day of climbing, we realized how big our task was. On the lower part, we followed a route from 1967, but halfway up, we took a new route to the upper snow basin and the summit. We decided to climb 'alpine style', carrying our equipment and food. It was the first time a major new route was climbed this way. We climbed up the snow of an avalanche scar to camp under a rocky cliff, and by the third day, my sleeping bag was wet. We spent the third night on a windy ridge; by now, we were both suffering. Mt. McKinley, because of lower air pressure in polar regions, affects the body more than its height suggests. It felt like we were at 7,000m, not 6,100m. We packed our bags and finally reached the summit and went down the other side, feeling triumphant. C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m) In September 1976, Paul Braithwaite and I flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. But we got a free ride to the Tanzanian side of Kilimanjaro, so we climbed Africa's highest mountain. On our way, we got lost in the thick jungles of the lower slopes. It was serious because water was scarce. On the second day, we found arrows on trees and a trail of rubbish that led us to a rock pool. I was never so happy to find rubbish on a mountain. We tried a direct start to the breach wall, a 305m-high icicle. After falling rock and ice, we wisely chose the Umbwe route to reach the summit. D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m) The original route up Aconcagua is like a walk. In January 1992, I arrived with my wife, Sharu, at Punta del Inca and met fellow climber and guide, Phil Erscheler. He was taking a group up the mountain via the Polish Glacier, away from the busy route, and suggested we join them. After three days of bad weather, we left base camp. The Polish Glacier was icy and windy. With a time limit to return to Buenos Aires for our flight, we skipped the glacier. Instead, we went across the north ridges to the standard route and joined many people on the path. The wind was strong as we walked the last few meters to the summit, and just before dark, we camped outside the refuge. Back at base camp, we met eight members of the Jakarta Mountaineering Club. They wanted to climb the Seven Summits and thought I should do the same when they learned I had climbed four. This was the first time I seriously thought about such a goal. E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m) When I learned that climbing Vinson Massif was just about guiding enough people to pay for the trip, climbing all Seven Summits became possible. Our team left Britain in late November 1992 and traveled to the South Pole. At this time of year, the sun is always up, day and night, and when the wind stops, it is very quiet. In the clean air, the atmosphere is refreshing, and spirits are lifted just by being there. On December 7, we left camp and headed to the summit. Despite strong winds and temperatures below minus 50°C, we all reached the top in 8 hours. Our happiness was lessened by the storm, which reduced visibility to a few meters. F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m) Our team met in St Petersburg in early summer 1994. When we arrived at Terskol, below Elbrus, a fee was asked from our guide for bringing foreigners, but it was later waived. After a few days of getting used to the altitude, the group took a cableway to 3,900m. From there, we walked to the refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, the wind was strong as we crossed open slopes, some icy. By mid-afternoon, we reached what we thought was the summit. But there was another kilometer-long ridge to the actual summit. As night fell, we returned to the refuge and the next day went down this extinct volcano. G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m) On our trip to Carstensz, we wanted to make a new route and spend time with the aboriginal Dani people. The largest gold mine in the world is cutting into the mountain, which is sacred to the local tribes. We were warned we might be taken hostage or harmed by bandits, but we continued. On May 12, we started climbing. The weather got better, and two team members went ahead. We were slower because Sham was filming. Climbing in rock shoes, we reached the summit by 11 am. I received a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!'

Text: 'Style Merchants Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley talks about the trends for this year's fashion lovers. Ned Ingham: Dress Designer Ned Ingham makes beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. 'People should choose simpler styles instead of traditional, stiff dresses,' he says. Ingham started drawing and designing wedding dresses when he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don't have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress: he also designs long evening dresses with new colors and fabrics. For those who like classic styles, Ingham offers a summer navy-blue suit, a key piece in English fashion for many years. Sally Quail: Jeweller Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but didn't study jewellery formally. She started designing jewellery when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous people wear her jewellery. Her style includes large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by the 18th century. Recently, she started using diamonds. 'It reflects my age,' says 36-year-old Quail. 'I wanted a diamond, so I began working with them.' Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer Lily Grimson started her business four years ago and has already had two of her handbags chosen for a big design exhibition. Her bags are always noticed. All of Grimson's bags are handmade in the UK. They are glamorous, made from fine calfskin or heavy silk. A mix of style and care makes a Grimson bag special. Peter Little: Hairdresser For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. 'Most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home,' he says. His goal is to make sure his clients don't look like they just left a salon. But this natural look is expensive - £250 for the first visit, and there's a three-month waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools. Now, people can style their hair at home. Penny Pratt: Florist Penny Pratt runs a small shop and is a flower consultant for a big supermarket chain. She also gives ideas to top restaurants. She used to be a teacher but changed careers 10 years ago. Her simple, modern flower designs have won many prizes, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She says, 'Flower arrangements are simpler now. Keep them simple but strong, and don't use too many leaves. For wedding bouquets, use flowers of the same kind.'

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four big old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way. It cost £250,000 to install, but MacCann believes it will be worth it. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, they will find those CDs ready on their next visit. 

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little themselves, or the front desk can adjust it more. Business guests will like the technology in their rooms. MacCann thinks 65% of guests will be business travelers. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has extra cables for future technology changes. TVs are rented, so they can be updated easily. DVD recorders can also be upgraded.

Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large bedrooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a popular place to eat without financial risk. With technology and a great staff, the Merrion is likely to succeed.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her big garden around her house gives her many flowers to paint. She loves tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow wildly all over the garden. The garden looks beautiful with colors and shapes, thanks to the people who owned it before. They were good gardeners and left plants that Susan likes. She also got a gardener named Danny from them. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny didn't agree with some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one plant at a time, not the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She paints one flower at a time, which can take a few days, and then adds more flowers. Sometimes, it takes years to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times because the tulips and poppies bloom then. She finds it interesting how flowers change over time. For example, tulips change shape when you put them in water.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. She was amazed by how wildflowers grew in difficult places like rocks. Now, her garden has plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas. She lets the garden grow freely, like a kind aunt who lets children play as long as they don't break anything. Susan is busy with two upcoming exhibitions and doesn't have much time for gardening. She hired another gardener but knows she needs to work in the garden to stay connected to her art.

Many trees in the Brackham area fell down in the big storms that March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This changed how the town center looked, which upset some people. One of these people would usually be Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police. But during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. He was a strong man, but he got very sick with bronchitis for the first time. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, told him to see a doctor. Pelham thought the police needed him, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forget things and get angry easily. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. He was too weak to argue. Soon, he got his medicine and went home to his wife, who sent him to bed. On Thursday morning, Molly told him the walnut tree fell during the night, but Pelham couldn't understand. On Thursday evening, he asked about damage to the house, was happy there was none, and went back to sleep. On Saturday, when he felt better, he saw that the missing walnut tree changed how the living-room looked. The Pelhams' big house had a large garden. It was expensive, but Pelham was happy they bought it. The garden made it feel private. But now, the storm changed things. Before, the walnut tree was part of the view from the living-room. It didn't make the room dark because there was another window, but it made nice light patterns that hid the old furniture.
