With the tree gone, the room was very bright, and the old furniture looked shabby. The view from the window was not nice. The tall house next door, which the tree hid before, was now visible with its ugly purple bricks and pipes. It had many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams. 'Doesn't it look terrible?' Pelham said to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded happy. 'I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.'

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first understood the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, before winter, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimetres deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden strong winds; trees moved, but the branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they did not trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that worried us most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams built many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we watched dark clouds over the hills to the west. Grey clouds spread over the valleys. They moved and rose, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we watched the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain came from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and was close to danger level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like Niagara Falls, as water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the waters rushed down. Just a couple of metres from our cottage, the stream was wild under the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it near our home, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the waters began to go down.

Many times before the dam was built, the river had flooded the nearby villages. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually, all is well; the water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with just a little overflow sometimes. We can enjoy, not fear, the big clouds over the valley, and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this protection, we feel our home in the valley is still safe.

Text: 'Film Critic Mark Adams talks about his last ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I wrote reviews for novels in other newspapers, films for a magazine, and anything for the radio. That's how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. He also wrote for radio and TV. He hired me, but Tom was not mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his team. At first, he wanted a team of critics to cover art forms that didn't need special knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to review from the material Tom picked, and there would be guests to make it friendly. It felt like a dream then: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. It seemed just as likely that a rich person wanted to help me and was pretending to hire me. I didn't have much confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to my review, I didn't know where to look. Tom's idea for a team of critics never happened. It was a good idea, but we didn't meet as planned, so everything was done by phone. It turned out that people preferred a reviewer to focus on one subject, so I chose film. Without Tom's help, we wouldn't have the current setup, where I write a long piece each week, usually on one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn't like the usual film critic's job, which means reviewing every film that comes out. That would make me bored quickly. I would soon be sitting in my seat on a Monday morning thinking, 'What bad film must I watch now?' - a feeling common in screening rooms worldwide. The space I have lets me expand my argument - or forces me, in a dull week, to make something interesting. But what is my role for the public? I think people choose films based on the stars, the publicity, or the director. People also have loyalty to a 'type' of film or the opposite. It's rare for someone who hates westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a fan of love stories to avoid a romantic film because of a review. So if a film review isn't really a guide for choosing films, what is it? I don't feel I have to be 'right' about a movie. I also don't think there should be a set number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. All I have to do is present an argument. I'm not a judge, and I don't want to be.'

Text: Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun." Teenager looking for a training partner for triathlon, preferably female. Chance to work with a possible Olympic champion. Must like distance running (15km sessions), distance swimming (training in cold rivers), and distance cycling (100km rides). Must do all three without stopping. The triathlon is becoming a popular Olympic sport. Many people watch athletes swim 1500m, cycle 40km, then run 10km without stopping. But why do triathletes want to do this? And why does a 17-year-old girl with good school results want to do it? Melanie Sears has not learned the usual answers about personal satisfaction and mental challenge. She says, "You swim 1500m, then get on your bike, still wet. You freeze. After the 40km cycle, you run 10km, which is hard when you're tired. But it's fun and worth it." Melanie did her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior. It seemed easy, so I waved at my team-mates." Confident, she entered the National Championships. She had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, but she got lost and cycled 20km too far. "I cried during the run." But she did not give up. "Sometimes I want to stop because of the pain, but I'm afraid if I stop once, I'll do it again." Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director, admires her. "I tested her fitness. She worked so hard on the running machine that it threw her off. She gave it everything, but most people stop when they can't go further. She kept going." Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but slower at cycling. That's why I'm working hard at it." She wants her parents to buy a £2,000 bike for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships. Her training makes her a bit of a recluse. "I don't have a social life. I'm not a party person. After two hours of swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I phone and write to the other girls in the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, what times they are achieving." Where will this focus end? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," with a 750m swim, 20km cycle, and 5km run. She wants to enter even tougher events. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. Funny, that.

Text: 'The Collectors Amanda Roy talks about the things she collects and why many people like this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults enjoys this hobby. It is a world of passion and happiness. But remember, if you do not love an object, do not collect it. Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect things. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked their shapes and colors. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells because they are beautiful. I have been collecting all my life. I collect many things, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote part of England. It was cold and windy, with many hills. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum. It was full of objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these objects. Many people are interested in collecting. One in three adults shares this passion. People collect for different reasons. Some people like it because they can control it. For me, it's just something I enjoy. A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with many interesting things. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. But you do not have to be rich to start a collection. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups. I remember getting a special tulip from another collector. I planted it, but one year it was stolen. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I looked all over the USA for them. This collection was destroyed in a house fire. The next day, I saw the remains of my furniture and collection. I was very sad. I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or poet is valuable. As small objects become popular, their prices go up. Toys from the 1950s are now an investment if you kept the original boxes. (I threw mine away.)'

**My Job**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. I read about the exhibition topic and talk to experts. I decide on the main themes and what objects and pictures to show. I make sure visitors understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to keep the exhibition safe. Before it opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start work at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents are needed for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are learning the routes. They find the best way using one-way streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like if a right turn is allowed at a junction. Close to the test, I give them a route and tell them to find another way because the road is closed. This makes them think.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the sea and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but mostly I am by the sea. I work with schools and run courses for people who make decisions about the sea. I take them out on a boat to see sea life. This often changes their views. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. But, I work for a charity, so I always need more money and resources.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is varied. I make sure our books match what the market needs and keep stocks of about 300 books. We have high standards for information. We get letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I answer them carefully. I talk about future projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job fun. The downside is there is too much paperwork, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

Text: 'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, own the house. They have made some changes to it, but very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel our friends recommended, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us have played cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We think it's a coincidence. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling when we arrived this year. She always seems to know when guests are coming because she's usually waiting in the big hall that smells like flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' These are the names of the rooms for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she does things like that; her husband does repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming in from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt like our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn, everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur took our luggage to the rooms, carrying as much as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns, others going down the cliff path to the sea. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew this because we always did it. Since we first came here, we all loved the beautiful landscape.'

Title: Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year doing this job. Sarah cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets. Chalets are wooden houses typical of the area.

Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is fun for a year or two before starting a serious job. She meets many successful people every week.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast and then prepares breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the worst part of the job.

By 11 a.m., Sarah is ready to ski. She skis as much as she can. On a good day, she skis until 4.30 p.m. She returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. Dinner is three courses and is served at 8 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they want to be alone.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out at about 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. But she does not stay out late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day.

On Sunday, work starts early. Breakfast for guests leaving is at 7 a.m. After they leave, Sarah cleans the chalet quickly. She clears breakfast, changes the beds, and gets everything ready. If she did not shop on Saturday, she does it now. At 3 p.m., she prepares tea for new guests who arrive at 4.30 p.m. She helps them with questions and takes them to get ski equipment if needed. Then she prepares dinner again. Sometimes she has a drink after dinner, but often she is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie. But she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by curly hair. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions on the phone or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita Cohen was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class. Years ago, these children came from their school 50 kilometers away to see how Marie's dad made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table. Marie called them the 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.

Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour answered, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, 'They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' Rita said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered, 'I'll set that up for you if you'd like. Tanning is an old industry. They found 6,000-year-old tanning relics in Turkey. The first clothes were just skins tanned by smoking them. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for two days. Glovemen love their trade. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' Rita replied, 'I can't say I have. I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' Seymour laughed. She made him laugh. She was eager to learn, like his daughter Marie. 

Seymour said, 'I'll show you the whole process. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

Text: 'Is it a hard job? Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem. A. Raquel Graham Raquel Graham calls from a taxi taking her to the airport. She can't meet us tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. When you're a personal assistant to a pop star, you have to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. There's just one small problem - she doesn't like flying. 'On a nine-hour trip to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help calm me down,' she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. 'It felt so closed in with those tiny windows.' When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork - organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel plans. She didn't apply for the job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance, which led to the job offer. She took a secretarial course at night school at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a PA. B. David Brown David Brown has been an accountant and a golf caddy; a person who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he liked being a caddy more. Well, you would too if golf was your passion. There were some downsides though. A small flat fee is given, plus a percentage of the winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that is spent on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first caddied for the golfer, Greg Norman. 'You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the course.' His accountancy skills were recently noticed by European Tour Productions when they made him a statistical data administrator. From cards brought in by the caddies, he collects and analyzes the statistics of each day's play. The results are wanted by TV commentators, golfing magazines, and the golfers themselves. C. Martin Fern Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to try food in the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? 'For those who can afford it, it's their choice,' he says. 'I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember for the rest of my life than buy a microwave.' His talent as a cook led to the offer of a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director of an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper called to offer a full-time job. 'It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income,' he says. 'But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession.' He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his waistline under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station. D. Dick Prince 'I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago,' says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. 'Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but my writing was mainly poems. Then I had this idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a kind of role reversal story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story.' Where do his ideas come from? 'Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them,' he says. 'That is what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not up with the dawn, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend another couple of hours typing out the morning's writing - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter rather than on one of those awful laptops. I get between 50 and a hundred letters a week, and that is the part about being a writer that I enjoy the most. I do try to answer them all, but nowadays I have some secretarial help.'

Text: 'In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were made into boards for building, there was an old brick building with two floors. Around the building were big piles of soft sawdust. These piles looked like golden mountains and went all the way to the blue lake. That afternoon, because they were bored, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, 'I dare you to jump down,' and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. 'I dare you all!' he shouted. 'You're all scared,' he said, trying to make them jump too. Laughing, he watched them from the roof. They looked scared, but one by one, they jumped and smiled with relief. In the hot sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one boy said, 'Let's go up and jump again.' They weren't very excited, but they all went up and jumped off again, until only Michael was left. The others were below, calling, 'Come on, Mike. What's wrong?' Michael wanted to jump and join them, but he stayed on the roof, nervous and smiling awkwardly. It seemed like a longer drop this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, but it didn't work. He tried to take a deep breath and close his eyes. The boys started to laugh at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. 'Come on, you're scared. Do you think we'll wait all night?' they shouted. When he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. 'Who started this? What's wrong with you?' he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, went down over the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. There were no sounds; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump before. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, 'You're old enough to come home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight.' She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke seriously, but Michael, feeling sad and miserable, hardly listened. He still saw the boys' smiling faces and heard them laugh at him.'

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy with your job but don't know how to change it? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people who want to change jobs go to a careers adviser. You will write a short history about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with career suggestions and possible retraining needed.

I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The test felt like a science exam. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. It was not about passing or failing. The tests included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and advice. I agreed with most of it, but I was surprised I did poorly in science and technical tests. I was happy to know I made the right choice with journalism.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to try Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to look at my career and skills,' says Donna. She found out she was good at design but had to think about the cost of retraining. Other ideas included working in the Far East for a year. She decided to use her skills in a new job as a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped her see what she wanted to do. She recommended them to her friends.

Some people feel they couldn't have changed without help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. The tests showed she liked sciences. After four sessions with an adviser, she decided to study geology. She thinks the advice was worth the money and feels happier now.

But careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, didn't find it helpful. She wanted new ideas but didn't like the options because they needed a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. She felt she didn't learn anything new about herself. She thought a friend could have given similar advice.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the wall and a stylish blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Half of the people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared." To help with this, he tries to make a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because people think it means pain. He believes dental visits should be relaxing and even fun.

This is surprising for many people who think dental visits are painful or very serious. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed and happy, they will forget bad experiences." He uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. His office was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while he checks their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth. Many patients like this part of the visit.

The office smells nice, like a perfume shop, not like a dentist's office. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome says, "When people come in, I want them to know it is not like a usual dentist's visit. Smell is important. The usual dentist smell can make people scared." I found the smell very nice.

Jerome is known as Glasgow's most fashionable dentist, but he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but good treatment is the most important. He uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels strange at first, but it is not painful if you are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. He learned that making it easier for the patient also makes it easier for the dentist. He thinks this patient-friendly approach will slowly change the formal British dentistry style.

A patient arrives, and Jerome offers him tea and asks what video he wants to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

**Chocolate: From Ancient Times to Today**

Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought during this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.

The cacao plant, used to make chocolate, was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan people in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, also known as cocoa beans.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water'. They added spices to the drink for special events. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took a century to become popular in Europe. In the late 1600s, chocolate houses opened in European cities where people drank chocolate.

In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands made chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. In 1847, Fry and Sons in Bristol made the first chocolate bar by mixing cocoa butter, chocolate liquor, and sugar. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.

In the early 1900s, French companies led the British chocolate market. In 1879, Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add French style. In 1905, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar became popular with ads linking it to healthy English milk.

Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. To attract more customers, companies now make chocolate bars into ice creams, drinks, and desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers still struggle after a drop in cocoa prices in the 1980s. Many small farmers went out of business. Remember them when you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

Title: THE SHELL ARTIST

Peter Cooke is 83 years old and very good at his art. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But right now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. He has been doing this for ten years.

Peter shows me his work in his apartment. He is very excited about it. He points to some shell ornaments above his fireplace. He says he doesn't mind if people don't buy them because he loves them. He never planned to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. Five years ago, he had an exhibition in London, and 70% of his work was sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday.

The pieces are expensive, with some costing around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he doesn't set the prices. He believes no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him that people will want his pieces when he stops making them.

Peter wishes he started this art earlier in life. He feels he could have made even better things. Now, he is limited by his age, but he still creates amazing work. His art is different from the usual shell items found in seaside shops. He makes boxes with tiny shells, pictures from shells, and flowers that look real.

Peter has his own way of working. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts, special glue, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He travels to places like France, Thailand, and Mexico to find beautiful shells. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who say he is harming the beaches. He believes he is saving shells that would otherwise be broken by the sea or people.

Text: 'The Schoolgirl Model When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to exciting places and appearing on magazine covers, she is probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more. 'I'm afraid Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said, 'no problem.' I was trying to forget all the bad things I had read about models, like being difficult, vain, and not smart. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she thought going to the hairdresser's was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not answer my questions. But when the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and said sorry for being late. She was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. She was not selfish; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must take an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum, proud of her successful daughter. Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense because it was not planned. Her older sister decided she should enter the model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should try it,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos anyway.' When they called to say she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final made Kira confident to continue, and she did great. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work. Kira now finds it hard to manage her two lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. 'They're really proud of me,' she says. However, some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. 'They say I think too much of myself.' This must be hard for Kira because she is not self-important. But she says, 'They think that because I'm a model now, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I'm more confident - not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more.' As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. 'If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, "Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us".' Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they finish school. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do if she wasn't a model. She pauses and replies: 'I'd like to do what you're doing.' '

Father and Son Search for Gold

Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they believe they are close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 and from Liverpool, said, "We are finding a lot of gold as we dig. We just need to dig a few more meters."

The Maddens have spent their lives looking for gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold in the "Dolgellau gold belt," near a Welsh town with the same name. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to find the best place to dig. After clearing the land and finding some gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and cleaning up the area. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They need to find someone to give them £50,000 to dig a few more meters. Chris Madden says, "It looks difficult, but we have some people we can ask."

Last week, people in the valleys heard about the dig. The idea of finding gold excited both the locals and the gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, more people might visit. But I hope not too many people come and dig up the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry was very busy in the late 1880s, with many mines and workers. But now, it has declined. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. Hall, who is 70, said, "Searching for gold is emotional. It's exciting to find hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at chemical processes in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. She dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very small. Rachel can touch the two pilots next to her. They cannot stand up or move much. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive lasts 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to go back up. If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that goes quickly to the surface. It is like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice journey.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck. She got in with an instructor. He showed her emergency procedures, like what to do if the pilot has a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a place five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was putting scientific equipment there to study a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching. She loves teaching, but she does it so she can continue her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out fast and is very hot, at 350 degrees.

Rachel was scared once when she first went down with the Americans. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope. Suddenly, there was a big explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle. Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence. When nothing happened, they were very relieved.

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out and sees the chimneys, she feels wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has seen these places before. She studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD. Seeing them for real was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired. My mind was tired of foreign timetables, money, and languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. I just needed to buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train's movement helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply. You might even burn socks that smell bad or throw away books when you finish them. This is the Inter-Rail spirit. You can forget about common sense and just enjoy the trip. All you need is a ticket. This train ticket lets young people visit many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our camp-site in southern France. But we wanted to keep traveling because there was always another country to see. And it didn't cost us extra. We were not only interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We made our own plans and only saw the easiest sights. We wanted to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that sometimes I only saw the view from the train station. We just wanted to have fun. We were like other Inter-Railers, sharing train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city is real only when the train arrives, and you see it with your own eyes. By seeing Europe, watching the landscapes change, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles, you can understand the continent better. Everyone knows what is there, but it means more when you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. The train trip won't show you new things in the world, but it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps people see this, even if it takes time.

Text: 'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your baggage is not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to people who travel a lot. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and they cannot promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes. 

Airlines ask you to check in early to give enough time for your baggage to go through the airport and onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times to change between flights, and they are also longer to help with baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause baggage issues. Sometimes, human error or a torn destination label can also cause problems. These issues are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. 

The chance of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America. To avoid losing your baggage, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes or it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

Text: 'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, giving some shade to the shallow water. The main colors are soft greens, mud browns, and different yellows from the sunlight. The bird moves quickly through this scene, like a flash of light. It is gone in a second, but you remember its image. Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He cannot say exactly why he likes this little bird so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. In Greek myth, a moon goddess turned into a kingfisher. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this. Kingfishers have no blue color in their feathers. The structure of their feathers reflects light and looks blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or green, depending on the light. Many wildlife photographers love them. Kingfishers are shy but can be watched from a hideout. This makes people want to photograph them. Charlie James used an old blanket as his first hideout. He waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back and sat close to him. But it took him four years to take a good picture. During this time, he spent a lot of time by a stream with many kingfishers. School made it hard to spend time with the birds, so he missed classes and did not do well in school. But people noticed his interest in kingfishers. At 16, he worked for a nature magazine. Later, he became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make a film about kingfishers with just beautiful images and no words. He likes to photograph parts of kingfisher wings. He thinks about the colors of the bird he loves. His photos show some of his feelings, but there is more to his love for kingfishers than his work can show.'

Text: 'Conducting an Orchestra Conducting an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work. A. ANNE MANSON Anne Manson, 30, got a chance to help famous conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. She was not nervous and enjoyed leading the orchestra. Anne is American and works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries with help from the British Arts Council. She has worked with Abbado on many projects since then. B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right opportunities. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. He thinks the timing was perfect because it helped him get many chances to perform. He worked as an assistant to a famous conductor. Now, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra invite him back. He hopes people will remember him for his work, not just the competition. C. WASFI KANI Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera and loves the long practice time for opera. She began conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional. Lessons with Sian Edwards were important for her. She likes the challenges of opera, including working with singers' personalities. D. ROGER VIGNOLES Roger Vignoles, 48, is surprised by his new career as a conductor. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival. He found it easier than expected because he knew the music well. He is learning from all his experiences and is open to new opportunities. E. WAYNE MARSHALL In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, now 32, and told his agent about him. Marshall soon conducted a musical in London. He had to be firm with musicians who were not paying attention. He gives clear instructions and is confident in what he wants. He has not formally studied conducting but is determined and knows what he likes.'

**Theme Parks in Britain**

If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to visit some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. But we were surprised! The park is great for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the children wanted to stay longer because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have better scenery. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We spent six hours there and liked the places to rest. The park looks beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with its exciting trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. For younger children, Toy Land is fun. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small. The park is well designed, so waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, a staff member helped by sitting with one of my daughters.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at one o'clock and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for brave people. If the children were older, they might find it a bit boring, but they loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary, and Ben thought it was the most frightening ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about twelve main rides, and the older children went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides, but she liked the Long Slide. The staff were sometimes nice, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their stories about starting a business in the countryside.

**A. Christine Hogan**

Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Christine had worked with computers before, so her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. Christine was careful with spending and talked to the bank manager if she needed more money. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings. Her business is small, and local people usually come to pick up their work.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**

Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no such jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different greeting cards, which she sells to museums. Maggy works in a big room at home. She doesn't advertise; people hear about her through others. She is cheaper than other artists, so people send her work from London. Maggy misses sharing ideas with others, but she likes being independent.

**C. Delia Turner**

Delia Turner has a curtain-making business. She started it eight years ago. At first, her business grew quickly, and she managed six full-time workers. But when the economy got worse, she had to let them go. Now, Delia makes curtains at home with her husband's help and other women who work from their homes. She has to lower her prices sometimes and look for new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**

Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because London was expensive and she loves the country. Tessa works with authors and artists from around the world. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. It was hard at first because she felt alone, but she enjoys working when she wants.

**E. Meg Rivers**

Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. Meg started making fruit cakes at home ten years ago. She used good quality ingredients and soon got requests from friends and family. Now, she sends cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building for her business. Meg doesn't bake anymore; she manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial side because she didn't have a lot of money to start with.

Text: 'Meet the Amazing Watkins Family The sons are musicians and composers, and their dad makes instruments. Matthew Rye reports. Families with musicians are not rare, but it is special to find one with music writers, performers, and an instrument maker. John and Hetty Watkins, teachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul. It was too expensive, so John thought about making one. He found the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for three years. After making some violins and violas, he tried making a cello. Paul, now 28, says, 'It turned out really well.' John later made another cello for Paul, which he used until recently. John retired from teaching to make instruments full-time and makes about twelve violins a year. He sold one to famous American player Jaime Laredo, which was a big success. Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music early. Paul first played the piano and then the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin, but he liked the cello player in his dad's music group. Huw was also encouraged to play the violin but chose not to. Huw says, 'My parents were supportive and relaxed.' Now 22, Huw is becoming known as a pianist and composer. John's cello helped Paul win the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At 20, Paul became the main cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his dad's cello. Now he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is 304 years old, from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul will play the Rugeri on TV in Elgar's Cello Concerto. He says, 'I'm always going to do it my way.' Paul can't watch himself on TV because he is playing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw's String Quartet will also be performed in London that night. John and Hetty will have to be busy to follow their sons' musical events.'

Text: 'Looking after the countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is a group that works to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people. Wardens talk to farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. He got the warden job because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. He is also strong enough for the job, which includes building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Gareth has learned more about nature conservation since working with the Trust. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and now sees how farming has changed the countryside. He says it's not the farmers' fault; they followed government advice. When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists disagreed. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's work includes conservation, letting people visit Trust land, planting trees, and meeting farmers. He makes sure jobs are done well and cheaply. He likes finishing projects, but he also spends time on paperwork. Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to most people, but some visitors can be rude. He says common sense is important for the job. If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But there might not be a job on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't people look at you strangely?" She said, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra says, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict plan to be very fit. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries playing. "We will have support from people at home, which is special," she says. "It's important to make netball more popular in our country. Playing here means more pressure. People expect us to start with a good game."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of skill." The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be hard. "You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you only have one chance."

In the 15 years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. "You train hard to win," says Kendra. "But after the game, we are all friendlier."

Netball now uses more science for fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mind and must lead by example. I support and encourage my team."

"From the start, my netball career was planned," she says. "I decided this competition would be my last as a player." She might coach young players in the future, but now she focuses on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**Specialist Music Schools**

What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents might not notice their child's talent until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or science, but musically talented children need special help. Regular schools might not have this help, especially if music is not important there. 

Children who are very good at music might benefit from going to a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools. These schools help children aged seven to eighteen to improve their music skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music activities like lessons, playing in groups, singing, and learning music theory. They also practice a lot in special rooms. The rest of their time is for regular school subjects like English, math, and science. 

These music schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school, which means they spend a lot of time with other children who also love music. 

There are some problems with these schools. First, they are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year. But schools try to help parents with scholarships. Second, not all parents want their young children to live away from home. Some school directors think it might not be good for very young children to be in such a strict environment. They want to make sure children grow up to be well-rounded people. 

Being in a music school can be stressful. Some children might lose interest in music as they grow older. The pressure to be the best can make them feel like they have failed. But schools watch each child's progress and offer help if needed. 

Many students from music schools say they learned a lot, but some wish they had more regular school subjects. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more than just music. 

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can decide for themselves if they want to go to a music school. Children who are good at both music and school subjects might do well in a regular school with a good music program. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, but this is only possible if they live near a big city.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her big garden around her house gives her many flowers to paint. She loves tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow wildly all over the garden. The garden has beautiful colors and shapes, thanks to the people who owned it before. They were good gardeners and left plants that Susan likes. She also got a gardener named Danny from them. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny didn't like some of her ideas, but when she said she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one plant at a time, not the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She paints one flower at a time, which can take a few days. Then she adds another flower to the painting. Sometimes, it takes years to finish a painting. Spring and early summer are her busiest times because the tulips and poppies bloom then. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." She also likes to watch how flowers change over time. For example, tulips change shape when you put them in water.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. She liked wildflowers because they grew in hard places like rocks. Now, her garden has plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas. They grow well in her garden. Susan lets her garden grow freely, like an aunt who lets children play as long as they don't break anything. She is busy with two art shows and doesn't have much time for gardening. She hired another gardener, but she knows she needs to work in the garden to stay connected to her art. "You have to get your hands dirty," she says.

**Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. Sarah cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses. She graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more serious job. She meets many successful people every week.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then prepares breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning the rooms is the worst part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as she can. On a good day, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower before cooking but does not sleep because it makes her too tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans up and fills the dishwasher. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they prefer to be alone. Good guests can make the week fun, but some weeks are not as good.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out at about 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. Sarah does not stay out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work earlier on Sunday because breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet quickly. She clears breakfast, strips the beds, and gets everything ready. If she did not shop on Saturday, she does it now. At 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests with ski equipment. Then she prepares dinner again. Sometimes she chats with friends, but if she is very tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing clothes for Marie Claire was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and quiet, but here I was busy. Some fashion team members seemed stressed. My job is not stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I like seeing how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. I stroked an elephant and thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She went with the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn't know gardening was so much work. I am more enthusiastic than good at gardening, so I will keep my job as a nurse."

Charlie Dimmock is a landscape gardener with Ground Force. She worked at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I would faint, but I was okay. The nurses are very friendly, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual work with men. I feel my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not fun, but it was satisfying."

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different. People respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my training. On the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone looked at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one adult."

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers don't eat very healthily, but they drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. But it has inspired me to join a gym and be healthier."

Text: 'On the Train: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories. A Andrea Thompson - Newsreader I love the south of France and visit often. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast and into Italy. The views of the sea are amazing. It doesn't matter if it is sunny or rainy, it is always beautiful. You can also see some of the nicest gardens and houses in France. It feels like you are looking into the homes of rich and famous people. The people on the train are always interesting, with a mix of tourists and locals. Raj Patel - Explorer I have enjoyed many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park because I was too young. When I moved to England, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first big station I saw, and it amazed me. Betty Cooper - Novelist I love the Blue Train because it took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey through France and then by boat up the Nile was the perfect way to relax after our wedding. Martin Brown - Journalist We were working on a series of articles and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not reliable, and the driver would wait for people. When the train came, many people climbed on, even on the roof for free. At night, the train went through beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream. Arisu Mezuki - Actress Most people love trains from when they are children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw few trains. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a railway. The old train line was kept by volunteers. That's when I started to love steam trains. When we were not filming, we rode the train. When I went back last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights on the station!'

Text: 'Do you want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. Selling your writing needs knowledge about the 'writing world'. No matter what you write, you need to know about the markets you want to reach. The best way to do this is by reading a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading will show you what publishers are looking for. Remember, things change over time. New magazines come out, editors change jobs, and magazines change their style. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. If you want to write short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and see what kind of stories they like. Pay attention to who the readers are. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I never want to discourage anyone. But maybe the work is not ready to be published. Most new writers send their work too soon. If you have only written one story, it is not likely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Write ten or twenty more. Each one will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others at first. Remember, every successful writer has faced rejection. Do everything you can to become a writer. Look for a creative writing course or join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

Text: 'No Title On the last day of a bad year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I thought there would be. The station didn't feel as nice and clean as usual. Older couples with matching bags sat on the benches, and many college students sat on the floor with their bags. A man with grey hair was talking to different people. He looked rich: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question. Then he came to a girl standing near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her. The man asked, 'Are you going to Philadelphia?' 'Well, I'm going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, and moved to the next bench. Now I was interested. 'Ma'am,' he asked an old lady, 'are you going to Philadelphia?' When she said, 'Wilmington,' he didn't say anything, just moved on to a couple with matching bags. I stood up straight and moved closer, looking at the platform like I was thinking about the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. I knew why he didn't. I probably looked unreliable. He just looked at me quickly and then went to the bench at the other end. He looked very stressed. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She put her book down. She was about thirty-five, older than me. She looked like a teacher. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favour?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my left wrist. (I don't have a watch.) Even without looking, I could tell she was careful. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too hard, I promise!' They were announcing my train now. People started moving to Gate E, the older couples pulling their bags like big pets. Then I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said "hello" to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called home from the station in Philadelphia; she didn't know what to do.' The woman made a sympathetic sound. I would have stayed quiet. Waited to see what he wanted. 'So I told her to stay there. Stay in the station, I said, and I would get someone here to take her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so important? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a bad excuse, if you ask me. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, which would have made more sense, but a padded envelope the size of a small book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel what was inside! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Be careful, lady, I thought.'

Text: 'Gary and Me John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his son Gary, a famous TV chef. I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for me. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I was upset because I was alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family.' My wife took care of the children and did my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant, and we always made sure to have meals together. This was good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life. Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. When he was older, he worked for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By 15, he was as good as the men working there, and sometimes he was in charge. He made over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he was talented. When he needed work experience for school, I sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do. I told him: 'Gary, if you want to succeed, do it by 30. After that, it might be too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he and the other new students were given a morning's work. But in an hour, Gary finished everything. That's my son! In the end, he helped others. We can't believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show is. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work hard for it. He's seen his chance and taken it. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even a little of what you say, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he listened sometimes.'

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you could afford was very difficult. The best way was to know someone who knew someone leaving a place. But if you were new in Dublin, like Jo, you had no personal contacts. Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. Dublin was a big unknown place for her. She didn't question why she was going there. Everyone from her school thought they should leave their small town and see more of the world. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, but Jo was the only one going to Dublin. She was going alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be good if she stayed in the hostel run by nuns, where she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because hostels were often cold.
