Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know her family was still thinking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed perfect. She hoped it was nice, that they would like her, and that it wasn't too expensive.

There wasn't a long line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The "own television" part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who didn't get the flat, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful."

"Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type."

"What did she do?" asked Jo.

"She didn't do anything. She just looked around, made a face, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear,' in a fancy voice. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?"

Pauline wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was amazed because she had never talked to a punk before. "I'm Jo, I work in the post office, and I called about the flat."

Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said "Nessa," one said "Pauline," and the other said "Other." "We'll put your name on it if you stay," she said kindly.

People love dolphins. We like to see them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are disappearing. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas.

The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has gone down by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law, but they are not. This could become a big problem for wildlife. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. The first two live far out in the sea and are seen only in small groups. We do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few left have skin injuries, showing they are stressed.

It is hard to know why dolphin numbers are going down. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces fish stocks and threatens dolphins. Dolphins need to find food quickly. If fish are gone, they may not survive. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks on their bodies show they died from getting caught in nets.

Pollution is another problem. Waste in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. Pesticides, which dissolve in fat, can be passed from mother dolphins to their babies through milk. There is a case where a baby dolphin died from its mother's milk.

Noise pollution is also a threat. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. Noise from ships and oil wells can disturb them. This noise travels better in water than in air and may affect dolphins in ways we do not know yet.

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels busy and stressful. You might think, "Oh no, another article about exercise!" But there are many good reasons to exercise. Exercise is really good for you.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit correctly, which is called good posture. Good posture is important because it stops muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood move better.

Exercise can make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep better and manage stress. Exercise can even help with some health problems. 

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. But be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is good for you.

Good posture is important for how you look and feel. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This helps you stand tall and breathe better. It also makes your body look slimmer.

Stretching your muscles makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine. Do it slowly and carefully, four or five times a week, for a more flexible and fit body.

The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

Why do film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home for many months? They want to find the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is hard to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are now in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained for six months. This rain causes problems. Newman said they bought an expensive tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda can then pull him out. Together, they have made some of TV's best wildlife films, like their famous film on leopards. Even when this film was on TV, they were back in Africa, this time looking for the shy jackal. 

This is normal for TV partnerships. Film-makers travel the world to film wildlife since TV began. I talked to Newman at a safari lodge. He said, 'We sometimes argue, but we get over it quickly.' They do not see one as the leader. They get along well because they see animals the same way. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now, we have a fixed camp. We leave at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' They eat pre-packed meals, heated by whoever is free. 'We can be away for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem,' says Newman. It is a tough life, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to animals. Newman remembers filming lions. One lioness would greet their car like it was part of her pride.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift'. Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months in one place to get enough material for a half-hour film. Before filming, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I worked well together from the start,' says Newman. 'We share the same ideas. We want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals and touch people's hearts. If you can make people feel something, it is better than just making them think.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'

'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I'm on a strict schedule to get very fit.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries playing. 'We'll have support from people at home, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to make netball more popular here. Because we are playing at home, there will be more pressure. People will expect us to start with a good game.'

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of skill.' The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra says, the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, with no rest. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you have only one chance.'

In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so much not to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we are all friendlier.' Netball is also more scientific now with fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mind and to lead by example. I support and encourage my team.'

'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided this competition would be my last as a player.' She will probably coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step.

Text: 'In hot water Rachel Mills is a scientist who works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel Mills teaches and studies marine geochemistry, which means she looks at the chemical processes in the sea. She is a teacher at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she goes into a steel vehicle, like a small car, and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'space is very small, and I can touch the two pilots. We can't stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and then three hours to go back up to the surface.' 'If there is a problem and we need to go up quickly, we can press a panic button. The outside part drops away, and a small escape vessel goes up fast, like a ping-pong ball in water. No-one has tested it yet, but I think it would not be a nice trip.' 'I didn't know how I would feel the first time I got into the vehicle. It was on a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He showed me what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack! They wanted to see how I would react in a small space.' Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian team. 'We went to a place five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, there are many underwater volcanoes, with chimneys blowing out black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean is very active. The Russian team was putting some scientific equipment there to study the effect of a big project that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.' When she isn't at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research into the "black smokers". This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.' 'The only time I was scared was when I first went down with the Americans. We were pulling equipment on a 50-metre rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a big bang, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. We were so relieved - we were still alive!' 'It's such an adventure diving to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the window and see those chimneys, I feel wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no-one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. People decide what they think about us in the first few minutes. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice. Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, 'I worked hard to get my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident.' She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. 'I saw a small hole in my jacket that morning,' she remembers. 'I wanted to change, but I knew it would make me late, and I think it's important to be on time.' Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, 'If someone doesn't try to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?' 

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says: 'People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best.' Many people forget how important it is to look professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but didn't get an interview. 'I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened,' she says. 'He told me I didn't look like an office manager. He suggested I improve my clothes before I apply again. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't matter.'

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from words, 38% from voice, and 55% from facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words are different, the listener will believe the facial expressions. So make sure your words and body language match. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer. It is also important not to look too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she got the job right away. 'I was happy,' she remembers. 'But I showed too much excitement. When the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't say no. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have got more if I controlled my excitement.'

Finally, what we say and how we say it is important for a successful interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. 'The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This will show your interest in the company.' Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. She says, 'Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and clear points.'

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly and used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counsellor helped him. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They left their friends, but many friends visit them now.

**The Hat Maker**

Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. She started her own business making hats in her London flat. She liked her job as a lawyer, but the hours were too long. She did not want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she is always busy. She likes being responsible for her work. She misses talking to colleagues but feels happier and less stressed now.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned about massage. He got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He feels in control and happy with his new job.

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country and won a medal. Sadly, it didn't get much media attention, and I hoped for some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there, with great places to train and good nightlife. But I must be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out before training, I have to say no. I want to go to the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Serious surfers know the best waves are early in the morning, so you can't party late at night. I don't mind that, but I miss sleeping in. It's worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job on a TV surfing show. I guess I'm a bit famous now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in style, but we don't look for media attention. Reporters sometimes care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends. You can't think about the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I'm rarely recognized on the street. I don't want to be a celebrity. I get letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to feel the crowd's support when I play. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans. I like being recognized by fans when I'm out, but it can be hard. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to be serious in any sport. I'm okay with focusing on my game now and enjoying other things after I retire, which happens early in tennis.

Text: 'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, 'They want everything they see. If it's not the latest sweet breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't buy all this stuff, and I feel bad about buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win.' Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number will probably grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why parents say no to buying things. They don't believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when they see fun and exciting ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, 'Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children.' The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, 'The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, "Tell your mum to buy this," they still want that to happen.' Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food, and now they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair when they say no. Mike, a father of two, says, 'We say no to sweets because they are bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be fair all the time.' Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children are not with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring more customers.'

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four big old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way. It cost £250,000 to install, but MacCann believes it will be worth it. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, they will find those CDs ready on their next visit. 

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a special system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little themselves, or the front desk can adjust it more. Business guests will like the technology in their rooms. MacCann thinks 65% of the hotel's business will come from them. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing facility. The hotel has extra cables for future technology changes. TVs are rented, so they can be updated easily. DVD recorders can also be upgraded.

Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large bedrooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food must be excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a popular place to eat without financial risks. With technology and a great staff, the Merrion is likely to succeed.

Text: 'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to tell us how they do it. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I think it's excitement. I need to do something challenging. If I'm learning something new, I get a lot of energy. Anything with rhythm gives me energy, too - right now I'm learning flamenco dancing. Dance is wonderful and gives energy. I think you can feel tired if you're bored. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work but I enjoy it - I love being at work, it isn't hard for me. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel bad even if you're tired. I need a lot of sleep, so when I get it, I feel good. When I sleep only six hours a night, I feel tired. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start! I do a yoga class once a week before work and try to do a workout at home. But if I've done exercise, I feel much better. I feel tired in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon and think it's good to eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthily to get my energy - I think it's natural enthusiasm and being positive. I don't like people with negative attitudes. I think we should all enjoy our lives. Enjoyment comes first. You have to achieve things and set goals. I enjoy what I do and the last two years have been very exciting. In my job, there are lots of lively young people and you can't help feeling that energy. I love being busy with work. I'm very sociable. I enjoy taking photos but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I rush to get them developed and can't wait to see them. I've also started writing words for imaginary songs - it's just for fun and helps my mind when I travel a lot.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from things I do and enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home with my family. Being positive about life helps. That's why I love working with kids, they give so much and are strong. Energy is like a natural chemical, it starts when you talk to others - just try smiling at people and feel happy when they smile back. It's better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise plan. The most energetic I get is running around with the kids and playing with them.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'What I love doing most is making a garden out of a wasteland. I did that once. The garden was all concrete - I broke all the concrete and put in a lot of soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. The other thing that gives me energy is knowing that someone wants to read what I'm writing - I find it hard to write if no one is interested. I also like going into a farmer's land or a wood. If I'm found, I say "Oh, what a wonderful wood, I didn't know it was private," and so on. I like it because it's childlike.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'I believe you must have an interest in and respect for what you do in life. I like to take risks and I get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do makes you tired. I used to be a member of different committees and didn't like the time they took. You only have a certain amount of energy, so use it for the things that are most important to you.' '

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. People have found old skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until about 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was calm and stylish. But in the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie made skating more athletic and popular. Today, skating is both beautiful and physically hard.

For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster only when you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to stay balanced. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It seems easy, right? As you practice, you can make bigger movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills. Even the best skaters fall. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed. This helps reduce the shock when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand.

Once you can skate confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. But first, learn figure skating and basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers to help you learn. You can soon learn basic moves and then turns, jumps, and spins.

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, practice exercises regularly. It is dangerous to skate with a stiff body. Warm-up exercises should include legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It is good for the heart and lungs and makes the body stronger. When combined with swimming or jogging, it is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Young Stars and Their Lives**

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I have no time to watch TV or go out with friends. I just do gym and school. I try to take each training day by day. When I am very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but not often. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great talent from a young age. Some parents push their children, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we gave up a lot, but they don't see what the sport gave us. We love it and what it did for Annika. Before gym, she was shy and hid behind me. Now, she has met people from all over the world and is confident."

**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me to events. Shows last one to five days. I never get tired of it. I love show-jumping; it's exciting and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I am determined. My goal is to join the British young riders team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To join big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is happy on a horse and knows what she's doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is wonderful."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not scared of being proud. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like embarrassment."

**F. Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down because she is special. If she has this gift, let her use it."

Text: 'We are all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller. More tall people are born every year. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. We are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are losing the effects of bad diets from the past. 'We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again,' says Professor Chris Stringer. Cro-Magnons lived 40,000 years ago. In the past, people got food from many places: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, and men hunted animals. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. About 9,000 years ago, farming started, which changed everything. Farmers took over green areas, and now three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our calories. This poor diet made people unhealthy. Over time, we ate soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sick farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn was not a blessing but a health problem. Farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. But people were poorly nourished. Only recently have richer countries improved their diets. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but there are problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and leg-room in planes and trains is small. Clothes makers have to change their products. We cannot grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say we are actually shrinking as a species. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate got warmer, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might shrink more. So, global warming could make us smaller.'

Text: 'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV, but many people don't know much about them. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. I heard that even TV workers don't respect them much. I thought studio audiences were just people who wanted to be on TV for a short time. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of backgrounds. TV shows try to get different people for different shows. Some people like to watch TV at home and don't understand why others go to a studio. Why would someone get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch something they can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. Why did she come? She wanted a chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors - I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.'

Text: 'Favourite places

Bruce
I don't like places that are wild and empty. I like places with people. It's the same when I travel. I like pretty villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham. It was in a nice valley. Riding my bike was a break from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape was familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which I became known for later.

Sophia
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. It is run by people who love trains. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive. The scenery is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I love. The train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we can see people doing everyday things, like making tea or washing dishes. I see myself as a woman in a small train, looking into other people's homes. I like the simple landscape. Just fields, sheep, and a faraway grey sea. It makes me look closely to find something special.

Matthew
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and quiet coast. The beaches are hard to get to and have many rocks, so not many people go there. Some brave surfers come, but most people like to look at the sea. The coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland to valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple places with a family in the village of Southole.

Annette
My favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a wide-open moorland, great for hiking. Not many people live or visit there. It's a quiet and empty place, and I like the space. I found it by accident when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

James
I bought Glenthorne, my favourite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's my dream place. It's a magic, quiet, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.'

Text: 'HAPPY HUNTING GROUND We are a family who loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was excited because she found a pine snake. 'Can we keep him?' she asked. I said, 'Yes, but only for one night.' We had a special tank for animals we found, so we could look at them and read about them in our nature book. I got home late. I started cooking when I heard my sons shouting, 'Oh, Mother! Help!' I ran to their room. Domino, our cat, had Bianca, a white mouse, in his mouth. Bianca was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino ran around the room with the mouse, trying to find a place to eat it. I tried to catch Domino but tripped and fell. Then I saw the snake. It was escaping from the tank. The room was full of noise and movement. The cat, mouse, kids, and snake were all moving around. The dog was barking. I turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and went back to the room. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse. The mouse was not hurt. This mouse was caught by the cat three more times but lived a long life. After saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It was hard to catch. I sat on the floor and waited. Slowly, the snake calmed down. I picked it up carefully and took it to the garden. I wanted it to go to a tree. But when I let go of its head, the snake moved over my shoulders like a scarf. We stood there, me, my four kids, and the snake. My oldest child, DJ, said, 'Mum, you are warm, and the shed is not.' We gently moved the snake to the tree. It slowly went up the wall and over the roof. As the last part of the snake disappeared, my three-year-old, Clay, said, 'Wow, that was a big snake!'

Text: 'Write me a letter! In our fast world of phones and computers, writing letters is disappearing. But for me, getting a letter is special. There is the excitement when it arrives, the joy of seeing who it is from, and the fun of reading it. I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. It started with little notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study as a doctor in London, I wrote a letter every week, and so did my mother. Sometimes my father wrote too, and his letters were always funny and long. Most letters from home were about everyday things. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters most. I also got letters from boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we stayed in touch by writing. Writing letters made our relationships better. I could say things in writing that were hard to say in person. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but a letter with a year's news is better! It's even better when it's an airmail letter with pretty stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, a friend I trained with 20 years ago. I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. I also write to a lady in France. We met in a restaurant on holiday. My husband took her photo, and I asked for her address. If she hadn't replied, we wouldn't have become friends. Now we write to each other often. I can practice my French because she doesn't speak English. We have visited each other too. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer. My family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing for 29 years but never met. Everyone was surprised that we wrote for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it on the front page. I am happy my children are writing letters too. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. I hope people do not let letter writing disappear.'

Title: Ancient Rock Art in Danger

In the French Alps, there is a special place called Mont Bego. Here, there are 36,000 old pictures carved into rocks. These pictures are about 4,000 years old. They show cows with horns, fields, and gods. People think this place was used for prayer a long time ago.

Many tourists visit Mont Bego. But some tourists are not careful. They damage the pictures by writing graffiti on them. Jean Clottes, an expert on rock art, says that if this continues, the pictures might be gone in 50 years. He has seen tourists step on the drawings and even take pieces of rock home. Some people rub the drawings to see them better, which also damages them.

Experts have different ideas on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the mountain should be closed to the public. People could only visit with a guide. But Jean Clottes thinks this is too strict and might upset local people.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, wants to keep the site open. He says it is hard to stop people from damaging the area because it is so big. He suggests charging a fee to visit, but there is no money from the government to pay for guards.

Annie Echassoux, another researcher, is worried because tourists can now reach the site more easily by car. She thinks the area should be roped off and guides should be provided. She believes money must be found to protect the drawings for future generations.

**Young Shoppers**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the newest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't buy all this, and I feel bad if I give in and buy unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things, and they don't believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when they see fun and exciting ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' that's what they want."

Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food, and now they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want them too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be fair all the time."

Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children are not with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring in more customers.

Text: 'Climbing Walls In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. The National Indoor Arena, where the event is held, is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both events have a wall for climbing. This is possible because of new technology. Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they climbed in cold places like Scotland or used buildings to stay fit. They needed strong fingers and wanted to avoid boredom. Sports centers started building climbing walls with special bricks. Don Robinson, a teacher, built a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He used natural rock in concrete blocks for the wall. Many walls like this were built in the 1970s, but they had problems. They were only vertical, unlike real cliffs with different shapes. Also, once built, they couldn't change, so climbers got bored. In 1985, Francois Savigny from France made a new material for climbing holds. These could be put on and taken off walls easily. French companies also made panels with steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhangs, but steel frames could be used anywhere. This system gave climbers many new holds to try.'

Text: 'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky'. Acting is a risky job because there are more actors than jobs. When you decide to be an actor, some friends might say you are crazy, but others might not. Everyone will give you different advice. It is your choice, and you are responsible for your dream. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee that you will succeed after training. It takes luck and talent. But there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous. Sometimes, it can also be rewarding. People often ask what talent is. I think it is natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. Talent also involves courage and belief in what you do. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain. In the theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is important in all acting. It is what makes actors want to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills and other actors' skills. But they do not assume they will always be successful. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, selling clothes or waitressing. Then, you get an audition, but you might not get the job. So, actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, rejection is possible from the start. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented for the job. It is up to you, because if you do not care, no one else will.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are happy to show you our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from all over the world, and she loves exciting food. Delia's book, "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," is very popular. It is a great book for both basic and advanced cooking. The book has been updated and is perfect for anyone who wants just one cookbook.

B. Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in just 15 years. He owns a well-known French restaurant in Britain. His book, "Blanc Mange," goes with his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by showing how ingredients work together. The book has over 80 recipes and explains why some dishes might not work. It also teaches some basic food chemistry. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows how good he is.

C. "Le Cordon Bleu" is famous for classical French cooking. For 100 years, this cooking school has trained many students. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they released the "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook." It has 100 respected recipes. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then has sections for Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. The recipes have step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes.

D. Fast food? No way! Many think good food takes a long time to cook, but Nigel Slater disagrees. His book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good food. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered. He has written more than 200 recipes from around the world. His recipes are ready in just 30 minutes and are very delicious. If you think fast food can't be great, try his recipes.

Text: 'We are all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. Every ten years, people in Europe get about one centimeter taller. More tall people are being born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. We are actually going back to how we were as cavemen. We are losing the effects of bad diets from the past. 'We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again,' says Professor Chris Stringer. Cro-Magnons lived 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people got food from many places: women gathered plants, and men hunted animals. They ate about 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Farmers took over green lands, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - give us more than half of our food. This poor diet made people less healthy. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. But most people were not well-fed. Only recently have richer countries started to eat better again. In the US, the average man is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but it also causes problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less leg-room in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their sizes. We cannot grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say that while individuals are getting taller, as a species, we are shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate got warmer, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might shrink more. So, global warming could make us smaller.'

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly and used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counsellor helped him. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, where they didn't know anyone. They left their friends, but many still visit them.

**The Hat Maker**

Katherine Goodison was a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job, but the hours were too long. She didn't want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she didn't. She likes having deadlines and being responsible for her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being in charge.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22 but didn't find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned about massage. He now works part-time and feels in control of his life.

Text: 'Onto a winner Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers with big beards in their forties, are in their small home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is special. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, was a grocer from Quebec, Canada. He brought the game to the USA and showed it to his family. Soon, the family played the game every weekend and holiday. Dave says they had 'the best time ever'. The family moved to New Mexico, but they still played pichenotte. Grandpa's board was made from old wooden food crates. Visitors were often interested because the game was unknown in southern USA. Three years ago, Dave saw the old board was broken and decided to make a new one. It was very nice. A relative wanted one, then a friend wanted another. The brothers took a new board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. People watched and said, "No way I'm playing that silly game." But then they played and didn't want to stop! People asked about the game's history. Dave found out it started in India with a game called 'carroms'. It changed to 'squails' in Britain, and British people took it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version from Quebec. Pichenotte is a game of skill for two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks'. They 'flick' the pucks across a board with their finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole is 20 points. Three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight small posts are obstacles. The game lasts about two minutes. The game was popular at the Santa Fe bar, so the brothers made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people liked it, and the game became more popular. Championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was made. The boards sold quickly, so the brothers started a pichenotte business. They made a workshop in their garage and made over 450 boards. The boards are made of birchwood and mahogany, weigh 12kg, and are 1cm thick. Norm says, 'They're very strong because they need to last a long time.' They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet. But soon, the brothers hope their garage will have a luxury car instead of wood. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they hope will make them rich.'

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago, this place was just empty land with lots of wild plants. People thought it was useless land. But one man, with help from his wife, changed it into the beautiful place you see today. They moved a lot of soil and clay to make the land look nice. Machines helped, but it was also a lot of hard work. They brought in 1,000 tonnes of good soil to make the grass, flowers, and rocks. 

Many trees and bushes were planted. They had to choose plants that could live near the sea and in strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden shops, but some came from Canada and New Zealand. 

Colin Sims thought of the Model Village. He made over 100 models in nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from stone, concrete, wood, and plastic to last in all weather. Colin learned from experts about how to use these materials, and soon he became an expert too. 

The models are all the same size compared to real life, and every small detail is important. The Model Village is very popular because of its high quality. The way Colin made the models is now used in other model villages in England and taught in some schools. 

The buildings in the village show traditional British styles. One of the best is the Manor House, a 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It looks like manor houses in the West Country. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is new. 

Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models. If you fall, it can take hours to fix the models. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. 

To enjoy your visit more, you can press buttons in front of some models to make them move. At the end of your visit, we would like to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us. Tell us if any models are not as good as the others. We often update the models and need to know which ones need fixing. 

We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village.

Text: 'Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the newspaper editors' rules. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people because they show private moments on the front page. However, few people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC is an organization that deals with these problems. These pictures are rarely important for the public. Do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress was upset about these pictures before. She was in a hotel, a place where she should have privacy, so she had a reason to complain, but she didn't. The PCC did not investigate, which is surprising. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC do something about these attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers and TV would report these decisions. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would stop publishing such material. Photographers would also be affected because they could not make money by taking secret pictures of celebrities. If the PCC acted like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue? Also, celebrities might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC watch all British newspapers and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want an investigation? Most people just want to forget and move on. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. A worse story might exist, and they fear it could become public if they complain. Even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian was also photographed secretly on his honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then or later when his family was photographed on holiday. He feared the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger. They might say it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.'

Text: 'There is a lot of advice for students who finish college and start their first job. In this article, we talk about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a second temporary job while searching for a permanent one. We are also not talking about people leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. We are talking about people who are taking a real step in their career. These people are choosing a job that matches their goals because they have learned some skills and know what they want. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goal. You need to ask yourself if you want to focus on a specific area, move up to higher positions, or change to a different field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can do temporary work when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career. Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because 'OK ... they were very supportive. I learned about office work and improved my computer skills. But there was no chance to move up. One day I quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.' Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more skilled and my job has grown,' she says. 'From the start, my boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I used to do mostly typing and phone work, but now I handle most of the letters and budgets. I also answer questions from company leaders to people who want to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and gives me special projects and events to organize.'

Text: 'Confident people - what's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were born that way, but most say it's a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asks five people how they did it. A Jenny When I left school, I was very shy and thought I would always be like that. When I was twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was scared, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life. B Michaela Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and acted too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, I don't feel bad about leaving some tasks for the next day. When things are difficult, I tell myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to forget those fears. C Lisa People think I'm confident, but when I look calm, I'm really scared. I learned to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous, and we feel better when we talk to friendly people. My mom once said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone is worried about themselves.' I remember this. You gain confidence by doing things that scare you. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt less scared. D Barbara My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I built it over time. If you keep going and learn from mistakes, you become more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You must like yourself, not try to be what others want. My company has training courses that help my confidence. They also encourage setting small goals. It's better to achieve small things than aim too high and get nothing. E Kim After college, I worked as a secretary. In meetings, I was scared to speak up. I finally got the confidence to share my ideas. When I started in politics, I was nervous speaking in public. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' I wrote notes to help me, like a comfort blanket. Everyone gets nervous speaking in public. The secret is to tell yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.''

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He showed me a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat next to them under the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a row of competitors waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kites, judged on decoration, stability, and flying skill. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them is a real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains with thick rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a small sign pointed up a path into the forest: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' It would have been good to know that most of this path was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the track, I found a man with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and some bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects under my mattress. The night was very dark and full of sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and made noises. In the morning, there was a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning hit the treetops. I got very wet. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car being washed away and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the track. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it more for its kind people.'

Text: 'What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but we shop in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I love shopping! I spend a lot of money when I can. I can't walk past sale signs without buying something. My boyfriend is the same, so we shop together a lot. We are a shopping couple! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I don't like shopping. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I don't shop for clothes often. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but we all like different things. I don't spend much on myself, and when I do, I feel guilty. I don't tell my husband the real price because it sounds too high. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for things I need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. I know what I want and won't buy anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I prefer doing other things. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want and where to find it. I shop quickly. I have some clothes I don't wear, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes. E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't like shopping at all. I can't find what I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. I don't shop for clothes often because people give me clothes. I do food shopping once a week and finish it quickly. F. Lisa, 22, actress I'm a happy shopper. I go shopping with my friends, and we often buy things. I don't look for anything special, but if I see something nice, I buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I'm a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I know what I want and don't spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I feel worse if I spend too much. H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but not on busy days like Saturday. I'm careful and know what I want. I look in many shops to find the best price. I take a long time to shop. I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I don't like shopping. I work in the city, so shops are not exciting for me. I shop only when I have to and don't try clothes on. Sometimes clothes don't fit, but I don't mind. I prefer making a few mistakes to spending a lot of time shopping.'

Text: 'NEW CHANCES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University can give you a degree, just like any other university. But, you can keep working while you study. It can also help you find new hobbies. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will meet many different people. Your degree might also help you get a new job. You don't go to the Open University for classes. You study at home using TV, radio, and computer programs. You can go to one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams to take, like in any university. If you want to know more, just fill out the form below. It could be the start of a great new time in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, children can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**

The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist painted flowers in different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman gave this picture to the Gallery in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started on 15 March in the Sunley Room. The Gallery has new works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

There are lectures every Wednesday for the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery restaurant now has better service and more food choices. The new kitchens offer many hot and cold dishes at good prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery are every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For one group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are for learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons in small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum said I should find a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too excited at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they'll know how to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'The Outdoor Centre Fees are for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. Pay fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is a place for everyone to enjoy outdoor sports and fun activities. Groups should tell the centre before they visit. Windsurfing - One-day course Beginner windsurfing courses are on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very fun. You will remember the first time you sail across the water. Boards with small sails are for beginners. Course fee: £32.50 (includes all equipment) One-day adventure course This is a great chance for you. Try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is for adults to enjoy outdoor activities in a fun way. You do not need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. Course fee: £22.50 Play Park The Play Park is for children from two to ten years old. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a big ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship. Group day and residential courses We also have day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us often. There are three big rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12). Summer adventure holidays (for 8-14 years old) Sailing Climbing Windsurfing Fun Games Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and can teach the activities. We make sure all children do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health.'

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people, young and old, enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun and interesting hobby. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections. This hobby can last a lifetime.

Starting a stamp collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find stamps on holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends. These stamps can come from all over the world.

If you want to collect stamps seriously, you can join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps. You can receive these stamps in three ways: 

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. We can send you individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too. A two-year membership costs just £5. If a group of you join together, you can get a discount. This is great value for money.

When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide to collecting. This guide has tips on how to add to your collection and includes addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the club magazine. It has competitions, quizzes, and lets you exchange stamps with members around the world.

Why not start this fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection and searching for rare ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and enjoy the excitement of stamp collecting.

To join, fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the euro are like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. A five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that is cheap to make. Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. In those times, Mr. Green the farmer traded the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each with something the other wanted. But over time, most societies made their own 'currencies' so people could trade more easily. The different currencies started to join together, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like. Here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, many people wrote about love, family, and problems with friends. You need to make ordinary situations interesting for readers. Write about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure it is correct. Do not write about things you are not sure about. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is not good. Develop the story carefully and think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story seem real by using good words. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email.
