You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your fee of £5 will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story. The closing date is 30 July and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she got the best education. This was not common because most women then could not study much. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have her books, but we know she wrote important math works. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented some scientific tools. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people connected with it were in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometres long. It goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometre extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the quiet end of the line.

**Fares:**  
- Adult: £10.00  
- Child: £5.00  
- Family (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00  
- Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. You can have a full day out with your family here. There are many hectares of parkland with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a small railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station has a special collection of old trains from Europe. You can see famous trains like the De Glen Compound from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can visit these trains all year, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do at the railway or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Book one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a great place for family events or company visits. You can have an interesting afternoon or evening here. Special programmes can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, and discos. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Text: 'Grass Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grass, and they are found everywhere on earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can live in the cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food.'

Text: 'The Young Achiever of the Year Kal Kaur Rai loves fashion and has just won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked drawing clothes and making patterns. She didn't tell her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her job. She thought they wanted her to have a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in an advertising agency. She had to go to events but couldn't buy the expensive clothes she liked, so she started making skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs. Her clothes sold well, and nothing was returned. This made her confident to leave her job, take a PS20,000 loan, and start her own women's clothing brand. Kal's parents were not upset about her new career and said they would support her, which made her happy. Her clothes are now sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over PS500,000. Her designs are in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has just won this award. Her business has grown a lot, and she feels very lucky. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.''

**SUNNINGDALE HOTEL**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given great service to people from all over the world. Over 50,000 guests from 174 countries have visited Sunningdale in the past 80 years.

The hotel is on a main road to the town centre. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the town centre. Buses to many parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Guests should not take buses with the blue sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 metres away.

The main building has 200 single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking for cars in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and stamps can be bought at the office.

Guests staying for a long time must pay weekly in advance. They must give one week's notice before leaving. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first.

Meal times are: breakfast 7 am - 9.30 am; lunch 1 pm - 2 pm; dinner 5.30 pm - 7 pm. During the week, dinner can be requested until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires are allowed. Guests should keep noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the volume low.

Guests should use taxis to get to the hotel if they arrive by train because the hotel is far from the main railway station.

Text: 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. But, life wasn't always easy for him. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he liked being in school plays. After he finished high school, Tom went to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also went to drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he was so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, making millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and is very popular with his many fans from all over the world.'

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat went into a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she thought. The driver found her after he drove more than 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day. The driver and the cat were both hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking questions. He called his last customers, but they did not lose a cat. It was late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. The cat's owner was also looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that came to a neighbour's house. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely back home.'

The Ghan Train

Mark Ottaway took a train trip from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north through a big desert to the colder south. People often call it the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. 

The idea of a train line between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. But there was a lot of flooding, which made it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The train can go up to 115 kph, but it is not a fast city train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan is not as luxurious as the Orient Express, but the food on the train is very good. 

The railway was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to the south of Australia through Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. The Ghan says it is the world's first north-south railway. 

When I waited to get on the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the trip. Most of the other passengers were older Australians. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the train waited for four hours. Some people got off and took a boat trip. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so our group just walked around it and watched the sunset. 

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many people stop here. After Alice Springs, the view from the train is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But on the third day, at dawn, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and even though the train did not do everything the ads promised, it took me to some of the most amazing places in Australia.

Text: 'Climbing to the top of Britain Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, my first big winter climb. We went up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is six hundred metres high - maybe the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is so hard it feels like ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we took all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path soon went up, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but when I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that next time I would train better before a climb. After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half metres wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. But we were not so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to slopes too dangerous to go down in winter. I was happy we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.'

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we moved to our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this school is special because it is very good for the environment. It took many months to build, so we watched it happen. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it was sad to lose some nice open space. The building machines were very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building might never be finished.

Now, we have five big classrooms, much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people in the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We can't wait to use them when our new sports field is ready.

When you come into the school, you will see there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound inside too. When we sing, it sounds like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is the tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday. It spins very fast and is so big you can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on the website.

Even though we are using the school now, some parts are not finished yet. For example, we are doing a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Do you want to join a book club and buy new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many people already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

- Send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

- Save money on the publishers' prices.
- Tick the box on your form to get a free watch.
- Reply within seven days to get another free gift from our book list.
- Order a DVD at half the usual price.

**When you've joined:**

- Books come straight to your door.

**Being a member:**

- After that, choose as many books as you want.

Text: 'A month ago, I didn't know that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 metres above the ground and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below me and understood why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place to stay wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn't know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock-climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we were out at last - covered in mud but happy and excited about what we did.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. In it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and the telephone rang soon after. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to drive over to return it. I got my handbag back, with everything inside untouched. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the scariest animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if sharks are turned over on their backs, they can stop moving. This helps researchers who study sharks. It lets them learn more about these interesting animals.'

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, and back from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, flights with Air Australia between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. Coach from Sydney to Melbourne via Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia. Nineteen nights' stay in good hotels with full continental breakfast. Day trip to Ayers Rock, a full day boat trip to the Barrier Reef, a visit to an Australian sheep farm, and city tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes. Hotel baggage handling. Experienced Globewise Tour Manager for the whole trip. PERTH Beautiful long, golden beaches, great restaurants, green parks, and the lovely Swan River. City tour included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs in the heart of Aboriginal country. Full tour included. See Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Drive to Yulara National Park. Visit the Olgas and Ayers Rock with its caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Fly to the seaside town of Cairns and relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF A full day's boat trip on the famous reef with the chance to see amazing, colorful fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY Enjoy the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city - a city tour and a visit to the famous Opera House are included. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE A city tour is included - or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip you'll want to return!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I joined the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. I was one of the youngest foreign students. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they spoke in English, so we could talk. Now, six months later, everyone is nice to me. My Russian is much better, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I was a bit sad. I called home late at night once because I felt lonely. The classes in Russia are harder than in England, and I eat a lot to have energy. This helps me perform well. In the evenings, I watch my favourite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the film ends. Now, I feel at home here. I like walking around the city and going to the shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was not very cold for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cosy. We are preparing for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers. I will enter the competition. I feel very lucky to be here.'

Text: 'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. But in winter, only a few people lived there with the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people thought the cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an art show in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, brought many visitors. One night, some visitors decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel started. Today, it is famous around the world. When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and new parts open each week until January 7th when the hotel is finished. The ICEHOTEL is built outside with natural winter materials, so the finish date can change because of the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it is colder outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the price for guests. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, a scarf, and many wool socks. They should choose shoes that are bigger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these things when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive. The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. About 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's normal hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours on the first day. However, it had to close in just half an hour. A police officer said: 'The police knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could enter. They did not want to wait quietly. Also, there was a long line of cars trying to get to the car park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again.'

Text: 'Membership The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now very active. Society Magazines We make great magazines, like the popular Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories by top British writers and gives new writers a chance to print their work. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can read some articles on our website. National Short Story Competition We have the National Short Story Competition, the biggest one like it. Anyone aged 18 and over can enter, and stories can be about any topic. Stories should be 1,000 to 1,500 words long. Members enter for free, but non-members pay PS5. The competition is from April to October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's book of short stories. The winner gets a contract to publish their own book of short stories. Education For almost thirty years, the Society has brought writers to classrooms to help children and teachers with writing. One project is the Young Writer of the Year, started in 1998, for writers aged 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers. The Writers' Cafe The Writers' Cafe is the social place of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, with vegetarian food, good coffee, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the center of London and is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on some products and events. Becoming a Member We have members all over the world, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.'

Text: 'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter holds four world records in free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya Streeter made history. She was the first person to dive 120 metres into the ocean and come back up without help, all on one breath. She had gone deeper a year before, but she used a balloon to help her come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She was the only woman in any sport to break a man's world record. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people say free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents, but Tanya disagrees. She says safety and training are very important. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training is always the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym. The rest of her time is in the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she does not want to hurt her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. When she practices diving, she often travels. She does fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important she does not get tired, or it could ruin her training. When Tanya is not training, she appears in public to promote sports products. She also supports environmental groups by doing research or making films. Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved swimming and exploring rock pools to see sea life. Tanya says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. She is famous in some countries, so people listen to her about environmental issues. Tanya is in her thirties now and wants to keep breaking her own world records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and does not plan to stop for many years.'

Text: 'CARTOON FILMS Cartoon films can do many things. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons fun again for everyone. In the late 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for children. But soon, some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and children could enjoy cartoon films. However, not every cartoon film was a success. The Black Cauldron, for example, did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.'

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role. "I never thought I would spend some of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted at school before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the part. My mother was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6.00am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I want to be an actress. I'm not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't got any offers yet. I don't know how I did it all because I had a busy social life too. When filming finished, I didn't know what to do. I've been in two college plays since then. I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my only goal was to make enough money to take care of my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a company that is growing quickly all over the world. Since we started, I have learned many things. You can find much of what I learned in this book because I think we, as a company, have something important to say about running a successful business without losing our true beliefs. This is not a typical business book, and it is not just about my life. The message is that to succeed in business, you have to be different. Business can be fun, it can be run with love, and it can do good things. In business, like in life, I need to enjoy myself, feel like part of a family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I hope there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can do. I find that exciting, and I hope you do, too.'

Text: 'A TRIP ON THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER VOYAGES JULES VERNE has a 'hotel ship' on the Douro river in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can take 160 guests in double rooms. All rooms have a private shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library. Itinerary Day 1 Leave in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Your guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will sleep. Day 2 In the morning, you will see Oporto. Then, you will return to the ship and go to Entre-os-Rios. This trip takes four hours. Day 3 You will keep traveling up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, where port wine is made. At dinner, you can try the food and drink from this area. Day 4 After breakfast, you will go by bus to the old town of Lamego and visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum was once a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. You will then return to the ship and sail to Tua. Day 5 Here, the Douro is very narrow. Depending on the river's depth, you may continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return trip to Tua is by bus, and there is much to see. Day 6 In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. You will return to the ship for lunch and then take the Douro river valley train to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will wait for you. Day 7 There will be a trip to Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then going down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on the Lady Ivy May. Day 8 You will arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before your flight home to London Heathrow.'

Text: 'HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It has water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometres and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The colour and taste of honey depend on the type of flower. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-coloured honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very important to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research says it can help with tiredness and improve sports performance. Honey is not just food - it can help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.'

Norwich Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a part of Britain. People have lived there for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By 1066, during the Norman invasion, it was one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a popular place for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th birthday. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it got a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. But in the 16th century, it was the second biggest city in England. It grew for 300 years and became rich, known for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has many students and is a modern business center, especially for insurance services. Norwich offers many entertainment options: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. It also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors.

A new shopping center called 'The Castle Mall' is a big attraction in Norwich. For over two years, people lived with a big hole in the city while builders worked. They moved a lot of earth to make a park on top of the Mall, with water pools and trees. People in Norwich are happy that the old market is still there, next to the new shopping center. Both places are busy, showing that Norwich has a good mix of old and new.

Text: 'The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, becomes full of bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons, and they took off from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries are expected at the festival's current location outside the city. What to see The pilots talk to each other by radio and light up their balloons at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. You must arrive just after night falls or before 5.30 am to see these 'glows' as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to take off. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, and some like famous products such as soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere, and you can enjoy a view of the festival from above. There are many other things to do for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the first and last three nights of the festival. The Albuquerque Box This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This means that by going up or down, skilled pilots can control where their balloons go. Practical advice Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long lines at the festival. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are important. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, bring your camera. If you don't use a digital camera, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.'

Text: 'The Eden Project The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. Since it opened, it has become one of the UK's most popular places to visit. The big 'biospheres' there look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone. This shows visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is amazing to see how many things we use every day come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. There are over 135,000 different types of plants grown here. Even if it is cold outside, electric heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always wet because of a big waterfall. Another zone has the climate of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. There are also plans to build a desert zone soon.'

Text: 'No Title Some people have said bad things about this year's book, New Writing 3, but I don't know why. 500 pages of new writing for only £6.99 is great! Most of the book is fiction, with parts of novels and short stories. There are fun stories by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. It's interesting that the less famous writers mostly wrote about food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - don't read it after eating. It has some scenes that might make you feel sick! There is also good work from nineteen poets, like R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are parts of novels being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a little non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers, and an amazing piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is a special collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will have.'

Text: 'No Title "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when you are learning about the world." Margaret lives in London and likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some five-year-olds who are very interested. She started teaching the violin in 1972, and her first class was with her children's five-year-old friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson is one hour long, every two weeks. Also, each student has one private lesson with her every week. Parents must come to the classes too. It is important that parents are interested in the lessons. From the first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading music. Margaret says her method is not to make great violinists. She suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin with more traditional methods.

Text: 'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' is the follow-up to 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar instead of Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined as the new drummer. The first song on the CD is a dance tune, showing that the band is not focusing on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance songs will surprise many fans. Both songs could become hit singles because they are very good. Singer Rob Letchford sings perfectly on these songs. Fans should be happy he recorded them before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets should not worry because all the concerts will be rescheduled when Rob is better.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from slow songs to ones that make you want to dance. I think the best songs are at the beginning, and the last few songs are not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' will likely be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

San Francisco

San Francisco is on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He first saw it in 1769. Even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbour, it was found by land, not by sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people made money by owning banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists come to San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It tells about everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about big news stories, like disease, an enemy navy on the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even his faults - he often slept in church or looked at pretty girls. He talks about his home life - a fight with his wife and how they made up, his worry about her illness. He liked books, music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, people did not care if shoes were comfortable or fashionable. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles when it was cold. We still use leather today, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton, depending on what is popular. Only one hundred and fifty years ago, people started wearing a different shoe on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now most shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many cheap shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I wanted to help more women try running, to show them it can be fun and to help them feel confident to start running. I started a running club for women in my area because I was upset with some race organisers. They complain there are not enough women in the sport, but they also don't provide separate changing rooms for women. I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. They liked the idea of losing weight, but I don't think they thought much about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined hard training. They didn't think about chatting and smiling while running in nice places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only one minute. Now, they can run for thirty minutes. They also learned from other runners about eating well and staying fit. I wanted to help women's running, and I have enjoyed watching their progress - almost as much as they have.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there to find gold and become rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew fast and became the largest city in Alaska for a short time. 

In summer, boats could bring important things to these towns. But in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, so boats could not travel. In 1910, a winter path was made for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to cross Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers and dogs could rest and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s. Then, airplanes started to replace boats and dog teams. But in 1925, a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The medicine to cure it was in Anchorage, far away. Airplanes were new, and people were not sure if they could fly in the cold. The best pilot, Carl Eielson, was not there. So, they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine. 

The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly on the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams six days to finish. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He trusted his dog Togo to find the way in the snow. Togo was a good guide. The last part was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had worked with dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. Balto saved the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race happens every year from Anchorage to Nome. It follows the 1925 journey and is called the Iditarod, known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland. In winter, it can be very cold, sometimes -40°C. But 6,000 people visit every year to see a very special hotel. In this hotel, you eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you want. The bar is also made of ice, so you should not put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. You can also get warm clothes if you need them. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in summer. Every winter, they build it again. They use 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow to make the hotel.'

Text: 'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in a boys' team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' A local newspaper wrote about the story, and Jose Craveirinha, who helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He saw that she was very fast. 'He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work and my legs hurt a lot.' But Jose talked to her parents and convinced them she could be successful and this would help their family. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally agreed to train in the United States. She had said no before because she would miss her family. Her life was different from the girls she met in the US. She says, 'They were good athletes but, while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were great and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs and most of the year she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.'

Text: 'The Skywalk The Grand Canyon in the United States was made by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk and run, but mostly to see the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, many people have visited it. You have to wear special covers on your shoes to keep the glass clean. Walking on the Skywalk makes you feel like a bird flying high in the air.'

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains are a long mountain range in North America. They start in the northwest and go down to the center of the continent. The Rockies are smaller than the Alps, but they are still very beautiful. There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You can start your trip in Vancouver, a very nice city in Canada. Vancouver is close to the sea and the mountains, so people can ski just 15 minutes from the city center. In the past, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to travel across the country. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still exciting. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will miss some of the beautiful views at night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China had a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many old zoos, animals had to perform for visitors. This does not happen now. Today, zoos let people see animals acting naturally. Most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. But not everyone likes zoos. Some people think zoos are good because they help us learn about animals and nature. Without zoos, this would be hard. Other people do not like zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and eat bad food.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different clothes, from black school uniforms like my band wore, to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to playing in competitions, so the music was really good, especially because everyone was so young. Players from each band even made new tunes on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play can join - only about half can. But anyone who wants to play goes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps around the country - I've been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't hard enough for people like me who are serious about music. But I find it exciting because it's both new and old at the same time - you can make your own music, but you also feel you're part of its history, as you're playing on stage like great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert It can rain anytime between November and March in Marrakesh, Morocco. It doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning the streets into rivers. But, because many winters have been dry recently, when it rains, local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens exist not because of the rain, but because of underground channels. These channels were dug in the 11th century and bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. Further south from Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow in winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has older brothers who work in banking and computers. But Gareth always wanted to be a clown. 

Three years ago, Alan lost his job. So, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. 'People laugh when we tell them,' says Kath. 'But it's true. Gareth wanted to be a clown since he was three years old, after we took him to the circus.'

Alan and Kath found jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house when they are away.

'It wasn't easy,' says Kath. 'We had a lot to plan. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths.'

'People ask about my education,' says Gareth. 'But everywhere we go, someone comes to teach me. I use the same books as my classmates at school, and I have a computer. I have never fallen behind.'

And the future? 'It was a hard choice,' says Kath, 'but it was the only way for Gareth to learn to be a clown. I'm happy it's working, and we like it.'

And Gareth? 'I want to be the main clown in a circus one day,' he says, 'maybe Bippo's circus.'

Text: 'Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. Our members are aged 8-18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to big newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. The stories by our members that are accepted can be read or listened to on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three places around the country where young people can meet other members and join projects. We plan to open more places. Our news group started in 1994 and was called 'Young News'. Since then, over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I sat with young journalists and was amazed by the chances they had. Age wasn't important, they did the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen centre in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learnt, I got a job at 19, and now I am the youngest worker on a big news website, checking articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll be trained and take part in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members who are 12 years old and over. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they get better, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who go with them on these trips. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next new-members' training will be in February. If you, or someone you know, is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen programme is good for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free and there is no test to join.'

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, we take tourists in a big plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not set yet, but if you book now, you can change the date if needed.

**Questions**

Here are answers to common questions about our flights.

**How long is the flight?**

The flight is about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica and the rest of the time flying back. On the way, experts who have lived in Antarctica talk about the environment and history. A camera near the pilot shows you what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers get two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you change seats. Business and first class passengers have a window seat for half of the flight. Economy passengers have a window seat or a seat next to it for half of the flight. Over Antarctica, you can walk around the plane to see the sights. The pilot flies in 'figure 8s' so everyone can see well.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different flight plans. The captain checks the weather on the morning of the flight and chooses the best route for clear views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most wildlife is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them well. We do not land in Antarctica to protect the environment. To see wildlife, you need a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes! You can bring your camera. We also have fun photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For one group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are for learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons in small classes are very popular, and there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum said I should have a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too excited at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they'll know how to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can be at the top of a hill. Ice might be under the melting snow, ready to make you slide off the road. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick movements can make a car hard to control. So when you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive so you don't spill it. Rule Number Two is to watch what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London to study law, but he went to art school instead. He found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. In his late twenties, he got money from the Italian government to study art. He liked early Italian artists, and this shows in his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian fields and the clear light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted colours thinly, one on top of another, from light to dark. He says he never knows what the final painting will look like. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colours - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colours next to.' He never makes drawings before he starts a painting. He thinks if he did, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are done. He likes models who don't ask to see their pictures while he is painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he does not feel part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we did not like the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben said, 'and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band started coming to our home with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house is full of the sound of their instruments and their singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts playing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must say that, although their music sounds a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot say if they are good at music - after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Text: 'Atlantic College Last week I visited Atlantic College, a private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives young people important experiences outside the classroom, and they can also study for their exams. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from all over the world. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, taking care of people with learning difficulties, or checking for pollution in rivers. One great thing about Atlantic College is that students come from different countries and backgrounds. Not many can pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, so there are grants to help. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only go because they get help from the government. "I really admire the college for trying to encourage international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even the ones you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn't believe how much less I argued with my sister." In conclusion, Atlantic College gives its students a great education with methods that really work.'

Text: 'Being an older student I am 32 years old and I have just finished my first year at university. I go to lectures, read books quickly, and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. I worked as a secretary and made good money, but I was bored because I did not have to think much. I felt sad because I thought I would stay in that job forever. I was jealous of the students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope, and I wanted to be like them. Now that I am a student, it is hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am happy to study because I need a qualification to get a good job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I like spending weekends with my books more than going to parties. I also enjoy student benefits like long holidays and discounts at the theatre and cinema. Sometimes I worry about what I will do after university, but I hope going back to school was a good choice.'

Text: 'Henry Ford Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not like farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cheap cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant less choice. 'You can have any color you like,' said Henry Ford of the Model T, 'as long as it's black.' '

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your ad for English courses in the newspaper. I want to know more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course is 6 weeks long and it costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course for 10 weeks for £200. I hope this helps. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain in the world, she was a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and her family and went to Asia with some other climbers. She found that life on Everest is difficult. 'You must carry everything on your back,' she said, 'so you can only take things that you need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I am usually a clean person, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now she has written a book about the trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She has a new job too, on a science program on television. Rebecca is well known today and she has more money, but she still lives in the little apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!'

Text: 'Dear Mike, I am sorry you could not come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and you stayed in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a very good party; the best I have ever had! Many of my friends were there and they gave me some nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. Love, Lorenzo'

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are big blue and white birds. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to where it is warmer. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane, and he decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he went on short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When the cold weather came in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to come back. They didn't come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He looked for them for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends went to college, but Esther used the money from her aunt to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon doubled the £500. At first, her parents didn't want Esther to make jam. They thought she should study and become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther didn't listen. She kept making jam. After a few months, she sold it at the local market. Then she started making orange juice and sold it to a school where her friend worked. After two years, her business was very big, and her parents were happy. She made many kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she needed people to help her.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I am very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go? I hope you like the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline '

Corryvale Farm Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens. They sell milk and eggs. But most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep. Each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they don't get too warm. Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer and the weather was hot, so people didn't want to buy sweaters. Then she made some socks. Everybody loved them because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. That's how Jenny's business started. At first, she made the socks at home. But soon, she had many customers, so she sent the wool to a factory. Now, all the socks are made on machines. There are six colours, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a favourite present. On the walls of Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made many new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher very much. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS LIKE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people go out and forget to close a door or a window. He reported that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. But he said that winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark and they can't be seen easily. Also, many houses are empty at that time because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This will help to keep burglars away. He also asked neighbours to watch the other houses in the street when people are not at home. They should call the police if they see anything strange. 'We will also tell you how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help costs nothing.''

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, I'm writing to say thank you for the two nights I stayed in your nice home. It was good to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you asked for. They're good photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. I am going to visit my sister in New York next week. I will take a lot of photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time. Thanks again. Love, Roy '

Text: 'The History of Farming Before people started farming, they went to the forest to find plants or fruit to eat. This meant that people moved all the time to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow food. These people were the first farmers. Farming made it possible for people to stay in one place, and their villages became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other work, like making clothes, because the farmers grew food for everyone. But farming was hard when the weather was bad, and then some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels thousands of kilometres from where it is grown to our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a small airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Then she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years later, she got her current job as a manager. This is what she told us about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach air hostesses and help them with problems. I also go to many meetings. My work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check plane times on my computer, and then I talk with some of the air hostesses. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I like office work, too. Traveling can be hard work. When I come back from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, It's nice to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8.30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a big blue bag and my name is on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms Johnson, I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6.30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson '

Text: 'People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for different jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers watched the sky, animals, and flowers to learn about the weather. Now, there are computer programs that help us know about the weather, and people can get weather information on their phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.'

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They are friends and classmates. They like to go fishing or swimming on weekends. But for the last few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room using his laptop. This is not because of homework. They made a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin. Kevin has problems with reading. He learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing sounds. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked for over 200 hours to make the game. Now it is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, if you see the word 'hat', there is a picture of a hat and you can hear Peter say 'Hat! Hat!' The boys have won many prizes for their game. It will soon be sold around the world. Many schools want to buy it.'

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I go to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But it is hard to sleep at night after a concert because I think about the music. Sport is important. Before my car accident, I went to the sports centre for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. I can't do that now, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well. I drink a lot of water because it's good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always drink that much. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but I like doing other things too. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's good to do nothing sometimes. I don't get tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now I eat lots of things like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

Text: 'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. Bollywood makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, making it the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians like watching films more than any other free-time activity, and ten million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films usually tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important in every film. Indian films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood made over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they do not earn as much money. This is why most Bollywood films cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film usually costs more than $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan is different. Some people say he is India's greatest actor. He has been the star of more than 140 films in almost 40 years of acting.

Text: 'Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have lived in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happier because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and I want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so it will be four more years before we can return. I just went to England for six weeks to work on a radio show about the English language and to talk about the book I just wrote. Most writers don't like doing this; they don't like traveling around the country to sell their book. I don't mind it. I like visiting new places and meeting many people. It's very different from my life in the United States when I'm writing. In England, people drove me in big cars and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me and it was fun.'

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer came later.
